subsection.text: In this division the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Adaptive reuse” means a change granted by a legislative body under § 4–207 of this article to the use restrictions in a zoning classification, as those restrictions are applied to a particular improved property.
“Charter county” means a county that has adopted charter home rule under Article XI–A of the Maryland Constitution and Article 25A of the Code.
“Code county” means a county that has adopted code home rule under Article XI–F of the Maryland Constitution and Article 25B of the Code.
“County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: “Development” means an activity that materially affects the existing condition or use of any land or structure.
“Development” does not include a normal agricultural activity.
“Legislative body” means the elected body of a local jurisdiction.
“Legislative body” includes:

subparagraph.text: the board of county commissioners;
the county council; and
the governing body of a municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: “Local executive” means the chief executive of a local jurisdiction.
“Local executive” includes:

subparagraph.text: the board of county commissioners;
the county executive;
the executive head; and
the mayor.

subsection.text: “Local jurisdiction” means a county or municipal corporation and the territory within which its powers may be exercised.

paragraph.text: “Local law” means an enactment of the legislative body of a local jurisdiction, whether by ordinance, resolution, or otherwise.
“Local law” does not include a public local law.

subsection.text: “Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, representative of any kind, partnership, firm, association, corporation, limited liability company, or other entity.

paragraph.text: “Plan” means the policies, statements, goals, and interrelated plans for private and public land use, transportation, and community facilities documented in texts and maps that constitute the guide for an area’s future development.
“Plan” includes a general plan, master plan, comprehensive plan, functional plan, or community plan adopted in accordance with Subtitle 4 of this title and Title 3 of this article.

subsection.text: “Priority funding area” has the meaning stated in § 5–7B–02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: “Regulation” means a rule of general applicability and future effect.
“Regulation” includes a map or plan.

subsection.text: “Sensitive area” includes:

paragraph.text: a stream or wetland, and its buffers;
a 100–year flood plain;
a habitat of a threatened or endangered species;
a steep slope;
agricultural or forest land intended for resource protection or conservation; and
any other area in need of special protection, as determined in a plan.

subsection.text: “Special exception” means a grant of a specific use that:

paragraph.text: would not be appropriate generally or without restriction; and
shall be based on a finding that:

subparagraph.text: the requirements of the zoning law governing the special exception on the subject property are satisfied; and
the use on the subject property is consistent with the plan and is compatible with the existing neighborhood.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, “state” means:

subparagraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

paragraph.text: When capitalized, “State” means Maryland.
“Subdivision” means:

subparagraph.text: the process and configuration of land by which one or more lots, tracts, or parcels of land are divided, consolidated, or established as one or more lots or parcels, or other divisions of land, consistent with criteria established by the legislative body of the local jurisdiction; or
the land so subdivided.

paragraph.text: “Subdivision” includes resubdivision.

subsection.text: “Variance” means a modification only of density, bulk, dimensional, or area requirements in the zoning law that is not contrary to the public interest, and where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not because of any action taken by the applicant, a literal enforcement of the zoning law would result in unnecessary hardship or practical difficulty, as specified in the zoning law.

paragraph.text: “Zoning law” means the legislative implementation of regulations for zoning by a local jurisdiction.
“Zoning law” includes a zoning ordinance, zoning regulation, zoning code, and any similar legislative action to implement zoning controls in a local jurisdiction.

section.text: In addition to the requirements of § 3–201(a) and (b) of this article, a planning commission shall implement the following visions through the comprehensive plan described in Title 3 of this article:

paragraph.text: quality of life and sustainability: a high quality of life is achieved through universal stewardship of the land, water, and air resulting in sustainable communities and protection of the environment;
public participation: citizens are active partners in the planning and implementation of community initiatives and are sensitive to their responsibilities in achieving community goals;
growth areas: growth is concentrated in existing population and business centers, growth areas adjacent to these centers, or strategically selected new centers;

community design: compact, mixed–use, walkable design consistent with existing community character and located near available or planned transit options is encouraged to ensure efficient use of land and transportation resources and preservation and enhancement of natural systems, open spaces, recreational areas, and historical, cultural, and archaeological resources;
infrastructure: growth areas have the water resources and infrastructure to accommodate population and business expansion in an orderly, efficient, and environmentally sustainable manner;

transportation: a well–maintained, multimodal transportation system facilitates the safe, convenient, affordable, and efficient movement of people, goods, and services within and between population and business centers;
housing: a range of housing densities, types, and sizes provides residential options for citizens of all ages and incomes;

economic development: economic development and natural resource–based businesses that promote employment opportunities for all income levels within the capacity of the State’s natural resources, public services, and public facilities are encouraged;

environmental protection: land and water resources, including the Chesapeake and coastal bays, are carefully managed to restore and maintain healthy air and water, natural systems, and living resources;
resource conservation: waterways, forests, agricultural areas, open space, natural systems, and scenic areas are conserved;
stewardship: government, business entities, and residents are responsible for the creation of sustainable communities by collaborating to balance efficient growth with resource protection; and

implementation: strategies, policies, programs, and funding for growth and development, resource conservation, infrastructure, and transportation are integrated across the local, regional, State, and interstate levels to achieve these visions.

subsection.text: A regulation adopted under this division that conflicts with any statute, local law, or other regulation shall govern if the regulation adopted under this division:

paragraph.text: requires a greater width or size of yards, courts, or other open spaces;
requires a lower height of buildings;
requires a reduced number of stories;
requires a greater percentage of lot left unoccupied; or
imposes a more restrictive standard.

subsection.text: A statute, local law, or other regulation that conflicts with a regulation adopted under this division shall govern if the statute, local law, or other regulation:

paragraph.text: requires a greater width or size of yards, courts, or other open spaces;
requires a lower height of buildings;
requires a reduced number of stories;
requires a greater percentage of lot left unoccupied; or
imposes a more restrictive standard.
This subsection applies to the Maryland–Washington Regional District established under Chapter 992 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1943.

This division does not supplement Chapter 992 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1943 if a local agency located within the Maryland–Washington Regional District administers municipal and regional planning and zoning.

In the Maryland–Washington Regional District, the additional and supplemental powers vested by this division in a legislative body may not be considered vested in and may not be exercised by a county council acting as a district council under Chapter 992 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1943.

In the Maryland–Washington Regional District, the powers vested by this division in a planning commission or board of appeals may not be considered vested in and may not be exercised by the Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission, the planning board, or the board of zoning appeals of the affected county.
Provisions of this division that are inconsistent with or contrary to Chapter 992 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1943 do not apply in the Maryland–Washington Regional District.
This division does not affect the validity of Chapter 992 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1943.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this division, any law or ordinance that is inconsistent with or contrary to this division is repealed to the extent of the inconsistency.

subsection.text: Other public general laws that may affect land use in a local jurisdiction under this division, Division II of this article, or otherwise, include:

paragraph.text: Article 23A, §§ 2(30) and (36), 9, 19, and 19A(e) of the Code;
Article 25, § 3 of the Code;
Article 25A, § 5 of the Code;
Article 25B, § 13 of the Code; and
Title 8, Subtitle 18 of the Natural Resources Article.

subsection.text: The inclusion or exclusion of a provision of public general law in this section may not be construed to imply any relationship between the provision and land use matters included in this article.

section.text: The requirement or authorization for a local jurisdiction to enact a local law to implement a provision of this division is not intended to alter in any way the form or legislative mechanism that the applicable enabling authority requires for the local jurisdiction to enact the local law, whether by ordinance, resolution, or otherwise, as of October 1, 2012.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “planning commission” includes a planning commission or board established under:

subparagraph.text: Title 2 of this article;
Division II of this article; or
Article 25A of the Code.

paragraph.text: Within 6 months after appointment to a planning commission, a member shall complete an education course that includes education on:

subparagraph.text: the role of the comprehensive plan;
if applicable, proper standards for special exceptions and variances; and
the local jurisdiction’s local laws and regulations relating to zoning, planned development, subdivision, and other land use matters.

paragraph.text: The failure of a member to complete an education course under this subsection may not:

subparagraph.text: invalidate a decision of the planning commission; or
be construed to create a private cause of action by any person.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “board of appeals” includes a board of appeals established under:

subparagraph.text: Title 4, Subtitle 3 of this article;
§ 10–403 of this article;
Division II of this article; or
Article 25A of the Code.

paragraph.text: Within 6 months after appointment to a board of appeals, a member shall complete an education course that includes education on:

subparagraph.text: the role of the comprehensive plan;
proper standards for special exceptions and variances; and
the local jurisdiction’s local laws and regulations relating to zoning, planned development, subdivision, and other land use matters.

paragraph.text: The failure of a member to complete an education course under this subsection may not:

subparagraph.text: invalidate a decision of the board; or
be construed to create a private cause of action by any person.

subsection.text: In this section, “planning commission” includes a planning commission or board established under:

paragraph.text: Title 2 of this article;
Division II of this article; or
Article 25A of the Code.

subsection.text: On or before July 1 of each year, a planning commission shall prepare, adopt, and file an annual report for the previous calendar year with the legislative body.
The annual report shall:

paragraph.text: index and locate on a map any changes in development patterns that occurred during the period covered by the report, including:

subparagraph.text: land use;
transportation;
community facilities patterns;
zoning map amendments; and
subdivision plats;

paragraph.text: state whether the changes under item (1) of this subsection are consistent with:

subparagraph.text: each other;
the recommendations of the last annual report;
the adopted plans of the local jurisdiction;
the adopted plans of all adjoining local jurisdictions; and
the adopted plans of State and local jurisdictions that have responsibility for financing or constructing public improvements necessary to implement the local jurisdiction’s plan;

paragraph.text: contain statements and recommendations for improving the planning and development process within the local jurisdiction;
state which local laws or regulations have been adopted or changed to implement the visions in § 1–201 of this subtitle as required under § 1–417 of this title or § 3–303 of this article; and
contain the measures and indicators required under § 1–208(c) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The legislative body shall review the annual report and direct that any appropriate and necessary studies and other actions be undertaken to ensure the continuation of a viable planning and development process.
The local jurisdiction shall make the annual report available for public inspection.

paragraph.text: The local jurisdiction shall mail a copy of the report to the Secretary of Planning.
The Department of Planning may comment on the report.

subsection.text: In this section, “National Center” means the National Center for Smart Growth Research and Education at the University of Maryland, College Park.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly finds that:

subparagraph.text: in addition to reporting on past land use indicators and measures, local jurisdictions should strive to achieve future land use goals that implement and achieve the visions in § 1–201 of this subtitle;
a statewide land use goal that embodies the visions in § 1–201 of this subtitle and smart and sustainable growth should be established;
the visions in § 1–201 of this subtitle will not be realized unless local jurisdictions set their own goal to make incremental progress towards achieving a statewide land use goal; and
resources are necessary to achieve a statewide goal, including funding for infrastructure inside the priority funding areas and land preservation outside the priority funding areas.
The statewide land use goal is to increase the current percentage of growth inside the priority funding areas and to decrease the percentage of growth located outside the priority funding areas.
Local jurisdictions shall develop a percentage goal towards achieving the statewide goal.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, the annual report required to be filed under § 1–207 of this subtitle shall include the following measures and indicators:

subparagraph.text: the amount, share, and net density of growth inside and outside the priority funding areas;
the creation of new lots and the issuance of residential and commercial building permits inside and outside the priority funding areas;
the development capacity analysis, updated every 3 years and whenever there is a significant change in zoning or land use patterns;
the number of acres preserved using local agricultural land preservation funding, if applicable; and
the following information on achieving the statewide goal stated in subsection (b)(2) of this section:

sub-subparagraph.text: the local goal;
the time frame for achieving the local goal;
the resources necessary for infrastructure inside the priority funding areas and land preservation outside the priority funding areas; and
any incremental progress made towards achieving the local goal.

paragraph.text: If all land within the boundaries of a municipal corporation is a priority funding area, the municipal corporation need not:

subparagraph.text: establish a local goal for achieving the statewide goal stated in subsection (b)(2) of this section; or
include information in the annual report on a local goal as required in paragraph (1)(v) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: A county or municipal corporation that issues fewer than 50 building permits for new residential units each year:

subparagraph.text: need not include information in the annual report on measures and indicators listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection; but
shall provide documentation to the Department of Planning each year that fewer than 50 building permits for new residential units are issued.

paragraph.text: In accordance with Title 2, Subtitle 5 and Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article, the Department of Planning may adopt regulations to detail how the measures and indicators required under subsection (c) of this section are submitted and transmitted in the annual report of each local jurisdiction.
The Department of Planning shall:

subparagraph.text: develop measures and indicators that will be collected by the Department; and
consider which measures or indicators may be collected by the National Center.

subsection.text: On or before January 1 of each year, the Department of Planning, in consultation with the National Center, shall submit a report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the measures and indicators collected under this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “action” means:

paragraph.text: the adoption of a local law or regulation concerning:

subparagraph.text: a special exception under § 1–101(p) of this title (Definitions – “Special exception”); or
plan implementation and review under § 1–417 of this title or § 3–303 of this article;

paragraph.text: a requirement under § 9–505(a)(1) of the Environment Article and Article 23A, § 19(o)(3)(iii) of the Code (Municipal annexation); or
a required finding under §§ 9–506(a)(1) and 9–507(b)(2) of the Environment Article (Water and sewer plan review).

section.text: This subtitle applies to:

paragraph.text: a special exception under § 1–101(p) of this title (Definitions – “Special exception”);
plan implementation and review under § 1–417 of this title or § 3–303 of this article;
§§ 9–505(a)(1), 9–506(a)(1), and 9–507(b)(2) of the Environment Article (Water and sewer plan review); and
Article 23A, § 19(o)(3)(iii) of the Code (Annexation plan).

section.text: Except as provided in § 1–304 of this subtitle, when a provision in a statute listed under § 1–302 of this subtitle requires an action to be “consistent with” or have “consistency with” a comprehensive plan, the term shall mean an action taken that will further, and not be contrary to, the following items in the plan:

paragraph.text: policies;
timing of the implementation of the plan;
timing of development;
timing of rezoning;
development patterns;
land uses; and
densities or intensities.

subsection.text: This section applies to plan implementation and review under § 1–301(1)(ii) of this subtitle.

In a priority funding area, if § 1–417 of this title or § 3–303 of this article requires an action to be “consistent with” or have “consistency with” a comprehensive plan, the term shall mean an action taken that will further, and not be contrary to, the following items in the plan:

paragraph.text: policies;
timing of the implementation of the plan;
timing of development;
timing of rezoning; and
development patterns.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this section, this division does not apply to charter counties.
The following provisions of this division apply to a charter county:

paragraph.text: this subtitle, including Parts II and III (Charter county – Comprehensive plans);
§ 1–101(l), (m), and (o) (Definitions – “Plan”, “Priority funding area”, and “Sensitive area”);
§ 1–201 (Visions);
§ 1–206 (Required education);
§ 1–207 (Annual report – In general);
§ 1–208 (Annual report – Measures and indicators);
Title 1, Subtitle 3 (Consistency);
Title 1, Subtitle 5 (Growth Tiers);
§ 4–104(b) (Limitations – Bicycle parking);
§ 4–208 (Exceptions – Maryland Accessibility Code);
§ 4–210 (Permits and variances – Solar panels);
§ 5–102(d) (Subdivision regulations – Burial sites);
§ 5–104 (Major subdivision – Review);
Title 7, Subtitle 1 (Development Mechanisms);
Title 7, Subtitle 2 (Transfer of Development Rights);
Except in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County, Title 7, Subtitle 3 (Development Rights and Responsibilities Agreements);
Title 7, Subtitle 4 (Inclusionary Zoning);
§ 8–401 (Conversion of overhead facilities);
For Baltimore County only, Title 9, Subtitle 3 (Single–County Provisions – Baltimore County);
For Howard County only, Title 9, Subtitle 13 (Single–County Provisions – Howard County);
For Talbot County only, Title 9, Subtitle 18 (Single–County Provisions – Talbot County); and
Title 11, Subtitle 2 (Civil Penalty).

subsection.text: This section supersedes any inconsistent provision of Division II of this article.
In addition to the powers the county may have had under this division before adopting code home rule, a code county may exercise the powers relating to land use stated in Article 25A of the Code.
A code county that chooses to exercise the powers relating to land use stated in Article 25A of the Code shall be treated as a charter county for purposes of § 1–401 of this subtitle.

section.text: A charter county shall enact, adopt, amend, and execute a plan in accordance with this part and Part III of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The planning commission for a charter county shall include in the comprehensive or general plan the visions under § 1–201 of this title and the following elements:

subparagraph.text: a development regulations element;
a sensitive areas element;
a transportation element; and
a water resources element.

paragraph.text: If current geological information is available, the plan shall include a mineral resources element.

subsection.text: The planning commission for a charter county may include in the plan a priority preservation area element developed in accordance with § 2–518 of the Agriculture Article.
The development regulations element shall include the planning commission’s recommendation for land development regulations to implement the plan.
The development regulations element shall encourage:

paragraph.text: the use of flexible development regulations to promote innovative and cost–saving site design and protect the environment; and
within the areas designated for growth in the plan:

subparagraph.text: economic development through the use of innovative techniques; and
streamlined review of applications for development, including permit review and subdivision plat review.

subsection.text: A sensitive areas element shall include the goals, objectives, principles, policies, and standards designed to protect sensitive areas from the adverse effects of development.

Before the plan is adopted, the Department of the Environment and the Department of Natural Resources shall review the sensitive areas element to determine whether the proposed plan is consistent with the programs and goals of the departments.
The transportation element may include all types of:

paragraph.text: airways;
highways or streets;
railways;
waterways;
routings for mass transit; and
terminals for individuals, goods, and vehicles related to airways, highways, railways, and waterways.

subsection.text: The transportation element shall:

paragraph.text: propose, on a schedule that extends as far into the future as is reasonable, the most appropriate and desirable patterns for:

subparagraph.text: the general location, character, and extent of channels, routes, and terminals for transportation facilities; and
the circulation of individuals and goods;

paragraph.text: provide for bicycle and pedestrian access and travelways; and
include an estimate of the use of any proposed improvement.

subsection.text: Considering available data provided by the Department of the Environment, the water resources element shall identify:

paragraph.text: drinking water and other water resources that will be adequate for the needs of existing and future development proposed in the land use element of the plan; and
suitable receiving waters and land areas to meet stormwater management and wastewater treatment and disposal needs of existing and future development proposed in the land use element of the plan.

subsection.text: The Department of the Environment shall:

paragraph.text: provide, on request of a local jurisdiction, technical assistance on the development of the water resources element; and

review the water resources element to determine whether the proposed plan is consistent with the programs and goals of the Department reflected in the general water resources program required under § 5–203 of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: The mineral resources element shall identify:

paragraph.text: undeveloped land that should be kept in its undeveloped state until the land can be used to assist in providing a continuous supply of minerals, as defined in § 15–801(i) of the Environment Article; and
appropriate postexcavation uses for the land that are consistent with the county’s land planning process.

subsection.text: A mineral resources element shall incorporate land use policies and recommendations for regulations:

paragraph.text: to balance mineral resource extraction with other land uses; and
to the extent feasible, to prevent the preemption of mineral resources extraction by other uses.

subsection.text: Before the plan is adopted, the Department of the Environment shall review the mineral resources element to determine whether the proposed plan is consistent with the programs and goals of the Department.

section.text: In addition to the requirements for the plan under Part II of this subtitle, a planning commission shall implement the visions set forth in § 1–201 of this title through the plan.

subsection.text: The planning commission of a charter county shall implement the visions set forth in § 1–201 of this title through the comprehensive plan elements required under Part II of this subtitle.

The legislative body of a charter county that has adopted a comprehensive plan under Part II of this subtitle may adopt regulations implementing the visions set forth in § 1–201 of this title in the plan.
At least once every 6 years, each planning commission shall review the comprehensive plan and, if necessary, revise or amend the comprehensive plan to include all:

paragraph.text: the elements required under Part II of this subtitle; and
the visions set forth in § 1–201 of this title.

subsection.text: The planning commission may prepare comprehensive plans for one or more geographic sections or divisions of the local jurisdiction if the plan for each geographic section or division is reviewed and, if necessary, revised or amended at least once every 6 years.

At least once every 6 years, which corresponds to the comprehensive plan revision process under § 1–416 of this subtitle, a charter county shall ensure the implementation of the visions, the development regulations element, and the sensitive areas element of the plan.
A charter county shall ensure that the implementation of the requirements of subsection (a) of this section are achieved through the adoption of applicable:

paragraph.text: zoning laws; and
local laws governing:

subparagraph.text: planned development;
subdivision; and
other land use provisions that are consistent with the comprehensive plan.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, on or before October 1, 2009, a charter county shall include in its comprehensive plan any plan element that is required under Part II of this subtitle.

On request of a charter county and for good cause, the Department of Planning may extend the deadline under subsection (a) of this section for that charter county by no more than two 6–month extensions.

A charter county that is not in compliance with this section after October 1, 2009, or after the expiration of any extension granted under subsection (b) of this section, may not change the zoning classification of a property until that charter county has complied with this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “planning board”:

paragraph.text: means a planning board established under this article; and
includes a planning commission or board established under Division II of this article or Article 25A of the Code.

section.text: On or before December 31, 2012, a local jurisdiction may adopt the mapped growth tiers in accordance with this subtitle.
Before adoption of the growth tiers, a local jurisdiction may submit the proposed tiers and any relevant information to the Department of Planning for:

paragraph.text: technical assistance, review, and comment; and
the opportunity for public review.

section.text: After adoption of the growth tiers, the local jurisdiction shall provide to the Department of Planning all information necessary to demonstrate the precise location of the tiers, including, as appropriate:

paragraph.text: a map of the area showing planning and zoning characteristics of each tier; and
existing and planned water and sewer services.

section.text: The Department of Planning may comment on the growth tiers adopted by the local jurisdictions.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (b), (c), and (d) of this section, a local jurisdiction that chooses to adopt growth tiers is not required to adopt all of the tiers.
A municipal corporation that exercises planning and zoning authority shall adopt Tier I and may adopt Tier II.
A county shall adopt Tiers I, III, and IV, and may adopt Tier II.
If a local jurisdiction does not adopt all of the tiers authorized under this section, the local jurisdiction shall document the reasons the jurisdiction is not adopting a particular tier.

If the Department of Planning comments under § 1–505 of this subtitle on any of the tiers or on an area within one of the tiers, the local legislative body or the planning board shall hold at least one public hearing on the comments by the Department of Planning.
The local legislative body or the planning board shall review the mapped growth tiers adopted by the local jurisdiction in light of the comments by the Department of Planning.

If the planning board holds the public hearing under subsection (a) of this section, after the public hearing and the consideration of the comments by the Department of Planning, the planning board shall recommend to the local jurisdiction that either the tiers or an area within the tiers:

paragraph.text: be changed; or
that the adopted tiers remain unchanged.

subsection.text: If the planning board recommends that the tiers or an area within the tiers be changed under subsection (c) of this section, the planning board shall provide the recommended mapped growth tier changes to the local jurisdiction.
The growth tiers adopted by a local jurisdiction shall meet the following criteria:

paragraph.text: Tier I areas are areas that are:

subparagraph.text: served by public sewerage systems and mapped locally designated growth areas; or
a municipal corporation that is a priority funding area that is served by public sewerage systems;

paragraph.text: Tier II areas are areas that are:

sub-subparagraph.text: planned to be served by public sewerage systems and in the municipal growth element; or
mapped locally designated growth areas; and

subparagraph.text: needed to satisfy demand for development at densities consistent with the long–term development policy after consideration of the capacity of land areas available for development, including in–fill and redevelopment, within the local jurisdiction;

paragraph.text: Tier III areas are areas that:

subparagraph.text: are not planned for sewerage service and not dominated by agricultural or forest land;
are not planned or zoned by a local jurisdiction for land, agricultural, or resource protection, preservation, or conservation; and
are one of the following:

sub-subparagraph.text: municipal corporations not served by a public sewerage system;
rural villages as described in § 5–7B–03(f) of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
mapped locally designated growth areas; or
areas planned and zoned for large lot and rural development; and

paragraph.text: Tier IV areas are areas that are not planned for sewerage service and are:

subparagraph.text: areas planned or zoned by a local jurisdiction for land, agricultural, or resource protection, preservation, or conservation;
areas dominated by agricultural lands, forest lands, or other natural areas; or

rural legacy areas, priority preservation areas, or areas subject to covenants, restrictions, conditions, or conservation easements for the benefit of, or held by a State agency, as defined in § 9–206 of the Environment Article, or a local jurisdiction for the purpose of conserving natural resources or agricultural land.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction shall strive to avoid creating a Tier III area that is bounded on all sides by land in a Tier IV area.
A local jurisdiction that adopts growth tiers shall incorporate the tiers into the comprehensive plan or an element of the plan:

paragraph.text: when the local jurisdiction conducts the 6–year review of the plan under § 1–416(a) or § 3–301(a) of this article; and
in accordance with the requirements of this section.

subsection.text: If a local jurisdiction does not incorporate all of the growth tiers authorized under this section into the comprehensive plan or an element of the plan, the local jurisdiction shall state that a tier is not adopted.

section.text: A local jurisdiction may establish by local law a planning commission with the powers and duties set forth in this division.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this division, a planning commission established under this subtitle shall consist of three, five, or seven members.
One member of the planning commission may be a member of the legislative body, who serves as an ex officio member concurrent with the member’s legislative term.
Except as otherwise provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the members of a planning commission shall be appointed by:

subparagraph.text: the legislative body; or
the person designated as the appointing authority in the local law establishing the planning commission.

paragraph.text: If there is a single elected local executive, the members of a planning commission shall be appointed by the local executive and confirmed by the legislative body.
The term of a member of a planning commission other than an ex officio member is:

subparagraph.text: 5 years; or
until the member’s successor takes office.

paragraph.text: The terms of the members of a planning commission shall be staggered.
After a public hearing, a legislative body may remove a member of a planning commission for:

subparagraph.text: inefficiency;
neglect of duty; or
malfeasance in office.

paragraph.text: A legislative body that removes a member of a planning commission shall file a written statement of the reasons for the removal.

subsection.text: If a vacancy occurs during the term of an appointed member, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term by the:

paragraph.text: legislative body; or
person designated as the appointing authority in the ordinance establishing the commission.
In a municipal corporation, the legislative body may designate one alternate member to sit on the planning commission in the absence of any member of the commission.
If an alternate member is absent, the legislative body may designate a temporary alternate member to sit on the planning commission.
From among its appointed members, a planning commission shall elect a chair.

subparagraph.text: The term of a chair is 1 year.
A chair may be reelected.

subsection.text: A planning commission may establish and select other officers that it considers appropriate.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a planning commission shall hold at least one regular meeting each month.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a planning commission appointed by a municipal corporation shall hold meetings quarterly, or more often as the planning commission’s duties require.
If there is no business before the planning commission, the chair may cancel the quarterly meeting.

subsection.text: Each member of a planning commission is entitled to the compensation that the legislative body considers appropriate.
A planning commission may:

paragraph.text: appoint the employees necessary for the performance of the planning commission’s functions; and
contract with planners, engineers, architects, and other consultants for services that the commission requires.
A planning commission shall have the powers necessary to enable the commission to fulfill its functions, promote planning, and execute the purposes of this division.

On a planning commission’s request, all public officials shall provide to the commission, within a reasonable time, available information that the commission may require for the performance of the planning commission’s functions.
In the performance of the planning commission’s functions, a planning commission and its members, officers, and employees may enter on any land and make examinations and surveys.
A planning commission may accept and use gifts and public or private grants for the performance of the commission’s functions.
A planning commission’s expenditures, other than gifts, shall be made in accordance with:

subparagraph.text: the conditions of the legislative body; and
the amount appropriated by the legislative body.

paragraph.text: The legislative body shall provide the funds, equipment, and accommodations necessary for the performance of the planning commission’s functions.
A planning commission shall:

subparagraph.text: adopt rules for the conduct of its business; and
keep records of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations.

paragraph.text: The records required under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be open to the public.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction shall enact, adopt, amend, and execute a plan in accordance with this division.
A municipal corporation may be included as part of a county plan under this division if:

paragraph.text: the legislative body of the municipal corporation, by resolution directed to the legislative body of the county where the municipal corporation is located, indicates the intention to participate in the county plan; and
the legislative body of the county approves the resolution.
The planning commission for a local jurisdiction shall include in the comprehensive plan the following elements:

subparagraph.text: a community facilities element;
an area of critical State concern element;
a goals and objectives element;
a land use element;
a development regulations element;
a sensitive areas element;
a transportation element; and
a water resources element.

paragraph.text: If current geological information is available, the plan shall include a mineral resources element.
The plan for a municipal corporation that exercises zoning authority shall include a municipal growth element.
The plan for a county that is located on the tidal waters of the State shall include a fisheries element.
The planning commission for a local jurisdiction may include in the plan additional elements to advance the purposes of the plan.
The additional elements may include:

subparagraph.text: community renewal elements;
conservation elements;
flood control elements;
housing elements;
natural resources elements;
pollution control elements;
the general location and extent of public utilities; and
a priority preservation area element developed in accordance with § 2–518 of the Agriculture Article.

subsection.text: The development regulations element shall include the planning commission’s recommendation for land development regulations to implement the plan.
The development regulations element shall encourage:

paragraph.text: the use of flexible development regulations to promote innovative and cost–saving site design and protect the environment; and
within the areas designated for growth in the plan:

subparagraph.text: economic development through the use of innovative techniques; and
streamlined review of applications for development, including permit review and subdivision plat review.

subsection.text: A sensitive areas element shall include the goals, objectives, principles, policies, and standards designed to protect sensitive areas from the adverse effects of development.

Before the plan is adopted, the Department of the Environment and the Department of Natural Resources shall review the sensitive areas element to determine whether the proposed plan is consistent with the programs and goals of the departments.
The transportation element may include all types of:

paragraph.text: airways;
highways or streets;
railways;
waterways;
routings for mass transit; and
terminals for individuals, goods, and vehicles related to airways, highways, railways, and waterways.

subsection.text: The transportation element shall:

paragraph.text: propose, on a schedule that extends as far into the future as is reasonable, the most appropriate and desirable patterns for:

subparagraph.text: the general location, character, and extent of channels, routes, and terminals for transportation facilities; and
the circulation of individuals and goods;

paragraph.text: provide for bicycle and pedestrian access and travelways; and
include an estimate of the use of any proposed improvement.

subsection.text: Considering available data provided by the Department of the Environment, the water resources element shall identify:

paragraph.text: drinking water and other water resources that will be adequate for the needs of existing and future development proposed in the land use element of the plan; and
suitable receiving waters and land areas to meet stormwater management and wastewater treatment and disposal needs of existing and future development proposed in the land use element of the plan.

subsection.text: The Department of the Environment shall:

paragraph.text: provide, on request of a local jurisdiction, technical assistance on the development of the water resources element; and

review the water resources element to determine whether the proposed plan is consistent with the programs and goals of the Department reflected in the general water resources program required under § 5–203 of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: The mineral resources element shall identify:

paragraph.text: undeveloped land that should be kept in its undeveloped state until the land can be used to assist in providing a continuous supply of minerals, as defined in § 15–801(i) of the Environment Article; and
appropriate postexcavation uses for the land that are consistent with the county’s land planning process.

subsection.text: A mineral resources element shall incorporate land use policies and recommendations for regulations:

paragraph.text: to balance mineral resource extraction with other land uses; and
to the extent feasible, to prevent the preemption of mineral resources extraction by other uses.

subsection.text: Before the plan is adopted, the Department of the Environment shall review the mineral resources element to determine whether the proposed plan is consistent with the programs and goals of the Department.

On a schedule that extends as far into the future as is reasonable, a community facilities element shall propose the most appropriate and desirable patterns for the general location, character, and extent of public and semipublic buildings, land, and facilities.
A community facilities element may include:

paragraph.text: places of worship;
fire stations;
hospitals;
institutions;
jails;
libraries;
parks and recreation areas;
police stations;
schools and other educational facilities;
cultural facilities;
social welfare and medical facilities; and
other public office or administrative facilities.

section.text: The areas of critical State concern element shall include the planning commission’s recommendations for the determination, identification, and designation of areas within the local jurisdiction that are of critical State concern.

subsection.text: The goals and objectives element shall include a statement of goals and objectives, principles, policies, and standards.
The statement shall serve as a guide for the development and economic and social well–being of the local jurisdiction.

On a schedule that extends as far into the future as is reasonable, the land use element shall propose the most appropriate and desirable patterns for the general location, character, extent, and interrelationship of the uses of public and private land.
The land use element may include the following public and private land uses:

paragraph.text: agricultural;
commercial;
forestry, in accordance with § 5–101 of the Natural Resources Article;
industrial;
recreational; and
residential.

subsection.text: The municipal growth element shall include:

paragraph.text: the municipal corporation’s:

subparagraph.text: future municipal growth areas outside the existing corporate limits;
past growth patterns;
capacity of land areas available for development, redevelopment, and in–fill;

paragraph.text: the land area needed to satisfy demand for development at densities consistent with long–term development policy;
the relationship of the long–term development policy to a vision of the municipal corporation’s future character;
rural buffers and transition areas;
protection of sensitive areas that could be impacted by development planned within the proposed municipal growth area;
population growth projections;
public services and infrastructure needed to accommodate growth within the proposed municipal growth areas, including those necessary for:

subparagraph.text: libraries;
recreation;
water and sewerage facilities;
public safety, including emergency medical response;
stormwater management systems sufficient to ensure water quality both inside and outside the proposed municipal growth area; and
public schools sufficient to accommodate student population consistent with State rated capacity standards established by the Interagency Committee on School Construction;

paragraph.text: any burden on services and infrastructure for which the municipal corporation would be responsible for development in areas near to and outside of the proposed municipal growth area; and
anticipated financing mechanisms to support necessary public services and infrastructure.

subsection.text: On request of a municipal corporation, the Department of Planning shall provide technical assistance for the purposes of developing the municipal growth element of the comprehensive plan.
The planning commission of a county that is located on the tidal waters of the State shall designate in the comprehensive plan areas on or near the tidal waters for:

paragraph.text: loading, unloading, and processing finfish and shellfish; and
docking and mooring commercial fishing boats and vessels.

subsection.text: The areas designated under subsection (a) of this section shall be geographically located to:

paragraph.text: facilitate the commercial harvesting of finfish and shellfish; and
ensure reasonable access to the waterways of the State by commercial watermen.
A planning commission shall prepare a plan by carefully and comprehensively surveying and studying:

subparagraph.text: the present conditions and projections of future growth of the local jurisdiction; and
the relation of the local jurisdiction to neighboring jurisdictions.

paragraph.text: A planning commission shall make the plan with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing the coordinated, adjusted, and harmonious development of the local jurisdiction and its environs.
The plan shall serve as a guide to public and private actions and decisions to ensure the development of public and private property in appropriate relationships.
In accordance with present and future needs, a plan shall promote:

subparagraph.text: good civic design and arrangement;
a healthy and convenient distribution of population;
the health, safety, and general welfare of the local jurisdiction; and
efficiency and economy in the development process.

paragraph.text: A plan shall:

subparagraph.text: include any areas outside the boundaries of the plan that, in the planning commission’s judgment, relate to the planning responsibilities of the commission; and
provide for:

sub-subparagraph.text: transportation needs;
the promotion of public safety;
light and air;
the conservation of natural resources;
the prevention of environmental pollution;
the wise and efficient expenditure of public funds;
adequate public utilities; and
an adequate supply of other public requirements.

subsection.text: In addition to the requirements for the plan under Subtitle 1 of this title, a planning commission shall implement through the plan the visions set forth in § 1–201 of this article.

paragraph.text: A planning commission may promote public interest in and understanding of the plan.

A planning commission shall consult with public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civic, educational, professional, and other organizations, and citizens about protecting or executing the plan.
A planning commission shall:

subparagraph.text: make and approve a plan; and
recommend the plan to the legislative body for adoption.

paragraph.text: A planning commission may recommend adoption of:

subparagraph.text: the whole plan;
successive parts of the plan, which correspond to geographic sections or divisions of the local jurisdiction; and
an amendment to the plan.

paragraph.text: The elements of the plan may be expressed in words, graphics, or any other appropriate form.
The elements of the plan shall be interrelated and each element shall describe how it relates to each of the other elements.

When a local jurisdiction initially implements the zoning powers under this division, the planning commission shall recommend the boundaries of the original districts and zones and appropriate regulations to be enforced in the districts and zones.

The planning commission shall make a preliminary report on the proposed districts, zones, and regulations and hold at least one public hearing on the preliminary report before submitting its final report to the legislative body.
The legislative body may not hold a public hearing or take action until it receives the final report of the planning commission.
A planning commission shall hold at least one public hearing before the commission recommends the adoption of a plan or any part or amendment to a plan.
The planning commission shall publish at least one notice of the time and place of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the local jurisdiction.

subsection.text: At least 60 days before the public hearing, the planning commission shall provide copies of the recommended plan and amendments to the plan to:

paragraph.text: adjoining jurisdictions; and
State units and local jurisdictions responsible for financing or constructing public improvements necessary to implement the plan.

subsection.text: The planning commission shall include in its report to the legislative body the recommendation of each unit and jurisdiction that comments on the plan.

paragraph.text: A majority of the planning commission, by resolution, shall approve the plan or any part of or amendment to the plan.
The resolution shall refer expressly to the text, map, and other matter that the commission intends to form the whole or part of the plan.
The action taken shall be recorded on the map, plan, text, or other matter by the identifying signature of:

subparagraph.text: the chair of the planning commission; or
the secretary of the commission.

subsection.text: An attested copy of the plan or part of the plan shall be certified to the legislative body.
Each local jurisdiction shall adopt a plan that includes:

paragraph.text: the elements required under Subtitle 1 of this title; and
the visions set forth in § 1–201 of this article.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, only a legislative body that has adopted a plan may adopt regulations implementing the visions stated in § 1–201 of this article in the plan.
This subsection does not limit the Department of Planning from exercising any authority granted under the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: This section applies only to a local jurisdiction where the legislative body has adopted a whole plan or a plan for one or more geographic sections or divisions of the local jurisdiction.

A publicly or privately owned street, square, park, or other public way, ground, or open space, a public building or structure, or a public utility may not be authorized or constructed in the local jurisdiction or in a geographic section of the local jurisdiction until the planning commission has approved the location, character, and extent of the development as consistent with the plan.

paragraph.text: The planning commission shall communicate its decision and the reasons for its decision to the legislative body or to the body that has jurisdiction over the financing of the public way, ground, space, building, structure, or utility.
The submission to the planning commission shall be considered approved if the planning commission fails to act on the submission within 60 days after the date it was submitted.
The legislative body or other body having jurisdiction may overrule the decision of the planning commission by a recorded vote of at least two–thirds of its entire membership.
The legislative body may adopt:

subparagraph.text: the whole plan;
a plan for one or more geographic sections or divisions of the local jurisdiction; or
an amendment or extension of or addition to the plan.

paragraph.text: The recommendation of the planning commission shall be considered approved if the legislative body fails to act within 60 days after the date the recommendation is submitted.
When developing a municipal growth element of the comprehensive plan, a municipal corporation shall consult with the counties in which the municipal corporation is located.
A municipal corporation shall provide a copy of a municipal growth element to the counties in which the municipal corporation is located before approval of the element.
The municipal corporation shall accept comments from the counties for 30 days after providing a copy of the municipal growth element to the counties in which the municipal corporation is located.

Within 30 days following the close of the comment period under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the counties and the municipal corporation shall meet and confer regarding the municipal growth element.

On request of either party, the county and the municipal corporation shall employ the Mediation and Conflict Resolution Office of the Maryland court system to facilitate the meeting and conferral under this subsection.
A municipal corporation and the counties in which the municipal corporation is located may enter into a joint planning agreement in order to coordinate implementation of a municipal growth element.
A joint planning agreement shall consider the municipal growth element required under Subtitle 1 of this title.

subsection.text: At least once every 6 years, each planning commission shall review the comprehensive plan and, if necessary, revise or amend the comprehensive plan to include all:

paragraph.text: the elements required under Subtitle 1 of this title; and
the visions set forth in § 1–201 of this article.

subsection.text: The planning commission may prepare comprehensive plans for one or more geographic sections or divisions of the local jurisdiction if the plan for each geographic section or division is reviewed and, if necessary, revised or amended at least once every 6 years.

section.text: To implement the plan, the planning commission shall periodically recommend to the appropriate public officials:

paragraph.text: programs for public structures, improvements, and land acquisitions; and
financing programs.

subsection.text: At least once every 6 years, which corresponds to the comprehensive plan revision process under § 3–301 of this subtitle, a local jurisdiction shall ensure the implementation of the visions, the development regulations element, and the sensitive areas element of the plan.
A local jurisdiction shall ensure that the implementation of the requirements of subsection (a) of this section are achieved through the adoption of applicable:

paragraph.text: zoning laws;
planned development ordinances and regulations;
subdivision ordinances and regulations; and
other land use ordinances and regulations that are consistent with the comprehensive plan.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, on or before October 1, 2009, a local jurisdiction shall include in its comprehensive plan any plan element required under Subtitle 1 of this title.

On request of a local jurisdiction and for good cause, the Department of Planning may extend the deadline under subsection (a) of this section for that local jurisdiction by no more than two 6–month extensions.

A local jurisdiction that is not in compliance with this section after October 1, 2009, or after the expiration of any extension granted under subsection (b) of this section, may not change the zoning classification of a property until that local jurisdiction has complied with this section.
It is the policy of the State that:

paragraph.text: the orderly development and use of land and structures requires comprehensive regulation through the implementation of planning and zoning controls; and
planning and zoning controls shall be implemented by local government.

subsection.text: To achieve the public purposes of this regulatory scheme, it is the policy of the General Assembly and the State that local government action will displace or limit economic competition by owners and users of property through the planning and zoning controls set forth in this division and elsewhere in the public general and public local laws.

section.text: To promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the community, a legislative body may regulate:

paragraph.text: the height, number of stories, and size of buildings and other structures;
the percentage of a lot that may be occupied;
off–street parking;
the size of yards, courts, and other open spaces;
population density; and
the location and use of buildings, signs, structures, and land.

subsection.text: When zoning or rezoning land under this division, a legislative body may impose any additional conditions or limitations that the legislative body considers appropriate to improve or protect the general character and design of:

paragraph.text: the land and improvements being zoned or rezoned; or
the surrounding or adjacent land and improvements.

subsection.text: A municipal corporation may include in an annexation agreement limitations on the use of land and density of development otherwise allowed in the zoning district where the land is located.

When zoning or rezoning land under this division, to ensure conformity with the intent and purpose of this division and of the local jurisdiction’s zoning law, a legislative body may retain the power to approve or disapprove:

paragraph.text: the design of buildings, construction, landscaping, or other improvements; and
changes made or to be made on the land being zoned or rezoned.

subsection.text: The powers provided in this section shall apply only if the legislative body adopts a local law that includes:

paragraph.text: enforcement procedures; and
requirements for adequate notice of:

subparagraph.text: public hearings; and
conditions sought to be imposed.

subsection.text: The powers granted to a local jurisdiction under this subtitle do not:

paragraph.text: grant the local jurisdiction powers in any substantive area not otherwise granted to the local jurisdiction by any other public general or public local law;
restrict the local jurisdiction from exercising any power granted to the local jurisdiction by any other public general or public local law or otherwise;
authorize the local jurisdiction or its officers to engage in any activity that is beyond their power under any other public general or public local law or otherwise; or
preempt or supersede the regulatory authority of any unit of the State under any public general law.
If a legislative body regulates off–street parking, the legislative body shall require space for the parking of bicycles in a manner that the legislative body considers appropriate.
A legislative body may allow a reduction in the number of required automobile parking spaces based on the availability of space for parking bicycles.

subsection.text: A legislative body may divide the local jurisdiction into districts and zones of any number, shape, and area that the legislative body considers best suited to carry out the purposes of this division.

paragraph.text: Within the districts and zones, the legislative body may regulate the construction, alteration, repair, or use of buildings, structures, or land.
Except as otherwise provided in this division or authorized by law:

subparagraph.text: zoning regulations shall be uniform for each class or kind of development throughout each district or zone; but
zoning regulations in one district or zone may differ from those in other districts or zones.

subsection.text: The legislative body shall adopt zoning regulations:

paragraph.text: in accordance with the plan;
with reasonable consideration for, among other things, the character of the district or zone and its suitability for particular uses; and
with a view to conserving the value of buildings and other structures and encouraging orderly development and the most appropriate use of land.

subsection.text: The zoning regulations shall be designed to:

paragraph.text: control street congestion;
promote health, public safety, and general welfare;
provide adequate light and air;
promote the conservation of natural resources;
prevent environmental pollution;
avoid an undue concentration of population; and
promote or facilitate adequate transportation, water, sewerage, schools, recreation, parks, and other public facilities.

subsection.text: A legislative body shall provide for the manner in which its zoning regulations and the boundaries of districts and zones shall be established, enforced, and amended.

paragraph.text: A legislative body shall hold at least one public hearing on a proposed zoning regulation or boundary at which parties in interest and citizens have an opportunity to be heard.

subparagraph.text: The legislative body shall publish notice of the time and place of the public hearing, together with a summary of the proposed zoning regulation or boundary, in at least one newspaper of general circulation in the local jurisdiction once each week for 2 successive weeks.
The legislative body shall publish the first notice of the hearing at least 14 days before the hearing.

paragraph.text: The zoning regulation or boundary may not become effective until 10 days after the hearing or hearings.

subsection.text: Zoning regulations and boundaries may be amended or repealed.

paragraph.text: If the purpose and effect of a proposed map amendment is to change a zoning classification, the legislative body shall make findings of fact that address:

subparagraph.text: population change;
the availability of public facilities;
present and future transportation patterns;
compatibility with existing and proposed development for the area;
the recommendation of the planning commission; and
the relationship of the proposed amendment to the local jurisdiction’s plan.

paragraph.text: The legislative body may grant the amendment to change the zoning classification based on a finding that there was:

subparagraph.text: a substantial change in the character of the neighborhood where the property is located; or
a mistake in the existing zoning classification.

paragraph.text: The legislative body shall keep a complete record of a hearing on an application for reclassification and the votes of the members of the legislative body.

A legislative body may not allow the filing of an application for a reclassification of all or part of any land for which a reclassification has been denied by the legislative body on the merits in the 12 months before the date of the application.
The provisions of § 4–203(b) of this subtitle concerning public hearings and notice apply to applications for reclassification.

subsection.text: A legislative body may authorize the planning director or another designee to grant an administrative adjustment from the following requirements in a zoning law enacted by the legislative body:

paragraph.text: height;
setback;
bulk;
parking;
loading, dimensional, or area; or
similar requirements.

subsection.text: Before developing criteria and procedures for administrative adjustments under this section, the legislative body shall:

paragraph.text: consult with the planning commission and the board of appeals; and
provide:

subparagraph.text: reasonable public notice of the proposed criteria and procedures;
an opportunity for a public hearing; and
an opportunity for public review and comment.

subsection.text: The criteria for an administrative adjustment shall include:

paragraph.text: standards for actions on requests;
standards for the classes of development that are eligible for an administrative adjustment; and
the maximum variation from a zoning requirement that is allowed under an administrative adjustment.

subsection.text: Procedures for administrative adjustments may address:

paragraph.text: applications;
notice to the public and to the parties in interest;
an opportunity for a public hearing;
an opportunity for the taking of testimony and evidence; and
decision making.

subsection.text: A decision on an application for an administrative adjustment shall include written findings of fact and conclusions of law.
By enacting a local law or adopting a procedure, a legislative body may authorize the appeal to the board of appeals of a decision to approve or deny an administrative adjustment.

Nothing in this section is intended to authorize a local jurisdiction to allow an administrative adjustment to State or local requirements that are intended to protect environmentally sensitive areas such as streams, slopes, wetlands, natural heritage areas, or critical areas.
By local law, a legislative body may specify in a zoning law the allowable modifications that may be made by a variance.
The modifications in a variance:

paragraph.text: may be only of density, bulk, dimensional, or area requirements of the zoning law;

may be only allowed where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not because of any action taken by the applicant, a literal enforcement of the zoning law would result in unnecessary hardship or practical difficulty as specified in the zoning law; and
may not be contrary to the public interest.

subsection.text: On application by a property owner, a legislative body may authorize how the uses allowed in a zoning classification are to be applied to a particular improved property by granting an adaptive reuse.
Before granting an adaptive reuse, the legislative body shall make specific findings, supported by facts in the record, that:

paragraph.text: the change is consistent with the plan for the local jurisdiction;
the change is in the public interest and provides a positive benefit to the community; and
literal enforcement of the zoning classification would deprive the owner of all reasonable economically viable use of the property.

section.text: A legislative body shall provide for exceptions to the zoning law when necessary to bring an existing parking lot into compliance with the requirements for parking spaces for individuals with disabilities and the van–accessible parking ratio requirement of the Maryland Accessibility Code adopted under § 12–202 of the Public Safety Article.

subsection.text: A legislative body may appoint full– and part–time hearing examiners that it considers necessary and appropriate.

paragraph.text: A legislative body may delegate to a hearing examiner the power to conduct a public hearing under §§ 4–204 and 4–205 of this subtitle.
A hearing shall be conducted under rules the legislative body adopts.

subsection.text: A hearing examiner shall recuse himself or herself from participating in a matter in which the hearing examiner may have a conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest.
A legislative body shall determine the term of office, required qualifications, and compensation of a hearing examiner employed by the local jurisdiction.
A hearing examiner shall issue a written recommendation in the time, manner, and form required by the legislative body.
In this section, “critical area” includes the areas designated as the Chesapeake Bay Critical Area and the Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area under § 8–1807 of the Natural Resources Article.
This section does not apply in the critical area.

For the purposes of issuing a permit or variance relating to zoning, construction, or stormwater for a project to install a solar panel, any calculation relating to the impervious surface of the project required by the State or local governing authority issuing the permit or variance may include only the foundation or base supporting the solar panel.
A legislative body shall provide for the appointment of a board of appeals.
The legislative body may not serve as the board of appeals.
A board of appeals consists of at least three members.
A member of a board of appeals shall be appointed by the local executive and confirmed by the legislative body.
The term of office of a member of a board of appeals is 3 years.
A member of a board of appeals may be removed:

paragraph.text: for cause;
on written charges; and
after a public hearing.

subsection.text: The appointing authority shall appoint a new member to fill the unexpired term of any member who leaves a board of appeals.

paragraph.text: A legislative body shall designate one alternate member for the board of appeals who may sit on the board when another member of the board is absent or recused.
When the alternate member is absent or recused, the legislative body may designate a temporary alternate.
The meetings of a board of appeals shall be held at the call of the chair and at other times determined by the board.
The chair of a board of appeals or the acting chair may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses.
All meetings of a board of appeals shall be open to the public.

subsection.text: A member of a board of appeals may receive compensation that the legislative body considers appropriate.
A board of appeals shall adopt rules in accordance with any local law adopted under this division.
A member of a board of appeals shall recuse himself or herself from participating in a matter in which the member may have a conflict of interest or an appearance of a conflict of interest.

subparagraph.text: A board of appeals shall make a recording of all proceedings with a contemporaneous written record showing the vote of each member on each question or the member’s absence or failure to vote.

sub-subparagraph.text: A board of appeals shall immediately file the recording of its proceedings in the office of the board.
The recording shall be a public record.

paragraph.text: If a recording or a transcript of a recording is not prepared in the normal course of the board’s proceedings, the party who requests a copy of the recording or its transcript shall pay the cost of preparing the recording or transcript.

section.text: A board of appeals may:

paragraph.text: hear and decide appeals when it is alleged that there is an error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative officer or unit under this division or of any local law adopted under this division;
hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of a local law on which the board is required to pass under the local law; and
authorize on appeal in specific cases a variance from the terms of a local law.

subsection.text: An appeal to the board of appeals may be filed by:

paragraph.text: a person aggrieved by a decision of the administrative officer or unit; or
an officer or unit of the jurisdiction affected by a decision of the administrative officer or unit.

subsection.text: A person shall file an appeal within a reasonable time provided by the rules of the board of appeals by filing with the administrative officer or unit from whose action the appeal is taken and with the board of appeals a notice of appeal specifying the grounds of the appeal.
The administrative officer or unit from whose action the appeal is taken shall transmit promptly to the board all papers constituting the record of the action appealed.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an appeal to a board of appeals stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed.

If an administrative officer or unit certifies to the board of appeals facts stated in the certificate that indicate to the administrative officer or unit that a stay would cause imminent peril to life or property, the board of appeals or the circuit court may stay the proceedings:

subparagraph.text: only for good cause shown; and
through issuing a restraining order after notice is given to the administrative officer or unit.

paragraph.text: A board of appeals shall:

subparagraph.text: establish a reasonable time for the hearing of an appeal;
give public notice of the existence of the appeal and of the hearing;
give due notice to the parties in interest and to other persons entitled to notice under local law or the rules of the board of appeals; and
decide the appeal within a reasonable time.

paragraph.text: At a hearing, a party may:

subparagraph.text: appear in person; or
be represented by an agent or attorney.

paragraph.text: A board of appeals may, in conformity with this division:

subparagraph.text: wholly or partly reverse the order, requirement, or decision that is the subject of the appeal;
wholly or partly affirm the order, requirement, or decision that is the subject of the appeal;
modify the order, requirement, or decision that is the subject of the appeal; or
issue a new order, requirement, or decision.

paragraph.text: The board of appeals shall have all the powers of the administrative officer or unit from whose action the appeal is taken.

subsection.text: Any of the following persons may file a request for judicial review of a decision of a board of appeals or a zoning action of a legislative body by the circuit court of the county:

paragraph.text: a person aggrieved by the decision or action;
a taxpayer; or
an officer or unit of the local jurisdiction.

subsection.text: The judicial review shall be in accordance with Title 7, Chapter 200 of the Maryland Rules.
This section does not change the existing standards for judicial review of a zoning action.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the circuit court shall review the decision of a board of appeals or a hearing examiner under this subtitle on the record transmitted by the board of appeals or hearing examiner, and not de novo.

paragraph.text: If, after a hearing, the circuit court determines that testimony is needed for the proper disposition of the matter, the court may take evidence or appoint a special master to:

subparagraph.text: take the required evidence; and
report the evidence to the court with the special master’s findings of fact and conclusions of law.

paragraph.text: The special master’s evidence, findings, and conclusions shall constitute a part of the proceedings on which the court shall make its determination.

section.text: The circuit court may not allow an award of costs against the board of appeals unless it appears to the court that the board, in making the decision that is the subject of the judicial review, acted:

paragraph.text: with gross negligence;
in bad faith; or
with malice.

section.text: All issues in any proceeding under this subtitle shall be scheduled and heard before all other civil actions and proceedings.

subsection.text: After deciding a judicial review under this subtitle, the circuit court shall file a written order and opinion embodying the reasons for its decision.

paragraph.text: A party may file an appeal of a judgment of the circuit court with the Court of Special Appeals during the period and in the manner required by the Maryland Rules.
The Court of Special Appeals may award costs in any appeal to that court under this subsection.

subsection.text: In addition to the judicial review provided under this subtitle, a legislative body may allow judicial review by the circuit court of any matter arising under the planning and zoning laws of the local jurisdiction.
A judgment of the circuit court under this section may be appealed to the Court of Special Appeals.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the territorial jurisdiction of a planning commission over a subdivision is limited to land located in the local jurisdiction.

In a local jurisdiction where a county has not adopted subdivision regulations, the territorial jurisdiction of a planning commission of a municipal corporation may include all land located up to 1 mile beyond the corporate limits of the municipal corporation that is not located in any other municipal corporation.
Before exercising subdivision powers under §§ 5–202 and 5–203 of this title, the planning commission shall recommend subdivision regulations to the legislative body.
The subdivision regulations shall be for the health, safety, welfare, and common interest of the citizens of the local jurisdiction.
The subdivision regulations may include provisions for the purposes of:

paragraph.text: adequately controlling shore erosion;
controlling sediment and ensuring protection from flooding;
arranging streets in relation to each other and to the comprehensive plan;
adequately and conveniently placing public school sites and open spaces for traffic, utilities, access of fire–fighting apparatus, recreation, and access to light and air;
avoiding inappropriate population congestion;
setting minimum lot widths and areas; and
determining the extent to which the following actions shall be taken before the approval of a plat:

subparagraph.text: the grading and improvement of streets and other ways;
