the provision of soil erosion or sediment control; and
the installation of water, sewer, other utility mains, piping, or other facilities.

paragraph.text: Subdivision regulations shall require that an appropriate easement be provided for any burial site located on the land.

The easement shall be subject to the subdivision plat for entry to and exit from the burial site by an individual related by blood or marriage or a person in interest, as defined in § 14–121 of the Real Property Article.
The existing right–of–way need not be extended for any improvements on the burial site.

subsection.text: Before adoption of a subdivision regulation, the legislative body shall hold a public hearing on the subdivision regulation.
The legislative body shall publish a notice of the public hearing at least once in a weekly or daily newspaper that circulates in the local jurisdiction.
The notice shall contain:

paragraph.text: the text of the subdivision regulation or, at the discretion of the legislative body, a brief and accurate summary of the nature and contents of the subdivision regulation sufficient to inform an individual of ordinary intelligence of the nature and contents of the subdivision regulation; and
the time and place of the public hearing.

subsection.text: When the legislative body adopts a subdivision regulation, the legislative body shall file a certified copy of the subdivision regulation with the clerk of the circuit court in which the local jurisdiction is located for recording.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Community sewerage system” means a publicly or privately owned sewerage system that serves at least two lots.
“Major subdivision” has the meaning stated in § 9–206 of the Environment Article.
“On–site sewage disposal system” has the meaning stated in § 9–206 of the Environment Article.

subparagraph.text: “Planning board” means a planning board established under this article.
“Planning board” includes a planning commission or board established under Division II of this article or Article 25A of the Code.

paragraph.text: “Shared facility” has the meaning stated in § 9–206 of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: This section applies only to a residential major subdivision in a Tier III area served by:

paragraph.text: on–site sewage disposal systems;
a shared facility; or
a community sewerage system.

subsection.text: If a local jurisdiction establishes the growth tiers under Title 1, Subtitle 5 of this article, a residential major subdivision in a Tier III area may not be approved unless the planning board has reviewed and recommended the approval of the major subdivision in the Tier III area.

paragraph.text: Before recommending the approval of a proposed major subdivision in a Tier III area, the planning board shall hold at least one public hearing.
The planning board shall conduct the public hearing in accordance with its rules and procedures.

subsection.text: The review of a residential major subdivision by the planning board shall include:

paragraph.text: the cost of providing local governmental services to the residential major subdivision unless a local jurisdiction’s adequate public facilities law already requires a review of government services; and
the potential environmental issues or a natural resources inventory related to the proposed residential major subdivision.

subsection.text: The planning board shall recommend the proposed residential major subdivision by resolution of the planning board.

After a planning commission begins to exercise control over subdivisions under this subtitle, the authority of the planning commission over plats shall be exclusive within the territory under its jurisdiction.

Unless otherwise provided in this division, all statutory control over plats or subdivisions granted by other statutes shall be considered transferred to the planning commission of the local jurisdiction.

subparagraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, if an applicant has complied with all subdivision regulations, a planning commission shall approve or disapprove a final plat within 30 days after the applicant submits the final plat to the planning commission.

If the planning commission does not approve or disapprove the plat within 30 days, the plat shall be considered approved and the planning commission shall issue a certificate to that effect on demand.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, if the planning commission does not approve or disapprove the plat within 30 days, an applicant for approval of a final plat may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of the period for approval.
If a final plat is disapproved, the planning commission shall state the grounds for the disapproval in the planning commission’s records.
Each plat approved by the planning commission shall, through the approval, be considered:

subparagraph.text: an amendment or a detail of the comprehensive plan; and
a part of the comprehensive plan.

paragraph.text: Approval of a plat does not constitute or effect an acceptance by the public of any street or other open space shown on the plat.

A planning commission periodically may recommend to the legislative body amendments of the zoning law or map to conform to the planning commission’s recommendations for the zoning regulation of the territory within approved subdivisions.
A planning commission may agree with an applicant on use, height, area, or bulk requirements or restrictions that are designed to promote the purposes of the zoning law of the local jurisdiction.

subparagraph.text: The requirements or restrictions shall be stated on the plat before the plat is approved and recorded.

The requirements or restrictions shall have the same force of law, shall be enforceable in the same manner and with the same sanctions and penalties, and shall be subject to the same power of amendment or repeal as though part of the zoning law or map of the local jurisdiction.

subsection.text: This section applies only where a legislative body has:

paragraph.text: adopted the transportation element of the comprehensive plan of all or part of the territory within its subdivision jurisdiction; and
filed a certified copy of the plan with the clerk of the circuit court of the county in which all or part of the territory is located.

subsection.text: A plat of a subdivision within the territory or part may not be filed or recorded until:

paragraph.text: the planning commission approves the plat; and
the chair or secretary of the planning commission indicates an approval in writing on the plat.

subsection.text: A planning commission may authorize an administrative officer to approve subdivision plats and site plans under § 5–202 of this subtitle in accordance with nondiscretionary criteria adopted and specified by local law.
The administrative officer shall approve a plat by indicating an approval in writing on the plat.
A planning commission may provide in the subdivision regulations or practice for tentative approval of a plat before completion of improvements or installation of utilities.
Tentative approval of a plat shall be revocable and may not be indicated on the plat.

paragraph.text: Instead of requiring the completion of improvements and installation of utilities before the final approval of a plat, a planning commission may accept security approved by the local jurisdiction to secure the construction of improvements and installation of utilities.
Forms of security accepted by a planning commission under paragraph (1) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall specify the time for completion and specifications set by or in accordance with the subdivision regulations of the planning commission;
may include a bond with surety, an irrevocable letter of credit, or any other form of security approved by the local jurisdiction; and
may be enforced by any appropriate legal or equitable remedy.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in §§ 9–603, 9–806, 9–1004, 9–1605, 9–1606, and 9–1607 of this article, an owner or agent of an owner of land located within a subdivision may not transfer, sell, agree to sell, or negotiate to sell land by reference to, exhibition of, or other use of a plat of a subdivision before the plat has been:

subparagraph.text: approved by the planning commission; and
recorded or filed in the office of the appropriate county clerk.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this subsection is subject to a civil penalty of not less than $200 and not exceeding $1,000 for each violation.
Each lot or parcel transferred or sold or agreed or negotiated to be sold in violation of this subsection is a separate violation.

subsection.text: The description of a lot or parcel by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring does not exempt the transaction from the penalties or remedies provided in this section.
A local jurisdiction may seek to:

paragraph.text: enjoin the transfer, sale, or agreement in any circuit court; or
recover the penalty by civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction.

subsection.text: A clerk of the circuit court for the county in which the local jurisdiction is located may not record a subdivision plat unless the plat has been approved by the planning commission for the local jurisdiction in the manner required by law.
A subdivision plat that is recorded without the required approval is limited to the legal effect of an unrecorded plat.
A legislative body may authorize judicial review by the circuit court of any matter arising under this title.
The judicial review shall be in accordance with Title 7, Chapter 200 of the Maryland Rules.
A judgment of the circuit court under this section may be appealed to the Court of Special Appeals.

section.text: After adopting the transportation element of a comprehensive plan, a planning commission periodically may:

paragraph.text: conduct surveys to locate street lines and any other part of the transportation element; and

make a reservation plat of the area surveyed, showing the land that the planning commission recommends be reserved for future dedication or acquisition as public streets and any other part of the transportation element.

subsection.text: On approval and adoption of a plat, streets located on the plat are reserved for future acquisition for public use.
The approval and adoption of a plat does not constitute the establishment of a street or acquisition of any land to create a street, public use, or public improvement.
Before adopting a plat, a planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the plat.

At least 10 days before the public hearing, the planning commission shall publish a notice of the time and place of the hearing, with a general description of the area covered by the plat, in a newspaper of general circulation in the local jurisdiction in which the area is located.

After the public hearing under § 6–103 of this subtitle, the planning commission may transmit the plat, as originally made or as amended by the planning commission, to the legislative body with the planning commission’s estimate of the schedule by which the local jurisdiction should acquire the reserved land.
After receiving the plat from the planning commission, the legislative body, by resolution, may:

paragraph.text: approve and adopt the plat;
disapprove the plat;
modify the plat with the approval of the planning commission; or

adopt a modified plat, notwithstanding the prior disapproval of the modification by the planning commission, with a favorable vote of at least two–thirds of the entire membership of the legislative body.

subsection.text: In the resolution adopting the plat, the legislative body shall establish the period for which land is to be reserved under § 6–102 of this subtitle.
After the plat is adopted, the clerk of the legislative body shall:

paragraph.text: transmit one attested copy of the plat to the clerk of the circuit court of each county in which the platted land is located; and
keep one copy of the plat for public examination.

subsection.text: A planning commission may negotiate for or secure from the owner of reserved land:

paragraph.text: a release of claims for damages or compensation for the reservation of the land; or
an agreement indemnifying the local jurisdiction from claims by others for damages or compensation.

subsection.text: A negotiated release or agreement shall bind the landowner executing the release or agreement and the landowner’s successors in title.

At any time after the filing of a plat with the clerk of the circuit court of the county and during the period specified for the reservation, a planning commission and the owner of reserved land may agree to modify the location of the lines of a proposed street.
An agreement to modify the location shall include a release by the landowner of any claim for compensation or damages caused by the modification.

paragraph.text: After the release is executed, the planning commission may make a plat corresponding to the modification and transmit the plat to the legislative body for approval.

If the legislative body approves the modified plat, the clerk of the legislative body shall transmit an attested copy of the modified plat to the clerk of the circuit court of the county in which the local jurisdiction is located.
The modified plat shall supersede the original or prior plat.

section.text: The legislative body, by resolution, may abandon a reservation and certify the abandonment to the clerk of the circuit court of the county in which the local jurisdiction is located.
In this subtitle, “appellate board” means:

paragraph.text: the board of appeals of a local jurisdiction established under Title 4, Subtitle 3 of this article; or
a special board of appeals created to consider appeals under this subtitle.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 6–203 of this subtitle, after recording a reservation plat approved by a legislative body under Subtitle 1 of this title, a local jurisdiction may not issue a permit to develop any part of the land between the lines of a proposed street as platted.

subsection.text: The appellate board of the local jurisdiction where a platted street is located may grant a permit to develop a platted street on an appeal filed by the owner of the land on which the street is located:

paragraph.text: after a hearing at which the parties in interest have an opportunity to be heard; and
by a vote of a majority of the authorized membership of the appellate board.

subsection.text: At least 15 days before the hearing required under subsection (a) of this section, the appellate board shall:

paragraph.text: mail to the appellant, at the address specified in the appeal petition, notice of the time and place of the hearing; and
publish a notice of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the local jurisdiction.
In order to grant a development permit, the appellate board shall find from the evidence and arguments presented on appeal that:

subparagraph.text: the entire property of the appellant, of which the reserved street location forms a part, cannot yield a reasonable return to the owner unless the permit is granted; and
after balancing the interests of the local jurisdiction and the appellant, the permit is required by reasonable justice and equity.

paragraph.text: In balancing the interests of each party, the appellate board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the interest of the local jurisdiction in preserving the integrity of the street plat and comprehensive plan; and
the interest of the appellant in the use of the property and in the benefits of property ownership.

subsection.text: If the appellate board grants a development permit, the appellate board:

paragraph.text: shall specify the exact location, ground area, height, and other details of the development; and
may impose reasonable requirements benefiting the local jurisdiction as a condition of granting the permit.

subsection.text: A public sewer or other public street utility or improvement may not be constructed in a street or highway until the street or highway is placed on the official map.
A development permit may not be issued unless a street or highway giving access to the proposed development has been placed on the official map.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a permit may appeal from a decision of the administrative officer in charge of issuing permits to an appellate board if:

subparagraph.text: the enforcement of this section would entail exceptional difficulty or unwarranted hardship; and
the circumstances do not require the development to be related to existing or proposed streets or highways.

paragraph.text: In deciding an appeal under this subsection, the appellate board may make any reasonable exception and issue the permit subject to conditions that will protect any future street or highway layout.

A decision rendered under this subsection shall be subject to judicial review in the same manner and subject to the same provisions of law as a decision of a board of appeals on zoning regulations under Title 4, Subtitle 4 of this article.

section.text: To encourage the preservation of natural resources or the provision of affordable housing and to facilitate orderly development and growth, a local jurisdiction that exercises authority granted by this division may enact, and is encouraged to enact, local laws providing for or requiring:

paragraph.text: the planning, staging, or provision of adequate public facilities and affordable housing;
off–site improvements or the dedication of land for public facilities essential for a development;
moderately priced dwelling unit programs;
mixed use developments;
cluster developments;
planned unit developments;
alternative subdivision requirements that:

subparagraph.text: meet minimum performance standards set by the local jurisdiction; and
reduce infrastructure costs;

paragraph.text: floating zones;
incentive zoning; and
performance zoning.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a legislative body that exercises authority granted by this division may enact local laws providing for the transfer, with or without consideration, of real property belonging to the local jurisdiction to a public or private entity, to use in developing or preserving affordable housing.
The authority granted under this subtitle is not intended to limit a local jurisdiction’s authority to:

paragraph.text: exercise any planning and zoning powers not expressly authorized under this subtitle; or
adopt other methods to:

subparagraph.text: facilitate orderly development and growth;
encourage the preservation of natural resources; or
provide affordable housing.

subsection.text: In this section, “restriction” means a restriction, moratorium, or capacity limitation imposed on development as a result of a local law enacted under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If an adequate public facility law has resulted in a restriction within a priority funding area, on or before July 1 every 2 years, a local jurisdiction shall report on the restriction to the Department of Planning.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: the location of the restriction;
the type of infrastructure affected by the restriction;
the proposed resolution of the restriction, if available;
the estimated date for the resolution of the restriction, if available;
if a restriction was lifted, the date the restriction was lifted; and
the local law or resolution that lifted the restriction.

paragraph.text: On or before January 1 every 2 years, the Department of Planning shall prepare and publish a report on the statewide impacts of adequate public facility laws.
The report shall include the identification of:

subparagraph.text: geographic areas and facilities within priority funding areas that fail to meet local adequate public facility standards; and
improvements to facilities scheduled or proposed in the local jurisdiction’s capital improvement program.

section.text: A legislative body that exercises authority granted by this division may establish a program for the transfer of development rights to:

paragraph.text: encourage the preservation of natural resources; and
facilitate orderly growth and development in the State.

subsection.text: In this section, “public facility” includes:

paragraph.text: recreational facilities;
transportation facilities and transit–oriented development; and
schools and educational facilities.

subsection.text: A legislative body that exercises authority granted by this division may establish a program for the transfer of development rights within a priority funding area to assist a local jurisdiction in the acquisition of land for the construction of a public facility within a priority funding area.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, proceeds of the sale of development rights shall be used to assist in:

subparagraph.text: the acquisition of the public site; or
the construction of the public facility.

paragraph.text: For schools and educational facilities, proceeds of the sale of development rights may only be used to assist in the acquisition of the land on which the school or educational facility will be located.
Any development rights sold under this section may only be transferred within a priority funding area.
Development rights associated with existing public land that is owned by a local jurisdiction on October 1, 2009, may not be sold or transferred under this section.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Development rights and responsibilities agreement” or “agreement” means an agreement between a local governing body and a person having a legal or equitable interest in real property to establish conditions under which development may proceed for a specified time.
“Local governing body” means the legislative body, the local executive, or other elected governmental body that has zoning powers under this division.
“Public principal” means the governmental entity of a local jurisdiction that has been granted the authority to enter agreements under § 7–302(a) of this subtitle.
Subject to §§ 7–303 through 7–305 of this subtitle, the local governing body of a local jurisdiction may:

paragraph.text: by local law, establish procedures and requirements for the consideration and execution of agreements; and
delegate all or part of the authority established under the local law to a public principal within the jurisdiction of the local governing body.

subsection.text: The public principal may:

paragraph.text: execute agreements for real property located within the jurisdiction of the local governing body with a person having a legal or equitable interest in the real property; and
include a federal, State, or local government or unit as an additional party to the agreement.

subsection.text: A development rights and responsibilities agreement shall include:

paragraph.text: a legal description of the real property subject to the agreement;
the names of the persons having a legal or equitable interest in the real property subject to the agreement;
the duration of the agreement;
the permissible uses of the real property;
the density or intensity of use of the real property;
the maximum height and size of structures to be located on the real property;
a description of the permits required or already approved for the development of the real property;
a statement that the proposed development is consistent with the comprehensive plan and development regulations of the local jurisdiction;

a description of the conditions, terms, restrictions, or other requirements determined by the local governing body of the local jurisdiction to be necessary to ensure the public health, safety, or welfare; and
to the extent applicable, provisions for the:

subparagraph.text: dedication of a portion of the real property for public use;
protection of sensitive areas;
preservation and restoration of historic structures; and
construction or financing of public facilities.

subsection.text: An agreement may:

paragraph.text: set the time frame and terms for development and construction on the real property; and
provide for other matters consistent with this division.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the local laws, rules, regulations, and policies governing the use, density, or intensity of the real property subject to an agreement shall be the local laws, rules, regulations, and policies in force at the time the parties execute the agreement.

If the local jurisdiction determines that compliance with local laws, rules, regulations, and policies enacted or adopted after the effective date of an agreement is essential to ensure the public health, safety, or welfare, an agreement may not prevent a local government from requiring a person to comply with those local laws, rules, regulations, and policies.

Before entering into an agreement, a person having a legal or equitable interest in real property or the person’s representative shall petition the public principal of the local jurisdiction in which the property is located.

paragraph.text: After receiving a petition and before entering into an agreement, the public principal shall conduct a public hearing.
A public hearing that is required for approval of the development satisfies the public hearing requirement.

subsection.text: The public principal of a local jurisdiction may not enter into an agreement unless the planning commission of the local jurisdiction determines whether the proposed agreement is consistent with the comprehensive plan of the local jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: If an agreement is not recorded in the land records of the local jurisdiction within 20 days after the date on which the parties execute the agreement, the agreement is void.
The parties to an agreement and their successors in interest are bound to the agreement after the agreement is recorded.

subsection.text: An agreement shall be void 5 years after the date on which the parties execute the agreement unless:

paragraph.text: otherwise established under § 7–303 of this subtitle; or
extended by amendment under subsection (f) of this section.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection and after a public hearing, the parties to an agreement may amend the agreement by mutual consent.

Unless the planning commission of the local jurisdiction determines whether the proposed amendment is consistent with the comprehensive plan of the local jurisdiction, the parties may not amend an agreement.
The parties to an agreement may terminate the agreement by mutual consent.

If the public principal or the local governing body determines that suspension or termination is essential to ensure the public health, safety, or welfare, the public principal or the local governing body may suspend or terminate an agreement after a public hearing.

subsection.text: Unless the agreement is terminated under subsection (g) of this section, the parties to an agreement or their successors in interest may enforce the agreement.

section.text: This subtitle does not require the adoption of a local law by a local governing body or authorize a local governing body to require a party to enter into an agreement.

subsection.text: To promote the creation of housing that is affordable by individuals and families with low or moderate incomes, a legislative body that exercises authority under this division may enact local laws:

paragraph.text: imposing inclusionary zoning, and awarding density bonuses, to create affordable housing units; and
restricting the use, cost, and resale of housing that is created under this subtitle to ensure that the purposes of this subtitle are carried out.

subsection.text: The authority granted under this subtitle is in addition to any other zoning and planning powers.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Appurtenance and environmental setting” includes:

paragraph.text: paved or unpaved walkways and driveways;
trees;
landscaping;
pastures;
croplands;
waterways; and
rocks.

subsection.text: “Commission” includes a historic district commission or a historic preservation commission.
“Demolition” includes any willful neglect in the maintenance and repair of a structure, other than the appurtenance and environmental setting of the structure, that:

paragraph.text: is not due to a financial inability to maintain and repair the structure; and
threatens to result in a substantial deterioration of the exterior features of the structure.

subsection.text: “District” means a significant concentration, linkage, or continuity of sites, structures, or objects united historically or aesthetically by plan or development.
“Person” includes a unit of local government.
“Routine maintenance” means work that:

paragraph.text: does not alter the exterior fabric or features of a site or structure; and
has no material effect on the historical, archaeological, or architectural significance of the site or structure.

subsection.text: “Site” means the location of:

paragraph.text: an event of historic significance; or
a structure or ruin that possesses historic, archaeological, or cultural significance.
“Structure” means a combination of material to form a construction that is stable.
“Structure” includes:

subparagraph.text: a building;
a stadium;
a reviewing stand;
a platform;
staging;
an observation tower;
a radio tower;
a water tank or tower;
a trestle;
a bridge;
a pier;
paving;
a bulkhead;
a wharf;
a shed;
a coal bin;
(xvii) a shelter;
(xviii) a fence;
a display sign that is visible or intended to be visible from a public way; and
a part of a structure.

section.text: It is a public purpose in the State to preserve sites, structures, and districts of historical, archaeological, or architectural significance and their appurtenances and environmental settings.

subsection.text: The preservation of a designated structure under this title includes preservation of an associated:

paragraph.text: natural land formation; and
appurtenance and environmental setting.

subsection.text: This title may not be construed to prevent routine maintenance, customary farming operations, or landscaping that does not have a material effect on the historic, archaeological, or architectural significance of a designated site, structure, or district.
The legislative body of each local jurisdiction, by local law, may regulate:

paragraph.text: the construction, reconstruction, alteration, moving, and demolition of sites or structures of historical, archaeological, or architectural significance;
the construction, reconstruction, alteration, moving, and demolition of sites and structures within districts; and
the appurtenances and environmental settings of sites and structures within the limits of the local jurisdiction.

subsection.text: The purpose of a local law adopted under this section is to:

paragraph.text: safeguard the heritage of the local jurisdiction by preserving sites, structures, or districts that reflect elements of cultural, social, economic, political, archaeological, or architectural history;
stabilize and improve the property values of those sites, structures, or districts;
foster civic beauty;
strengthen the local economy; and
promote the preservation and appreciation of those sites, structures, and districts for the education and welfare of the residents of each local jurisdiction.

section.text: For the purposes of this title, each local jurisdiction may designate boundaries for sites, structures, and districts that are considered to be of historic, archaeological, or architectural significance, by following the procedures of the local jurisdiction for establishing or changing zoning districts and classifications.
A local jurisdiction may create a historic district commission or a historic preservation commission.

paragraph.text: A commission shall consist of at least five members.
A majority of the members of a commission shall be residents of the local jurisdiction that created the commission.
Each member of a commission shall have a demonstrated special interest, specific knowledge, or professional or academic training in:

subparagraph.text: history;
architecture;
architectural history;
planning;
archaeology;
anthropology;
curation;
conservation;
landscape architecture;
historic preservation;
urban design; or
a related discipline.

paragraph.text: A local jurisdiction that creates a commission may establish and publicly adopt additional qualifications for a member of the commission.
The term of a member of a commission is 3 years.
The terms of the members shall be staggered.
A member is eligible for reappointment.
The appointing authority shall fill any vacancy on a commission for the unexpired term of the vacant position.
Each local jurisdiction may designate one alternate member for the commission who may sit on the commission when any other member of the commission is absent.
When the alternate member is absent, the local jurisdiction may designate a temporary alternate.

subsection.text: A commission shall adopt rules and regulations necessary for the conduct of its business.
An interested person or representative of an interested person may appear and be heard at a public hearing that a commission conducts.

section.text: Subject to any requirements of the local jurisdiction that relate to the acceptance and use of gifts by public officials, a commission may accept and use gifts as needed to perform its duties.

paragraph.text: Subject to any requirements of the local jurisdiction that relate to the acquisition of easements, a commission may acquire easements in connection with individual sites or structures, or with sites or structures located in or adjacent to a locally designated historic district.

An easement acquired by a commission may grant to the commission, the residents of the historic district, and the public the right to ensure that any site, structure, or surrounding property on which the easement is applied is protected in perpetuity from changes that would affect the historic, archaeological, or architectural significance of the site, structure, or surrounding property.

A commission may designate the Maryland Historical Trust to analyze and make recommendations on the preservation of sites, structures, or districts of historic, archaeological, architectural, or cultural significance within the area the commission serves.
The recommendations of the Maryland Historical Trust may include:

subparagraph.text: proposed boundaries for sites, structures, and districts; and
the identification and designation of the sites, structures, and districts to be preserved.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction shall adopt guidelines for rehabilitation and new construction design for designated sites, structures, and districts that are consistent with those generally recognized by the Maryland Historical Trust.
The guidelines adopted under this section may include:

paragraph.text: design characteristics intended to meet the needs of particular types of sites, structures, and districts; and
identification of categories of changes that are so minimal in nature that they do not:

subparagraph.text: affect historic, archaeological, or architectural significance; and
require review by a commission.

subsection.text: A person shall file an application with the commission before constructing, reconstructing, altering, moving, or demolishing a site or structure located within a locally designated district if any exterior changes are involved that would affect the historic, archaeological, or architectural significance of the site or structure, any portion of which is visible or intended to be visible from a public way.

paragraph.text: An application filed under subsection (a) of this section shall be considered and approved or rejected by the commission.
The commission may reject an application based only on the considerations listed in § 8–303(a) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An applicant may not resubmit an application that is identical to a rejected application for 1 year after the rejection.

A local jurisdiction may not grant a permit for a change to a locally designated site or structure, or to a site or structure located in a locally designated district, until the commission has acted on the application in accordance with § 8–303(a) of this subtitle.
In reviewing an application, a commission shall:

paragraph.text: use the guidelines adopted under § 8–301 of this subtitle; and
consider:

subparagraph.text: the historic, archaeological, or architectural significance of the site or structure and its relationship to the historic, archaeological, or architectural significance of the surrounding area;
the relationship of the exterior architectural features of the structure to the remainder of the structure and to the surrounding area;
the general compatibility of exterior design, scale, proportion, arrangement, texture, and materials proposed to be used; and
any other factors, including aesthetics, that the commission considers pertinent.

subsection.text: A commission shall consider only the exterior features of a structure.
A commission shall strictly judge plans for sites or structures determined by research to be of historic, archaeological, or architectural significance.
Unless the plans would seriously impair the historic, archaeological, or architectural significance of the surrounding site or structure, a commission may not strictly judge plans:

paragraph.text: for a site or structure of little historic, archaeological, or architectural significance; or
involving new construction.

subsection.text: A commission is not required to limit construction, reconstruction, or alteration to the architectural style of any one period.
A commission shall attempt, with the owner of a site or structure, to formulate an economically feasible plan to preserve the site or structure if:

paragraph.text: an application is submitted for construction, reconstruction, or alteration affecting a site or the exterior of a structure or for the moving or demolition of a structure; and
the commission considers preservation of the site or structure to be of unusual importance to the local jurisdiction, the State, or the nation.

subsection.text: Unless the commission is satisfied that the proposed construction, reconstruction, or alteration will not materially impair the historic, archaeological, or architectural significance of the site or structure, the commission shall:

paragraph.text: reject the application; and
file a copy of its rejection with the building inspector of the local jurisdiction.

subsection.text: The commission shall have 90 days after the date on which the commission concludes that an economically feasible plan cannot be formulated under this section to negotiate with the owner and other parties to find a means of preserving the site or structure.

If a site or structure is considered to be valuable for its historic, archaeological, or architectural significance, a commission may approve proposed construction, reconstruction, alteration, moving, or demolition, despite the fact that the changes come within the provisions of this section if:

paragraph.text: the site or structure is a deterrent to a major improvement program that will be of substantial benefit to the local jurisdiction; or
the retention of the site or structure would:

subparagraph.text: cause undue financial hardship to the owner; or
not be in the best interests of a majority of persons in the community.

paragraph.text: A commission shall file with the building inspector of the local jurisdiction a certificate of the commission’s approval, approval with conditions, or modification, or written notice of rejection of an application or plan submitted to the commission for review.

An applicant may not begin work on a project submitted to the commission for review until the commission has filed the certificate of approval, approval with conditions, or modification with the building inspector.

The building inspector may not issue a building permit for a change or construction submitted to the commission for review until the building inspector has received the certificate of approval, approval with conditions, or modification from the commission.

subsection.text: If there is no building inspector in the local jurisdiction:

paragraph.text: a commission shall issue a certificate of the commission’s approval, approval with conditions, or modification, or a written notice of rejection, to the owner, lessee, or tenant of the property that is the subject of the application or plan; and
the owner, lessee, or tenant may not begin the proposed work or change until the commission has issued the certificate of approval, approval with conditions, or modification.

section.text: If a commission fails to act on a completed application within 45 days after the date when the completed application was filed, the application shall be considered approved unless:

paragraph.text: the applicant and the commission agree to an extension of the 45–day period; or
the application is withdrawn.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a decision of a commission may appeal the decision in the manner provided for an appeal from the decision of the planning commission of the local jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: Each local jurisdiction in which a district is designated may enact local laws requiring that:

subparagraph.text: utility companies relocate existing overhead lines and facilities underground within the defined part of the district or the entire district; and
if necessary, private owners who receive service from the relocated lines and facilities place any connection underground.

paragraph.text: A local law enacted under this section shall:

subparagraph.text: require that the estimated cost to property owners for work performed on private property be determined and made available to affected property owners;
provide financing for these costs to private owners, including financing for any charges for the amortization of bonds issued to initially cover private costs; and
include any other provisions reasonably related to placing overhead lines and facilities underground and administering underground relocation projects.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Public Service Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: determine the amount of the monthly surcharge required to support the net capital costs of an underground relocation and determine which customers of the applicable utility are subject to the surcharge;
include the related net capital costs in the rate base; or
adopt any other method to appropriately apportion the costs.

paragraph.text: A utility may not be required to pay more than one–half of the net capital costs of an underground relocation.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction may appropriate money for underground relocation projects from any federal, State, and local funds the local jurisdiction receives for that purpose.

paragraph.text: In implementing subsection (a)(2)(ii) of this section, the local jurisdiction may enter into an agreement with individual property owners under which the local jurisdiction agrees to advance funds to cover the property owners’ costs for the relocation of the overhead lines and facilities.

subparagraph.text: The local jurisdiction may appropriate money, impose taxes, or borrow money to pay and advance the costs of an underground relocation.
In order to recapture expended costs, the local jurisdiction may:

sub-subparagraph.text: impose a benefit assessment against property in the district on behalf of which the utility is relocated underground; and
provide for the collection of the assessment.

section.text: A commission may request that the appropriate enforcement authority of the local jurisdiction seek any of the remedies and penalties provided by law for any violation of a local law adopted under this title.
This subtitle applies to Allegany County.

subsection.text: The planning commission may consist of nine members.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the planning commission is 5 years.
The terms of two of the members of the planning commission shall be staggered.
At the end of a term, a member of the planning commission continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

section.text: This subtitle applies to Baltimore County.

subsection.text: In addition to the jurisdiction granted in Title 11, Subtitle 2 of this article, the legislative body of Baltimore County may provide by local law for an administrative proceeding to enforce its zoning regulations.
The local law may include the authority to impose civil fines and penalties for zoning violations.

section.text: This subtitle applies to Carroll County.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may appoint one of the members of the board of county commissioners to the planning commission.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall designate one alternate member of the planning commission who may sit on the planning commission in the absence of a member of the planning commission.
When the alternate is absent, the county commissioners may designate a temporary alternate.

section.text: If a plat is approved and recorded in accordance with this division before the transfer of the property, § 5–301 of this article does not apply to a contract for sale or negotiation for sale of property zoned industrial, commercial, or both industrial and commercial.

subsection.text: If the county commissioners abate a violation of a zoning law, the county commissioners may assess against the property the reasonable costs of the abatement.

paragraph.text: The assessment shall be:

subparagraph.text: added to the annual tax bill of the property to be collected in the same manner as ordinary taxes are collected; and
subject to the same interest and penalty for nonpayment as provided by law for the nonpayment of county taxes.

paragraph.text: The assessment is a lien against the property from the date of assessment until paid.
A property owner aggrieved by the assessment may petition the county commissioners for relief.
Within 30 days after receiving a petition, the county commissioners shall conduct a hearing to determine the propriety and reasonableness of the assessment.
At the hearing, the petitioner shall have the burden of showing good cause as to why the assessment should not be made.

section.text: This subtitle applies to Cecil County.

subsection.text: The planning commission consists of six regular members and one alternate member.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the planning commission is 3 years.
The terms of the members of the planning commission shall be staggered.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
An ex officio member serves a term concurrent with the member’s term of office.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The board of county commissioners shall appoint a director of planning and zoning for the county.
The director shall serve at the pleasure of the county commissioners.

subsection.text: The planning commission may not appoint a director of planning and zoning.
Notwithstanding § 4–302 of this article, the board of appeals consists of five regular members and one alternate member.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the board of appeals is 3 years.
The terms of the members of the board of appeals shall be staggered.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

section.text: This subtitle applies to Charles County.

paragraph.text: The planning commission consists of seven members who shall represent as many different geographical areas of the county as is possible.
A member of the county commissioners may not sit on the planning commission.
The term of a member of the planning commission is 3 years.
The terms of the members of the planning commission shall be staggered.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: Each year, the county commissioners shall appoint the chair of the planning commission.
Each member of the planning commission is entitled to the compensation the county commissioners consider appropriate.
Notwithstanding § 4–302 of this article, the members of the board of appeals shall be appointed to 4–year terms.
The terms of the members of the board of appeals shall be staggered.
This section applies only to an application for a special exception for:

paragraph.text: an asphalt plant;
a concrete plant;
sand and gravel washing, crushing, or screening; or
surface mining.

Notwithstanding Title 4, Subtitle 3 of this article, the county commissioners may hear and decide a special exception under an appeal filed by a property owner who is aggrieved by a decision of the board of appeals on the special exception.
The county commissioners shall hear and decide an appeal of a special exception in accordance with rules and procedures adopted by the county commissioners.

subsection.text: If the county commissioners adopt rules and procedures for considering a special exception under this section, the decision of the county commissioners to grant, deny, modify, or remand the application for the special exception is a final decision for which judicial review may be requested in the circuit court under Title 4, Subtitle 4 of this article.
Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the subdivision regulations may provide for the reservation of property for traffic, recreation, or other public purposes.
A reservation of property under subsection (a) of this section may not continue for longer than 3 years without the written approval of all persons with a legal or equitable interest in the property.
The subdivision regulations shall provide for public notice and an opportunity for a public hearing before a property may be reserved.

section.text: Section 5–301 of this article does not apply to the sale or negotiation for sale of industrial property.

subsection.text: If the county commissioners abate a violation of a zoning law, the county commissioners may assess against the property the reasonable costs of the abatement.
The assessment shall be:

paragraph.text: added to the annual tax bill of the property to be collected in the same manner as ordinary taxes are collected; and
subject to the same interest and penalty for nonpayment as provided by law for the nonpayment of county taxes.

subsection.text: The assessment is a lien against the property from the date of assessment until paid.

section.text: This subtitle applies to Frederick County.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, the board of county commissioners may overrule an action of the county planning commission under Title 3, Subtitle 2 or 3 of this article by a majority vote of the membership of the board of county commissioners.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding § 4–302 of this article, the members of the board of appeals may be appointed to terms of 1 to 3 years.
The terms of the members of the board of appeals shall be staggered.

section.text: If a plat is approved and recorded in accordance with this division before the transfer of the property, § 5–301 of this article does not apply to a contract for sale or negotiation for sale of property zoned industrial, commercial, or both industrial and commercial.
This subtitle applies to Howard County.

subsection.text: In addition to the jurisdiction granted in Title 11 of this article, the county council may provide by local law for an administrative proceeding to enforce its zoning regulations.
The local law may include the authority to impose civil fines and penalties and to create liens and assess costs for zoning violations.

section.text: This subtitle applies to St. Mary’s County.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, land or buildings may not be used for chemical or catalytic manufacturing, chemical fabrication, gasoline processing, or refining of petroleum or petroleum products.
Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to land or buildings used:

paragraph.text: on or before July 23, 1974, for chemical or catalytic manufacturing, chemical fabrication, gasoline fabrication, gasoline processing, or refining of petroleum or petroleum products; or
on or after July 1, 1980, for manufacturing alcohol fuel.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, any land or building used for races or speed contests involving automobiles or other vehicles, as defined in § 11–176 of the Transportation Article, shall cease operation:

paragraph.text: by 12:30 a.m.; or
if a race or speed contest is in progress at 12:30 a.m., within 30 minutes after the conclusion of that race or speed contest.

subsection.text: The required closing time for land or buildings under subsection (a) of this section does not apply to areas used for the operation of concessions or to a passage used as an entrance to or exit from the concession areas.
Notwithstanding § 4–302 of this article, the members of the board of appeals may be appointed to terms of 1 to 3 years.
The terms of the members of the board of appeals shall be staggered.

section.text: Section 5–301 of this article does not apply to the sale or negotiation for sale of industrial property.

A property deeded before January 1, 1994, and improved with a residence before January 1, 2007, is exempt from the subdivision regulations adopted by the county under Title 5 of this article for purposes of constructing additions to the residence or accessory buildings.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding § 5–301(a) of this article, the county commissioners may provide a civil penalty for a subdivision violation.
In a proceeding before the District Court, a subdivision violation shall be enforced in the same manner and to the same extent as a municipal infraction under Article 23A, § 3(b) of the Code.
Notwithstanding Title 11, Subtitle 2 of this article, the county commissioners may provide a civil penalty for a zoning violation.
In a proceeding before the District Court, a zoning violation shall be enforced in the same manner and to the same extent as a municipal infraction under Article 23A, § 3(b) of the Code.

section.text: This subtitle applies to Talbot County.

subsection.text: In addition to the jurisdiction granted in Title 11 of this article, the legislative body of Talbot County may provide by local law for an administrative proceeding to enforce its zoning regulations.
The local law may include the authority to impose civil fines and penalties for zoning violations.

section.text: Except for land within a municipal corporation, this subtitle applies to Washington County.

subsection.text: In this section, “public facilities” means schools, roads, water, wastewater, and stormwater management facilities, and other infrastructure supported by the federal, State, or local government for public purposes.

In addition to the authority granted in Title 7, Subtitle 1 of this article, the county commissioners may provide by local law for the provision and financing of adequate public facilities concurrently with the need for those facilities.
The local law may include the authority for the county commissioners to:

paragraph.text: determine the functional or design capacity of public facilities;
establish standards for determining the adequacy of public facilities;
determine school capacity standards;
determine the student yield factors for schools at various levels;
establish categories of developments that will be exempt from the application of the local law;
establish formulas for measuring available capacity of public facilities;
determine the adequacy of public facilities in areas affected by new developments in the development plan review process;

enter into agreements with developers providing for the payment of monetary compensation to address inadequacies in public facilities caused by proposed developments as a part of the development plan approval process;
determine the value of in–kind contributions of equivalent value such as real estate;
require forfeiture of contributions 3 years after final plat approval;
establish an appeal process for decisions made under the local law;
limit the number of building permits in any school district; and
limit the number of residential building lots approved for development on an annual basis.

subsection.text: The local law may authorize the county commissioners to impose civil fines and penalties for any violation of the local law.

section.text: This subtitle applies to Worcester County.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, on the zoning or rezoning of land, the county commissioners may impose appropriate restrictions or conditions to preserve or improve the general character and design of:

paragraph.text: the land and improvements being zoned or rezoned; or
the surrounding land and improvements.

subsection.text: On the zoning or rezoning of land, the county commissioners may retain the power to approve or disapprove the design of buildings, construction, landscaping, or other improvements or alterations made on the land to assure conformity with the purposes of this division and the county zoning law.
The county commissioners may exercise the power granted under this section only if the county commissioners adopt a local law that includes:

paragraph.text: enforcement procedures; and
requirements for adequate notice of public hearings and conditions sought to be imposed.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this division or of the local laws of the county, an application for zoning classification or reclassification shall contain the following information:

paragraph.text: if the applicant is a corporation, the names and residences of the officers, directors, and all stockholders owning more than 20% of the capital stock of the corporation;
if the applicant is a general or limited partnership, the names and residences of all partners who own more than 20% of the interest of the partnership;
if the applicant is an individual, the applicant’s name and residence; or

if the applicant is a joint venture, unincorporated association, real estate investment trust, or other business trust or statutory trust, the names and residences of all persons holding an interest of more than 20% in the joint venture, unincorporated association, real estate investment trust, or other business trust or statutory trust.

section.text: In this title, “Board” means the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals.

subsection.text: A regulation adopted under this title that conflicts with any statute, local law, or other regulation shall govern if the regulation adopted under this title:

paragraph.text: requires a greater width or size of yards, courts, or other open spaces;
requires a lower height of buildings;
requires a reduced number of stories;
requires a greater percentage of lot left unoccupied; or
imposes a more restrictive standard.

subsection.text: A statute, local law, or other regulation that conflicts with a regulation adopted under this title shall govern if the statute, local law, or other regulation:

paragraph.text: requires a greater width or size of yards, courts, or other open spaces;
requires a lower height of buildings;
requires a reduced number of stories;
requires a greater percentage of lot left unoccupied; or
imposes a more restrictive standard.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this section, this division does not apply to Baltimore City.
The following provisions of this division apply to Baltimore City:

paragraph.text: this title;
§ 1–101(m) (Definitions – “Priority funding area”);
§ 1–101(o) (Definitions – “Sensitive area”);
§ 1–201 (Visions);
§ 1–206 (Required education);
§ 1–207 (Annual report – In general);
§ 1–208 (Annual report – Measures and indicators);
Title 1, Subtitle 3 (Consistency);
Title 1, Subtitle 4, Parts II and III (Home Rule Counties – Comprehensive Plans; Implementation);
§ 4–104(b) (Limitations – Bicycle parking);
§ 4–205 (Administrative adjustments);
§ 4–207 (Exceptions – Maryland Accessibility Code);
§ 4–210 (Permits and variances – Solar panels);
§ 5–201(d) (Subdivision regulations – Burial sites);
Title 7, Subtitle 1 (Development Mechanisms);
Title 7, Subtitle 2 (Transfer of Development Rights);
Title 7, Subtitle 3 (Development Rights and Responsibilities Agreements);
Title 7, Subtitle 4 (Inclusionary Zoning); and
Title 11, Subtitle 2 (Civil Penalty).

subsection.text: It is the policy of the State that:

paragraph.text: the orderly development and use of land and structures requires comprehensive regulation through the implementation of planning and zoning controls; and
planning and zoning controls shall be implemented by local government.

subsection.text: To achieve the public purposes of this regulatory scheme, the General Assembly recognizes that local government action will limit free business enterprise and competition by owners and users of property through the planning and zoning controls set forth in this title and elsewhere in the public general and public local laws.

section.text: To promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the community, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may regulate:

paragraph.text: the height, number of stories, and size of buildings and other structures;
the percentage of a lot that may be occupied;
off–street parking;
the size of yards, courts, and other open spaces;
population density; and
the location and use of buildings, signs, structures, and land.

section.text: The powers granted to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City under this title do not:

paragraph.text: grant to the Mayor and City Council powers in any substantive area not otherwise granted to the Mayor and City Council by any other public general or public local law;
restrict the Mayor and City Council from exercising any power granted to the Mayor and City Council by any other public general or public local law or otherwise;
authorize the Mayor and City Council or the officers of Baltimore City to engage in any activity that is beyond their power under any other public general law or public local law or otherwise; or
preempt or supersede the regulatory authority of any unit of the State under any public general law.

subsection.text: To preserve structures and landmarks of historic and architectural value as a public purpose of the State, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may enact laws for historic and landmark zoning and preservation.
This section does not restrict any charter power or other power of Baltimore City.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may divide Baltimore City into districts and zones of any number, shape, and area as they determine are best suited to carry out the purposes listed in § 10–302 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Within the districts and zones, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may regulate the construction, alteration, repair, or use of buildings, structures, or land.

subparagraph.text: Zoning regulations adopted by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City under this subtitle shall be uniform for each class or kind of development throughout each district or zone.
Zoning regulations in one district or zone may differ from those in other districts or zones.

section.text: Zoning regulations adopted by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: be in accordance with the plan;
be designed to:

subparagraph.text: control street congestion;
promote health, public safety, and general welfare;
provide adequate light and air;
promote the conservation of natural resources;
prevent environmental pollution;
avoid an undue concentration of population; and
promote or facilitate adequate transportation, water, sewerage, schools, recreation, parks, and other public facilities; and

paragraph.text: include reasonable consideration for:

subparagraph.text: the character of the district or zone and its suitability for particular uses;
the conservation of the value of buildings and other structures; and
encouragement for orderly development and the most appropriate use of land throughout Baltimore City.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall provide for the manner in which zoning regulations and the boundaries of districts and zones shall be established, enforced, and amended.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall hold at least one public hearing on a proposed zoning regulation or boundary at which parties in interest and citizens have an opportunity to be heard.
The zoning regulation or boundary may not become effective until after the hearing or hearings.

subsection.text: At least 15 days before a public hearing is held under this section, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall publish notice of the time and place of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in Baltimore City.
If a hearing under this section will be on a proposed change in the boundaries of a district or zone, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall:

paragraph.text: post a similar notice at a place designated by the respective zoning authorities within the district or zone proposed to be changed; and
mail notice of the proposed change by United States first–class mail to any person whose name last appeared in the Baltimore City tax records as the owner of the property proposed to be changed.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may amend or repeal zoning regulations and boundaries.

paragraph.text: If the purpose and effect of a proposed map amendment is to change the zoning classification of particular property, the City Council shall make findings of fact that address:

subparagraph.text: population change;
the availability of public facilities;
present and future transportation patterns;
compatibility with existing and proposed development for the area;
the recommendations of the Baltimore City Planning Commission and the Board; and
the relationship of the proposed amendment to Baltimore City’s plan.

paragraph.text: The City Council may grant the amendment to change the zoning classification based on a finding that there was:

subparagraph.text: a substantial change in the character of the neighborhood where the property is located; or
a mistake in the existing zoning classification.

paragraph.text: The City Council may not allow the filing of an application for a reclassification of a tract or parcel of land for which a reclassification has been denied by the City Council on the merits in the 12 months before the date of the application.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall refer proposed changes to the boundaries of a district or zone to the Baltimore City Planning Commission and to the Board.
The Planning Commission and the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: study the proposed changes in relation to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the plan;
the needs of Baltimore City; and
the needs of the particular neighborhood in the vicinity of the proposed changes; and

subparagraph.text: report their findings and recommendations to the Mayor and City Council.

paragraph.text: If the Planning Commission and the Board recommend disapproval of the proposed changes to the boundaries of a district or zone, the changes may not take effect unless a majority of the members of the City Council vote to approve the changes.

subsection.text: The provisions of § 10–303 of this subtitle concerning public hearings and notice apply to all changes or amendments to regulations and boundaries.
A violation of this title or a local law enacted or regulation adopted under this title is a misdemeanor.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide by local law for the enforcement of this title and any local law enacted or regulation adopted under this title.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may:

subparagraph.text: require punishment by fine or imprisonment or both; and
enact or adopt civil penalties for a violation.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide by local law that a violation of this title or a local law enacted or regulation adopted under this title is a civil zoning violation.

subsection.text: In addition to any other available remedies, the proper authorities of Baltimore City may institute any appropriate action or proceedings to:

paragraph.text: prevent the unlawful construction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use of a sign, a building, a structure, or land in violation of this title or any local law enacted or regulation adopted under this title;
restrain, correct, or abate the violation;
prevent the occupancy of the building, structure, or land; or
prevent any illegal act, conduct, business, or use in or about the premises of the building, structure, or land.

subsection.text: The City Council of Baltimore City may appoint full– and part–time hearing examiners that it considers necessary and appropriate to conduct public hearings as required under §§ 10–303 through 10–305 of this title.
The City Council shall establish the term of office, qualifications, and compensation for hearing examiners.
A hearing examiner shall conduct a hearing in the same manner and subject to the same rules as a hearing conducted by the City Council.
A hearing examiner shall issue a written recommendation in the time, manner, and form established by the City Council.
With the advice and consent of the City Council, the Mayor may provide for the appointment of a Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals.

paragraph.text: The Board shall consist of five members.

subparagraph.text: The term of a member of the Board is 4 years.
The terms of the members of the Board shall be staggered as provided on October 1, 2012.

paragraph.text: With the advice and consent of the City Council, the Mayor shall appoint an individual to fill the unexpired term of any member.
On written charges and after a public hearing, the Mayor may remove any member of the Board for cause.
The Board shall adopt rules in accordance with any local law adopted under this title.
Meetings of the Board shall be:

subparagraph.text: held at the call of the chair and at other times determined by the Board; and
open to the public.

paragraph.text: The chair of the Board or, in the chair’s absence, the acting chair may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses.
The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, including the vote of each member on each question, or the member’s absence or failure to vote.

subparagraph.text: The Board shall keep records of the examinations and other official actions of the Board.
The records of the Board shall be:

sub-subparagraph.text: filed promptly in the office of the Board; and
open to the public.

subsection.text: The Board may:

paragraph.text: hear and decide appeals when it is alleged that there was an error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative official or unit under this title or any local law adopted under this title;
hear and decide special exceptions or conditional uses on which the Board is required to act under a local law;
authorize on appeal in specific cases a variance from the terms of a local law;
approve buildings and uses limited as to location by any regulation adopted under a local law; and
when acting on a zoning application, consider the availability of public facilities in the area, including schools and flood plain facilities, under regulations adopted under a local law.

subsection.text: If authorized by the general zoning laws of Baltimore City, this subtitle does not prevent the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City from granting by local law:

paragraph.text: variances;
special exceptions; or
conditional uses.

subsection.text: An appeal to the Board may be filed by:

paragraph.text: a person aggrieved by a decision of the administrative officer or unit; or
an officer or unit of Baltimore City affected by a decision of the administrative officer or unit.

subsection.text: A person shall file an appeal within a reasonable time provided by local law or the rules of the Board by filing with the administrative officer or unit from whose action the appeal is taken and with the Board a notice of appeal specifying the grounds of the appeal.
On receiving the notice of appeal, the administrative officer or unit from whose action the appeal is taken shall transmit to the Board all papers constituting the record of the action appealed.

paragraph.text: Unless the administrative officer or unit from whose action an appeal is taken, after receiving the notice of appeal, certifies facts to the Board that the administrative officer or unit believes that a stay would cause imminent peril to life or property, an appeal stays all proceedings in the action appealed.
If the administrative officer or unit provides facts showing that a stay would cause imminent peril to life or property, the proceedings may be stayed only by a restraining order granted by:

subparagraph.text: the Board; or
the Circuit Court for Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: A restraining order may be issued only:

subparagraph.text: on application;
for good cause shown; and
after notice is given to the administrative officer or unit from whose action the appeal is taken.

paragraph.text: The Board shall:

subparagraph.text: establish a reasonable time for the hearing of an appeal;
give public notice of the existence of the appeal and of the hearing, and due notice to the parties in interest and to other persons entitled to notice under local law or the rules of the Board; and
decide the appeal within a reasonable time.

paragraph.text: At a hearing, a party may:

subparagraph.text: appear in person; or
be represented by an agent or attorney.

paragraph.text: The Board may, in conformity with this title:

subparagraph.text: wholly or partly reverse the order, requirement, or decision that is the subject of the appeal;
wholly or partly affirm the order, requirement, or decision that is the subject of the appeal; or
modify the order, requirement, or decision that is the subject of the appeal.

paragraph.text: The Board shall have the powers of the administrative officer or unit from whose action the appeal is taken.

subsection.text: If five members of the Board are present, the concurring vote of at least four members is necessary to:

paragraph.text: reverse any order, requirement, or decision of an administrative officer or unit;
decide in favor of the applicant on any matter on which the Board is required to act under a local law; or
effect any variation in a local law.

subsection.text: If four members of the Board are present, the concurring vote of at least three members is necessary to take any action under this section.
A request for judicial review by the Circuit Court for Baltimore City may be filed by any person, taxpayer, or officer or unit of Baltimore City aggrieved by:

paragraph.text: a decision of the Board; or
a zoning action by the City Council.

subsection.text: The judicial review shall be in accordance with Title 7, Chapter 200 of the Maryland Rules.
This section does not change the existing standards for judicial review of a zoning action.

paragraph.text: The Circuit Court for Baltimore City may:

subparagraph.text: consider the judicial review on the record; or
allow either side or both sides to present additional testimony if the court believes that additional testimony is required for the proper disposition of the judicial review.

paragraph.text: The court shall consider the judicial review without a jury.
In reviewing a decision of the Board, the Circuit Court for Baltimore City may:

subparagraph.text: reverse in whole or part;
affirm in whole or part;
modify; or
remand for further consideration.
If a petition for judicial review is remanded for further consideration, any testimony taken in court shall be made available to the Board.
The costs of preparing the testimony shall be made a part of the costs of judicial review.

section.text: A judgment of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City under § 10–502 of this subtitle may be appealed to the Court of Special Appeals.

subsection.text: In addition to the judicial review provided under § 10–501 of this subtitle, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may allow judicial review by the Circuit Court for Baltimore City of any matter arising under the planning and zoning laws of Baltimore City.
A judgment of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City under this section may be appealed to the Court of Special Appeals.
This section does not restrict any charter power or other power of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City.
A legislative body may provide by local law for the enforcement of this division and of any local law enacted or regulation adopted under this division.
Any property subdivided in violation of §§ 5–301 and 5–302 of this article shall remain subject to the adopted subdivision regulations.
A violation of this division or of a local law enacted or regulation adopted under this division is a misdemeanor.
A legislative body may:

paragraph.text: provide for punishment of a violation by fine or imprisonment or both; and
impose civil penalties for a violation.

subsection.text: In addition to any other available remedy, a local jurisdiction may institute any appropriate action or proceeding to:

paragraph.text: prevent the unlawful construction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use of a building, structure, sign, or land in violation of this division or of a local law enacted or regulation adopted under this division;
restrain, correct, or abate the violation;
prevent the occupancy of the building, structure, or land; or
prevent any illegal act, conduct, business, or use in or about the premises.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a local jurisdiction may not institute an action or proceeding to:

paragraph.text: abate a transfer that has been completed; or
prevent the occupancy of a building, structure, or land involved in the transfer as a result of a violation of § 5–301 or § 5–302 of this article.

section.text: In this subtitle, “zoning official” means a county employee with the duty of enforcing the zoning law.

subsection.text: A legislative body of a county may provide a civil penalty for a zoning violation, which shall be enforced as provided in this subtitle.
The legislative body may:

paragraph.text: impose a fine not exceeding $500 for each violation;
establish a schedule of additional fines for each violation; and
adopt procedures for the collection of the fines.

subsection.text: A zoning official may deliver a citation to a person who has committed a civil zoning violation.

paragraph.text: The citation shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the person charged;
the nature of the violation, including the provision violated;
the location and time of the violation;
the amount of the fine;
the manner, location, and time for payment of the fine; and
