notice of the cited person’s right to elect to stand trial for the violation and how to exercise that right.

paragraph.text: The citation shall bear a certification attesting to the truth of the matters set forth in the citation.

subsection.text: The zoning official shall keep a copy of the citation.

A person who receives a citation may elect to stand trial for the violation by filing a notice of intention to stand trial with the zoning official at least 5 business days before the date set forth in the citation for the payment of fines.
After receiving a notice of intention to stand trial, the zoning official shall forward the notice, with a copy of the citation, to the District Court having venue.
After receiving the citation and notice, the District Court shall:

paragraph.text: schedule the case for trial; and
notify the defendant of the trial date.

subsection.text: If a person that receives a citation for a violation fails to pay the fine by the date of payment set forth in the citation and fails to file a notice of intention to stand trial, the zoning official shall mail a notice of the violation to the person’s last known address.

If the person that receives the citation does not pay or otherwise satisfy the citation within 15 days after the date the notice of violation is mailed, the person shall be subject to an additional fine not exceeding twice the amount of the original fine.

paragraph.text: If the person that receives the citation does not pay or otherwise satisfy the citation within 35 days after the notice of violation is mailed, the zoning official may request the District Court to adjudicate the violation.
If the zoning official requests adjudication, the District Court shall:

subparagraph.text: schedule the case for trial; and
summon the defendant to appear.

section.text: In a proceeding before the District Court, a violation shall be adjudicated in the same manner and to the same extent as a municipal infraction under Article 23A, § 3(b)(7) through (15) of the Code.

subsection.text: All fines, penalties, or forfeitures collected by the District Court for zoning violations shall be remitted to the county in which the zoning violation occurred.
If the District Court finds that a person has committed a civil zoning violation, the person shall be liable for the costs of the court proceedings.

section.text: The governing body of a county may authorize the county attorney to seek adjudication of a civil zoning violation.
A finding by the District Court of a violation under this subtitle is not a criminal conviction and does not impose any of the civil disabilities ordinarily imposed by a criminal conviction.

subsection.text: In this division the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission.
“Commissioner” means a member of the Commission.
“County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.
“County planning board” means a planning board for a county established under Title 20, Subtitle 2 of this article.
“District council” means:

paragraph.text: for a single county, the county council sitting as the district council of the county with respect to that portion of the regional district in the county under § 22–101 of this article;
for the district council as a whole, the county councils of both counties sitting jointly as the bi–county district council of the regional district under § 22–102 of this article; or

for a municipal corporation, the governing body of the municipal corporation sitting as the district council for the municipal corporation under an agreement authorized under § 20–704(c) of this article.

subsection.text: “Governed special taxing district” or “governed district” means a special taxing district that:

paragraph.text: has an elected local governing body; and
performs general municipal functions.
“Local law” means an enactment of the legislative body of a local jurisdiction, whether by ordinance, resolution, or otherwise.
“Local law” does not include a public local law.

subsection.text: “Metropolitan district” means the Maryland–Washington Metropolitan District established under Title 19 of this article.
“Park” includes a public playground, play field, and any other recreational ground, space, or facility.

“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, representative of any kind, partnership, firm, association, corporation, limited liability company, or other entity.
“Regional district” means the Maryland–Washington Regional District established under Title 20, Subtitle 1 of this article.
“Road” includes a highway, freeway, boulevard, parkway, street, avenue, lane, alley, viaduct, bridge, and any other way or part of a way.
“Sensitive area” has the meaning stated in § 1–101 of this article.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, “state” means:

subparagraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

paragraph.text: When capitalized, “State” means Maryland.
“Subdivision” means:

subparagraph.text: the process and configuration of land by which one or more lots, tracts, or parcels of land are divided, consolidated, or established as one or more lots or parcels, or other divisions of land, consistent with criteria established by the legislative body of the local jurisdiction; or
the land so subdivided.

paragraph.text: “Subdivision” includes resubdivision.
“Zoning law” means the legislative implementation of regulations for zoning by a local jurisdiction.
“Zoning law” includes a zoning ordinance, zoning regulation, zoning code, and any similar legislative action to implement zoning controls in a local jurisdiction.

section.text: This division applies only in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Title 20, Subtitle 7, Part I, Title 24, Subtitle 2, and Title 25, Subtitle 3 of this article, Article XI–E of the Maryland Constitution does not apply to the Commission, the metropolitan district, or the regional district.
Neither the Commission, the metropolitan district, nor the regional district is a “municipal corporation” under Article XI–E of the Maryland Constitution.

section.text: The requirement or authorization for a local jurisdiction to enact a local law to implement a provision of this division is not intended to alter in any way the form or legislative mechanism that the applicable enabling authority requires for the local jurisdiction to enact the local law, whether by ordinance, resolution, or otherwise, as of October 1, 2012.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission.
The Commission is a body politic and corporate and is an agency of the State.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of 10 members.
Of the 10 members of the Commission:

subparagraph.text: five shall be residents and registered voters of Montgomery County; and
five shall be residents and registered voters of Prince George’s County.
Subject to the approval of the County Executive, the County Council shall appoint each commissioner from Montgomery County.
Subject to the approval of the County Council, the County Executive shall appoint each commissioner from Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: Each commissioner shall be an individual of ability, experience, and integrity.

paragraph.text: Of the commissioners from each county, not more than three shall be members of the same political party.
A commissioner may not be selected as representing or supporting any special interest.
The term of a commissioner is 4 years and begins on June 15.
The terms of commissioners are staggered as required by the terms provided for commissioners on October 1, 2012.
At the end of a term, a commissioner continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A commissioner who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A commissioner who is appointed to fill a vacancy for an unexpired term shall be a member of the same political party as the commissioner who vacated the office.
A commissioner appointed from Montgomery County may not be appointed for three consecutive full terms.
In Montgomery County, the County Council shall make an appointment to the Commission from a list of applicants.
The list shall be:

subparagraph.text: completed at least 3 weeks before an appointment is made; and
made available to the public.

paragraph.text: If the County Council does not appoint an individual whose name appears on the list or if no name appears on the list, the County Council shall provide for the preparation of a second list and follow the procedures under paragraph (2) of this subsection.
Within 3 days after making an appointment, the County Council shall submit the name of the appointee to the County Executive.
Within 30 days after the appointment is submitted, the County Executive shall approve or disapprove the appointment.
An appointment that is not disapproved by the County Executive in accordance with this subsection is deemed to be approved.
If the County Executive disapproves an appointment, the County Executive shall return the appointment to the County Council with the reasons for the disapproval stated in writing.
By the affirmative vote of seven of its members, the County Council may appoint a commissioner over the disapproval of the County Executive.

In Prince George’s County, the County Council shall hold public hearings on an appointment to the Commission not less than 10 days and not more than 20 days after the County Executive submits the name of the appointee to the County Council.
If the County Council fails to act on the appointment within 30 days after the County Executive submits the name of the appointee, the appointment is deemed to be approved.
A vote of a majority of the full County Council is required to approve or disapprove an appointment.

subparagraph.text: In making and approving appointments, the County Council and County Executive shall attempt to provide reasonable geographic balance with respect to the commissioners’ places of residence.
The appointment resolution for each appointment shall describe the resulting geographic distribution and provide appropriate explanations.

subsection.text: This section applies to each commissioner appointed by the Montgomery County Council under §§ 15–102 and 15–103 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Montgomery County Council may require an applicant for appointment as a commissioner to be interviewed by the County Council or its designated agent in private regarding possible or potential conflicts of interest.

Before the appointment is made, the County Council or its designated agent shall interview in private an applicant who is selected for appointment regarding possible or potential conflicts of interest.

subsection.text: An applicant may not be appointed unless the applicant:

paragraph.text: has filed a financial disclosure statement as required by § 15–820 of the State Government Article; and
has been interviewed as required by subsection (b) of this section.
In an interview under this section, the applicant shall be interviewed:

subparagraph.text: under oath;
in a question and answer format; and

about information and interests including all sources of income, property holdings, business interests, and financial interests of the applicant and the applicant’s spouse, parent, child, brother, or sister.

paragraph.text: The County Council may require the applicant to produce relevant documents.
A written transcript shall be made of all questions and answers in an interview under this section.
Unless the examination is waived by the applicant:

subparagraph.text: the transcript shall be submitted to the applicant for examination;
the transcribing officer shall make any changes in the transcript that the applicant desires to make, accompanied by a statement of the reason given by the applicant for the changes; and
the applicant shall sign the transcript.

paragraph.text: The transcribing officer shall certify on the transcript that:

subparagraph.text: the applicant was sworn by the officer; and
the transcript is a true record of the testimony given by the applicant.

paragraph.text: The County Council shall:

subparagraph.text: publicly disclose the complete transcript of an appointee within 3 weeks after the date of the appointment; and
when the appointee takes office, destroy immediately the complete transcript of any other applicant without disclosure of any information contained in the transcript.

paragraph.text: On or before June 1 of each year, an appointee shall disclose, in writing, to the County Council all information available to make current the property holdings, business interests, and financial interests in the State and the greater Washington metropolitan area of the appointee and the appointee’s spouse, parent, child, brother, or sister.
The County Council shall publicly disclose the information received from the appointee.
If the County Council determines it necessary, the County Council may require substantiation and additional information.
The Montgomery County Council may remove any commissioner appointed from Montgomery County before the expiration of the commissioner’s term.

With the approval of a majority of the members of the County Council, the County Executive of Prince George’s County may remove any commissioner appointed from Prince George’s County before the expiration of the commissioner’s term.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, before a commissioner may be removed under subsection (a) of this section:

subparagraph.text: the cause for removal shall be stated in writing; and
a public hearing shall be held on the removal.

paragraph.text: In Prince George’s County, the commissioner sought to be removed may waive in writing the public hearing held by the County Council.

subsection.text: The County Executive of Prince George’s County, with the approval of a majority of the members of the County Council, and the Montgomery County Council, with the approval of the County Executive in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, shall each designate a commissioner for the position of chair or vice chair.

paragraph.text: Within 3 days after making a designation, the Montgomery County Council shall submit the name of the designee to the County Executive.
Within 30 days after the designation is submitted, the County Executive shall approve or disapprove the designation.
If the County Executive disapproves a designee, the County Executive shall return the name of the designee to the County Council with the reasons for the disapproval stated in writing.
By the affirmative vote of six of its members, the County Council may designate a commissioner for the position of chair or vice chair over the disapproval of the County Executive.
A designation that has not been disapproved by the County Executive in accordance with this subsection is deemed to be approved.

subsection.text: The Commission shall elect a chair and vice chair from the commissioners designated in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: The chair shall:

subparagraph.text: preside at meetings of the Commission; and
perform the other customary duties of the office.

paragraph.text: The vice chair shall preside in the absence of the chair.
The chair and vice chair of the Commission also serve as chairs of their respective county planning boards.

subsection.text: The Montgomery County Council may designate a commissioner from that county to serve on a full–time basis as the chair or vice chair of the Commission.

With the approval of a majority of the members of the County Council, the County Executive of Prince George’s County may designate a commissioner from that county to serve on a full–time basis as the chair or vice chair of the Commission.

subparagraph.text: Each commissioner other than the chair is entitled to an annual salary of $5,600.
The chair of the Commission is entitled to an annual salary of $6,100.

paragraph.text: All salaries shall be paid monthly from the administrative tax collected by the Commission under § 18–307 of this article.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, each commissioner is entitled to an annual expense allowance not exceeding $2,400, in accordance with rules and regulations the Commission adopts.
A commissioner shall submit a voucher showing the expenses.

With the approval of the County Executive of Montgomery County, the County Council may authorize an appropriate supplementary salary for the commissioner designated by Montgomery County to serve on a full–time basis.

If the County Executive fails to approve a supplementary salary authorization by the County Council within 30 days after the authorization is submitted, the County Council, by an affirmative vote of six of its members, may authorize the supplementary salary without the approval of the County Executive.

paragraph.text: On the recommendation of the County Executive of Prince George’s County, the County Council may authorize an appropriate supplementary salary for the commissioner designated by Prince George’s County to serve on a full–time basis.
Any supplementary salary authorized under this subsection shall be paid from the administrative tax collected by the Commission under § 18–307 of this article.
The Commission shall appoint an executive director, a secretary–treasurer, and a general counsel.
The executive director, secretary–treasurer, and general counsel serve at the pleasure of the Commission.
The Commission shall set the compensation of the executive director, secretary–treasurer, and general counsel.

subsection.text: The executive director and the secretary–treasurer shall be bonded.
Of the three officers appointed under this section, not more than two shall be residents of the same county.

section.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: appoint or contract for the services of planning, engineering, legal, administrative, auditing, clerical, staff, or other employees necessary to administer this division on a regional basis; and
set the compensation of employees and contractors.

section.text: The Commission may require any officer or employee to post security in a form and amount the Commission approves.
The Commission may:

paragraph.text: maintain offices in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County; and
hold meetings, conduct hearings, and perform any of its duties under this division at the office that, in the Commission’s judgment, best suits the convenience of the public.

subsection.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: exercise the powers, duties, and functions provided in this division;
use a common seal;
sue and be sued; and
do any other corporate act necessary to carry out this division.

subsection.text: The Commission may raise the defense of partial governmental immunity described under § 5–512 of the Courts Article.
The Commission shall establish an adequate comprehensive insurance program.

paragraph.text: The comprehensive insurance program shall provide:

subparagraph.text: compensation for personal injury or death or property damage resulting from negligence, malpractice, or any other civil or tortious act or omission of the Commission, or of its commissioners, employees, and agents acting within the scope of their duties and without malice or gross negligence; and
protection for property of the Commission and for officials and employees acting within the scope of their duties, including a comprehensive workers’ compensation program.

paragraph.text: The Commission may purchase any other liability insurance the Commission considers necessary.

subsection.text: The Commission may establish a program of group health, life, hospitalization, and disability insurance by purchasing insurance coverage from insurance companies authorized to do business in the State and, except for disability insurance, not by self–insurance.

paragraph.text: The insurance required under subsection (b) of this section and the disability insurance authorized under subsection (c) of this section may be provided by:

subparagraph.text: purchasing insurance coverage from insurance companies authorized to do business in the State;
a self–insurance program; or
a combination of purchased insurance coverage and self–insurance.

paragraph.text: If a self–insurance program is established and funded to cover all or part of the insurance required under subsection (b) of this section:

subparagraph.text: the Commission shall adopt rules and regulations for the administration of the program; and
funding for the program shall be included in the annual operating budget.

paragraph.text: The insurance program established by the Commission shall provide for:

subparagraph.text: defense of claims; and
compensation for damages.

paragraph.text: Within the limits of appropriations for the insurance program, the Commission may:

subparagraph.text: engage necessary claims investigators and adjustors; and
provide for the defense and settlement of claims and payment of judgments.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Commission may cooperate with and enter into agreements to obtain and provide insurance coverage in the most economical manner with:

subparagraph.text: Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County;
both Montgomery County and Prince George’s County; or
subject to the approval of the county government of a county affected by the agreement, other units of government.

paragraph.text: An agreement under paragraph (1) of this subsection may provide for any type of insurance protection, including:

subparagraph.text: public liability;
group health, life, hospitalization, and disability;
real and personal property; and
workers’ compensation.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not authorize the Commission to establish a self–insurance program for group health, life, and hospitalization insurance.

Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, a payment made to a police officer employed by the Commission for an illness or injury received in the line of duty in accordance with any disability program or disability insurance program authorized under this section is considered in the nature of workers’ compensation.
A payment described in this subsection is independent of any payment made under the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act.
This subsection does not affect:

subparagraph.text: the offset provision under § 9–610 of the Labor and Employment Article; or
the presumption of a police officer’s entitlement to benefits under § 9–503 of the Labor and Employment Article.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall prepare an annual financial report.
The annual financial report shall:

subparagraph.text: include the financial statements of the Commission; and
be certified by an independent certified public accountant.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall make the certified annual financial report available for distribution to the public.
After the audit is completed, the Commission shall publish a summary financial report consisting of a combined statement of revenues and expenditures for all funds:

subparagraph.text: in at least one newspaper of general circulation published in Montgomery County; and

sub-subparagraph.text: in the newspapers officially designated by the Prince George’s County government as newspapers of record; or
in the absence of a designation of a newspaper of record, in at least one newspaper of general circulation published in Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: The publication of the summary financial report shall carry appropriate references to the Commission’s certified annual financial report.
The Commission shall publish each year a report describing the work of the Commission for the previous year, in the detail that the Commission considers appropriate.
The report required under this subsection shall include:

subparagraph.text: land acquisitions;
financial transactions;
personnel matters; and
litigation and disposition of violations.

subsection.text: The Commission may publish pamphlets describing:

paragraph.text: the law administered by the Commission; and
subdivision, zoning, and other regulations adopted or enacted by the Commission or the district councils.

subsection.text: The Commission may charge a fee for a publication issued under this section to cover any of the cost of the publication.
The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: maintain a minute or record book; and
record its actions in the minute or record book in usual corporate form.
The votes of the commissioners shall be separately taken and recorded by yeas, nays, and abstentions, and the reasons for each abstention shall be recorded, with respect to any:

subparagraph.text: action authorizing, modifying, or rescinding the adoption of a master plan;
approval of plats of subdivision;
approval of subdivision or other regulations;
recommendations on zoning map amendments; or
zoning text amendments.

paragraph.text: The names of the commissioners voting or abstaining shall be included in the minute entry following a brief summary of the matter on which the vote was taken.

subsection.text: The minute or record book shall be kept available and open to public inspection and copying during business hours in the Commission’s principal offices.

section.text: In the performance of the functions and duties of the Commission, any commissioner or employee or agent of the Commission may enter at all reasonable hours any building or private premises in the metropolitan district or in the regional district to make examinations and surveys and to place and maintain necessary monuments and marks on the building or premises.

Commissioners and employees of the Commission may engage in civilian defense or other defense activities under the direction of, or in cooperation with, federal, State, or county units in charge of the defense activities.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit a commissioner from:

paragraph.text: appearing in the pursuit of the commissioner’s private interests as a citizen;
accepting or receiving any benefit by operation of law; or
prosecuting or pursuing any claim, right, privilege, or remedy that accrues to the commissioner by operation of law.

subparagraph.text: This subsection does not prohibit a commissioner from having or holding a private investment, business, or professional interest, unless the interest is or reasonably may be in conflict with the proper performance of the commissioner’s duty.

A private investment, business, or professional interest is presumed to be in conflict with the proper performance of the commissioner’s duty if the commissioner or the commissioner’s spouse, parent, child, brother, or sister:

sub-subparagraph.text: jointly or severally owns more than 3% of the invested capital or capital stock of any entity involved in the decision being made by the commissioner, Commission, or county planning board on which the commissioner serves; or

receives a total combined compensation of more than $5,000 a year from any person involved in the decision being made by the commissioner, Commission, or county planning board on which the commissioner serves.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to or include:

subparagraph.text: an interest or investment in land geographically remote from the land involved in the decision;
the ownership of a recorded single–family lot on which the commissioner actually resides; or
a possibility of reverter, a mortgage, or other security interest in real property not otherwise described in this subsection.

paragraph.text: A commissioner may not:

subparagraph.text: decide, or participate in, a decision in which the commissioner has a financial interest, whether as an owner, member, partner, officer, employee, stockholder, or other participant of or in any private business or professional enterprise, that will be affected by the decision; or
knowingly participate in a decision affecting the financial interest, jointly or severally, of a person related to the commissioner or the commissioner’s spouse, parent, child, brother, or sister.

subsection.text: A commissioner may not:

paragraph.text: act as a broker, agent, attorney, representative, or employee of any person in the person’s business dealings with:

subparagraph.text: Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County;
the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission; or
the Commission;

paragraph.text: decide, or participate in, a decision on any matter in which a close business or professional associate has acted as a broker, agent, attorney, representative, or employee of any person or represented private interests before:

subparagraph.text: Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County;
the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission; or
the Commission; or

paragraph.text: represent a private interest or appear in a position of advocacy, other than in the performance of the commissioner’s official duties, either in person or through an associate, in any matter or proceeding pending before:

subparagraph.text: the Montgomery County Council;
the Prince George’s County Council;
the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
the Commission;
the Montgomery County Board of Appeals; or
the Prince George’s County Board of Appeals.

subsection.text: A commissioner may not solicit or accept any gift, favor, loan, service, promise, employment, or thing that might influence or tend to influence the proper performance of the commissioner’s duty.
A commissioner may not:

paragraph.text: disclose confidential information concerning the property, management, or affairs of:

subparagraph.text: Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County;
the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission; or
the Commission; or

paragraph.text: use any information described in item (1) of this subsection to advance the financial or other private interests of the commissioner or other persons.

subsection.text: A commissioner may not attempt to influence for a purpose contrary to this section any other county or State official in the conduct of the other official’s duties.

paragraph.text: If a commissioner has any interest described in this section that is or reasonably may be incompatible with or in conflict with any of the commissioner’s official duties or acts, the commissioner:

subparagraph.text: shall disclose the interest in a regular public meeting of the Commission or the county planning boards; and
is disqualified and may not participate in the decision or act affected by the interest.

paragraph.text: A disclosure made under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall appear in the minutes of the meeting.

subsection.text: A commissioner who violates any provision of subsections (b) through (f) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both;
suspension from the Commission or employment not exceeding 6 months;
forfeiture and removal from office; or
any combination of the penalties described in items (1) through (3) of this subsection.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 426 OF 2012 //

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Certified minority business enterprise” means a minority business enterprise that meets the requirements established by regulation under § 15–203 of this subtitle.
“Minority” means a group that the Commission finds to be socially or economically disadvantaged in accordance with § 15–202(a) of this subtitle.
“Program” means the Minority Business Enterprise Utilization Program.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 426 OF 2012 //

subsection.text: The Commission may study and make a finding as to whether a group is socially or economically disadvantaged as a result of discrimination in the public or private sector that affects the group’s utilization and participation in contracting or procurement with the Commission.

If the Commission finds that a program is necessary to remedy discrimination against a minority, the Commission shall establish a Minority Business Enterprise Utilization Program to facilitate participation of responsible certified minority business enterprises in contracts awarded by the Commission for goods, services, and construction.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 426 OF 2012 //

subsection.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations for the operation of the Program.
The regulations shall provide for:

paragraph.text: acceptance of the certification of a minority business enterprise that has been certified by the State certification agency designated under § 14–303 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
waiver of all or part of the Program provisions for a specific contract if the Commission determines that:

subparagraph.text: a minority business enterprise is unavailable; or
application of the Program to the contract conflicts with the overall objectives and responsibilities of the Commission;

paragraph.text: graduation of a certified minority business enterprise from the Program if the Commission determines that a minority business enterprise no longer requires the assistance or benefits offered by the Program;
termination of the Program when the Program is no longer necessary to remedy the effects of past discrimination;
acceptance of the decisions of any other certification program that, in the judgment of the Commission, assures that a certified minority business enterprise is legitimate;
minority participation in subcontracting and direct contracting; and
application of reasonable preferences to a certified minority business enterprise in evaluating competitive bids or proposals.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 426 OF 2012 //

On or before October 31 of each year, the Commission shall issue a report to the Montgomery County and Prince George’s County delegations to the House of Delegates and Senate of Maryland, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, that:

paragraph.text: evaluates the results of the Program through June 30 of that year; and
makes appropriate recommendations.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Contract” means an agreement, commitment, or arrangement made between the Commission and a governmental unit to further the purposes stated in § 15–302 of this subtitle.
“Governmental unit” means:

paragraph.text: the National Capital Planning Commission;
the United States government;
the District of Columbia;
the State, including the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
Virginia;
Montgomery County or Prince George’s County;
any municipal corporation, local subdivision, or corporation within the State, Virginia, Montgomery County, or Prince George’s County; or
any other governmental agency the Commission determines to be appropriate to further the purposes stated in § 15–302 of this subtitle.

section.text: The Commission is the representative of the State for purposes of:

paragraph.text: acquiring and developing land or other property under this division;
exercising the duties of the State under this division;
complying with § 1(a) and (b) of the Capper–Cramton Act, Public Law 71–284, 46 Stat. 482, for acquiring parklands in the metropolitan district; or
securing funds authorized by the Act or by any other federal, State, or local law.

subsection.text: For the purposes of § 15–302 of this subtitle, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: act in conjunction and cooperation with other governmental units; and
enter into contracts with governmental units.

subsection.text: The Commission may not obligate itself or the metropolitan district for expenditures above the amount of money the Commission has or shall receive from bonds, taxes, donations, contributions, or appropriations under this division.

Within a reasonable time after the Commission makes a request, public officials of the State, Montgomery County, and Prince George’s County shall furnish the Commission with available information required for Commission work.
The Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission shall:

paragraph.text: make available for Commission use the maps, surveys, engineering information, and other records of the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission; and
when requested by the Commission, furnish engineering services and advice at cost.

subsection.text: The conditions and limitations established in this section apply to contracts or amendments to contracts entered into under this subtitle to acquire parkland in the metropolitan district in accordance with § 1(a) and (b) of the Capper–Cramton Act, Public Law 71–284, 46 Stat. 482.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the Commission may amend a contract.
An amendment to a contract shall be ratified by the appropriate county council before the amendment becomes binding on the State, the Commission, or the county.
The Commission may enter into a contract with a governmental unit to:

subparagraph.text: adopt a general or revised plan for the acquisition of parklands in the metropolitan district; and
specify the method to finance the acquisition.

paragraph.text: The appropriate county council shall ratify a contract before the contract becomes binding on the State, the Commission, or the county.
The Commission may enter into a supplemental agreement to a contract or amendment to a contract with a governmental unit in accordance with this subsection.
A supplemental agreement shall:

subparagraph.text: be for the acquisition of specific units of land in the metropolitan district that comprise portions of the general park plan adopted in the contract or amendment to the contract; and
specify the financing for the acquisition.

paragraph.text: A supplemental agreement for a specific unit of land located in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County shall be submitted to the appropriate county council for ratification.
The appropriate county council shall ratify a supplemental agreement if the county finds that:

subparagraph.text: the boundaries of the unit of land to be acquired under the supplemental agreement are in the general park plan adopted by the contract or amendment that the agreement supplements; and
the proceeds from the taxes authorized under the supplemental agreement will allow the Commission to satisfy the obligations of the supplemental agreement, including any interest.

paragraph.text: In determining whether the Commission will be able to meet an obligation with the proceeds of the taxes authorized under the supplemental agreement, the appropriate county council shall:

subparagraph.text: compute the proceeds on the assessable basis of the parts of the metropolitan district lying in the county for the fiscal year in which approval is sought; and
assume that the entire tax imposed will be collected so long as there is an outstanding and unpaid obligation.

paragraph.text: The appropriate county council may ratify the supplemental agreement by simple resolution authorizing the chair of the county council to:

subparagraph.text: endorse the supplemental agreement; and
execute a guarantee in accordance with this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Ratification by the Montgomery County Council is not necessary to approve:

subparagraph.text: contracts or amendments that are not related to the acquisition of a specific unit of parkland; or
supplemental agreements to contracts related only to the acquisition of specific units of parkland.

section.text: In this subtitle, “board” means the merit system board of the Commission.

subsection.text: The Commission shall implement a merit system adopted under this subtitle.
The merit system includes each employee of the Commission, except:

paragraph.text: the commissioners;
the executive director, secretary–treasurer, and general counsel appointed by the Commission under § 15–109 of this article;
a part–time or temporary employee under Subtitle 2 or Subtitle 5 of this title;
in Montgomery County, each position excluded under § 20–204(b) of this article; and
in Prince George’s County:

subparagraph.text: the deputy chief of park police as provided in § 17–305 of this article; and
each director and deputy director as provided in § 20–204(c) of this article.

subsection.text: There is a merit system board of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The board consists of three members appointed by the Commission.
Nothing contained in this subtitle requires that an appointment be made for the purpose of rotating majority membership on the board between residents of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.
The Commission may reappoint a member of the board.
Each member of the board:

subparagraph.text: shall be a resident of the regional district;
shall be knowledgeable and experienced in personnel matters; and
may not be a member or employee of the Commission or the executive director, secretary–treasurer, or general counsel appointed by the Commission under § 15–109 of this article.

paragraph.text: Not more than two members of the board may reside in the same county.

subsection.text: Each member of the board shall be appointed for a term of 4 years and continue to serve until the member’s successor is appointed.
The Commission shall fill each vacancy on the board in the same manner as an original appointment.
The Commission shall designate one member of the board to serve as the chair at the pleasure of the Commission.

section.text: The Commission shall set the compensation of the members of the board as authorized by the Commission’s budget for each fiscal year.
After proper notice and due consideration, the Commission may remove a member of the board for misfeasance, malfeasance, or nonfeasance in office.

subsection.text: The board shall:

paragraph.text: prepare and recommend a compensation plan, a classification plan, and comprehensive regulations governing operation of the merit system; and
submit its recommendations to the Commission for adoption.
The Commission may adopt, disapprove, or modify a recommendation of the board.
If the Commission does not act on a recommendation of the board within 90 days after the date of filing of the recommendation with the Commission, the recommendation is deemed approved.

subsection.text: A recommendation by the board for an amendment to an adopted compensation plan, classification plan, or regulation is subject to subsection (b) of this section.

section.text: The Commission may make available to the board its records, facilities, and staff and consultants necessary to carry out the duties of the board.

subsection.text: If the board determines that the testimony of a witness is essential for the proper consideration of a case before the board, the board may issue a subpoena to the witness to appear at a proceeding the board conducts in accordance with this subtitle.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this section, the board may petition a court of competent jurisdiction to compel compliance with the subpoena.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Confidential employee” means an employee who acts in a confidential capacity with respect to an individual who formulates, determines, or implements management policies in the field of labor–management relations.
“Probationary employee” means a merit system employee during the employee’s initial probationary period following employment.

paragraph.text: The rights granted to Commission merit system employees under this subtitle do not apply to:

subparagraph.text: attorneys in the General Counsel’s office;
confidential employees;
employees who are at grade J or above;
park police officers;
probationary employees; or
supervisors, as defined in § 2(11) of the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. § 152(11).

paragraph.text: Commission employees are divided into four bargaining units consisting of:

subparagraph.text: the office unit that includes office classification titles in which employees are responsible for internal and external communications, recording and retrieving information, and paperwork required in an office;
the professional/technical unit that includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: professional classification titles in which employees have special or theoretical knowledge that usually is acquired through college training, other training that provides comparable knowledge, or work experience;

paraprofessional classification titles in which employees perform, in a supportive role, some of the duties of a professional or technician but that usually require less formal training or experience than those duties performed by those with professional or technical status; and

technical classification titles in which employees have a combination of basic scientific or technical knowledge and manual skill that usually are acquired through specialized postsecondary school education or through equivalent on–the–job training;

subparagraph.text: the service/labor unit that includes classification titles in which employees perform service and maintenance, may operate specialized machinery or heavy equipment, and whose duties contribute to the comfort and convenience of the public or to the upkeep and care of Commission buildings, facilities, or grounds; and

the trade unit that includes classification titles in which employees are required to have a special manual skill and a thorough knowledge of processes that are acquired through on–the–job training, experience, apprenticeship, or other formal training programs.

paragraph.text: A bargaining unit may not be defined by county boundaries.

If an employee organization is certified to represent more than one bargaining unit, the Commission shall negotiate a single contract with that organization covering all employees the organization represents.

subsection.text: The Commission shall recognize the right of an employee organization, certified under this subtitle as the exclusive representative of a bargaining unit, to represent the employees in the bargaining unit in collective bargaining and in the settlement of grievances.
An employee organization certified as the exclusive representative of a bargaining unit shall:

paragraph.text: serve as the sole bargaining agent for the unit in collective bargaining; and
represent all employees in the bargaining unit fairly, without discrimination, and without regard to whether an employee is a member of the employee organization.

subsection.text: An employee organization meets the requirements of subsection (b)(2) of this section if the employee organization’s actions with respect to employees who are members of the employee organization and employees who are not members of the employee organization are not arbitrary, discriminatory, or in bad faith.
After a public hearing on the appointment, the Commission shall appoint an experienced neutral third party to serve as labor relations administrator for an initial term of 1 year.

After the term of the labor relations administrator appointed under subsection (a) of this section expires, the exclusive representative and the Commission shall appoint a labor relations administrator for a 2–year term from a list of five nominees on whom they have agreed.

After the term of the labor relations administrator appointed under subsection (a) of this section expires and after a public hearing on the appointment, if no exclusive representative has been certified under this section, the Commission shall appoint the next labor relations administrator for a term not exceeding 1 year.
A labor relations administrator is eligible for reappointment.
An employee organization that is certified or that seeks certification as an exclusive representative under this subtitle shall submit to the labor relations administrator:

paragraph.text: a copy of the employee organization’s constitution and bylaws; and
any change in the constitution or bylaws.

subsection.text: The constitution or bylaws shall include:

paragraph.text: a pledge that the employee organization accepts members without regard to age, marital status, national origin, race, religion, disability, sexual orientation, or gender;
the right of members to participate in the affairs of the employee organization;
procedures for periodic elections of officers by secret ballot;
fair procedures governing disciplinary actions;
procedures for the accurate accounting of income and expenditures;
a requirement that a certified annual financial report be produced; and
the right of members to inspect the organization’s accounts.

subsection.text: The labor relations administrator shall conduct an election for an exclusive representative after:

paragraph.text: an employee organization demonstrates, by petition, that at least 30% of the eligible employees in a bargaining unit support representation by an exclusive representative for collective bargaining; or
an employee or an employee organization demonstrates, by petition, that at least 30% of the eligible employees in a bargaining unit no longer support the current exclusive representative.

At least 30 days before an election under subsection (a) of this section, the labor relations administrator shall obtain from the Commission and provide to the employee organization a list of the names, addresses, and telephone numbers of every employee in the bargaining unit.

The provision of a list under this subsection by the Commission, the labor relations administrator, or a Commission official, employee, or other agent does not constitute a violation of § 10–617(e) of the State Government Article or any State or local law.

subsection.text: Elections shall be conducted by secret ballot containing:

paragraph.text: the name of each employee organization that submits a valid petition requiring an election;
the name of any other employee organization supported by a petition signed by at least 10% of the eligible employees in the bargaining unit; and
an option for no representation.

If a petition described in subsection (a)(1) of this section is submitted at the same time that a petition described in subsection (a)(2) of this section is submitted, one election shall be held to determine which employee organization, if any, shall be the exclusive representative.
The ballot shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name of the current certified employee organization;
the name of the petitioning employee organization; and
an option for no representation.

paragraph.text: If none of the choices on the ballot receives a majority of the votes cast, the labor relations administrator shall hold a runoff election.
In the runoff election, the ballot shall contain the two choices that received the highest number of votes cast in the initial election.

subsection.text: After the election, the labor relations administrator shall certify the employee organization that received a majority of the votes cast as the exclusive representative.

If the petitioning employee organization is certified as the result of an election held under subsection (d) of this section, that employee organization shall be treated as a successor in interest and party to any collective bargaining agreement to which the previous employee organization was a party.
The Commission and the employee organization shall share equally the costs of the election procedures.

paragraph.text: Elections may not be conducted:

subparagraph.text: within 1 year after the date of a valid election under this section; or
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, during the term of a collective bargaining agreement.

paragraph.text: During the term of a collective bargaining agreement, a petition for an election may be filed only during November of the fiscal year in which the agreement expires.

subsection.text: If the Commission and an employee organization dispute the eligibility of an employee in a bargaining unit, the dispute shall be submitted to the labor relations administrator.

The labor relations administrator shall hold evidentiary hearings at which the Commission and interested employee organizations shall have the opportunity to present testimony, documentary and other evidence, and arguments.
The decision of the labor relations administrator is final.
The Commission and the employee organization shall share equally the costs of the hearings.
The Commission and an employee organization certified as exclusive representative shall meet and engage in collective bargaining in good faith regarding:

paragraph.text: salary and wages, including the percentage of the increase in the salary and wages budget that will be devoted to merit increments and cash awards, provided that salaries and wages shall be uniform for all employees in the same classification;
pension and other retirement benefits for active employees;
employee benefits such as insurance, leave, holidays, and vacations;
hours and working conditions;
orderly processing and settlement of grievances concerning the interpretation and implementation of a collective bargaining agreement that may include:

subparagraph.text: binding third party arbitration, under which the arbitrator may not amend, add to, or subtract from the provisions of the collective bargaining agreement; and
provisions for the exclusivity of forum;

paragraph.text: matters affecting the health and safety of employees; and
the effect on employees of the exercise of the Commission’s rights and responsibilities under § 16–213 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: This section does not require the Commission or the employee organization to agree to any proposal or to make any concession.

subparagraph.text: Collective bargaining may not begin later than September 1 before the beginning of a fiscal year for which an agreement has not been reached between the Commission and the exclusive representative.
Collective bargaining shall conclude on or before the following February 1.

paragraph.text: During the period between the dates set in paragraph (1)(i) and (ii) of this subsection, the parties shall negotiate in good faith.

subsection.text: If a party to the collective bargaining considers a bargaining proposal to violate the rights and responsibilities of the Commission under § 16–213 of this subtitle or the rights of Commission employees under § 16–216 of this subtitle or otherwise to violate this subtitle, the party may petition the labor relations administrator for a determination of whether the bargaining proposal constitutes a negotiability dispute that violates this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The procedure for resolving a negotiability dispute shall follow the process for reviewing unfair labor practice charges.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the labor relations administrator may shorten the time periods or order any appropriate expedited procedure.

subsection.text: The labor relations administrator may order a party to withdraw all or part of a bargaining proposal that violates this subtitle.

Unless petitioned to judicial review on the basis that the decision or order is arbitrary, is capricious, or exceeds the authority of a party, any decision reached and order issued under this subtitle is final.

paragraph.text: If the parties have not reached an agreement on or before December 1 on a collective bargaining agreement that would become effective the following July 1, the parties jointly shall appoint a mediator–arbitrator.
If the parties are unable to agree on a mediator–arbitrator, the labor relations administrator shall appoint the mediator–arbitrator on or before December 7.
Notwithstanding appointment of the mediator–arbitrator, this section does not require mediation–arbitration to begin before the date set forth in subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: During the course of the collective bargaining:

paragraph.text: either party may declare an impasse and request the services of the mediator–arbitrator; or
the parties jointly may request the services of a mediator–arbitrator before an impasse is declared.

subsection.text: If the mediator–arbitrator finds in the mediator–arbitrator’s sole discretion that the parties are at a bona fide impasse or on February 1, whichever occurs earlier, the mediator–arbitrator shall direct the parties to submit:

paragraph.text: a joint memorandum listing all items to which the parties previously agreed; and
a separate memorandum of each party’s last final offer presented in negotiations on all items to which the parties previously did not agree.
On or before February 10, the mediator–arbitrator shall hold a closed hearing on the parties’ proposals at a time, date, and place selected by the mediator–arbitrator.
Each party shall submit evidence or make oral and written arguments in support of the party’s last final offer.
The mediator–arbitrator may not open the hearing to a person that is not a party to the mediation–arbitration.

On or before February 15, the mediator–arbitrator shall issue a report selecting the final offer submitted by the party that the mediator–arbitrator determines to be more reasonable when viewed as a whole.
In determining which offer is more reasonable, the mediator–arbitrator:

subparagraph.text: may consider only:

sub-subparagraph.text: past collective bargaining agreements between the parties, including the past bargaining history that led to the agreement or the precollective bargaining history of employee wages, hours, benefits, and other working conditions;
a comparison of wages, hours, benefits, and conditions of employment of similar employees of other public employers in the Washington metropolitan area and the State;
a comparison of wages, hours, benefits, and conditions of employment of similar employees of private employers in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County;
the public interest and welfare;
the ability of the Commission to finance any economic adjustments required under the proposed agreement;
the effects of any economic adjustments on the standard of public services normally provided by the Commission; and

the annual increase or decrease in consumer prices for all items as reflected in the most recent Consumer Price Index – Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers (“CPI–W”) for the Washington–Baltimore metropolitan area; and

subparagraph.text: shall consider all items on which the parties agreed before the mediation–arbitration began to be integrated into each offer.

The mediator–arbitrator may not receive or consider the history of collective bargaining relating to the immediate dispute, including any offers of settlement not contained in the offer submitted to the mediator–arbitrator.
The mediator–arbitrator may not compromise or alter the final offer that the mediator–arbitrator selects.

Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the offer selected by the mediator–arbitrator, as integrated with the items on which the parties previously agreed, shall be the final agreement between the Commission and the exclusive representative without ratification by the parties.
The economic provisions of the final agreement are subject to funding by the Montgomery County Council and Prince George’s County Council.
The Commission shall request funds in the Commission’s final budget from the county councils for all economic provisions of the final agreement.

paragraph.text: The parties shall execute an agreement incorporating the final agreement, including arbitration awards and all issues agreed to under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commission and the employee organization shall share equally the costs of the mediator–arbitrator’s services.
A mediator may be used in the collective bargaining process whenever:

paragraph.text: the Commission and the employee organization agree to mediation; or
an impasse results, and the Commission or the employee organization requests mediation.
The mediator shall be selected jointly by the Commission and the employee organization from a list supplied by the American Arbitration Association or the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
If the Commission and the employee organization are unable to agree on the selection of a mediator, the labor relations administrator shall select the mediator.

subsection.text: The Commission and the employee organization shall share equally the costs of mediation.
The Commission and an employee organization certified as exclusive representative of a bargaining unit shall execute a collective bargaining agreement incorporating all matters agreed.
If a collective bargaining agreement provides for a grievance procedure, that grievance procedure shall be the sole procedure for employees in the bargaining unit.
The collective bargaining agreement may include an agency shop or other union security provision.
The collective bargaining agreement supersedes any conflicting regulation or administrative policy of the Commission.
A single–year or multiple–year collective bargaining agreement shall expire at the close of the appropriate fiscal year.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a collective bargaining agreement shall be effective on the approval of the Commission and the membership of the employee organization representing the bargaining unit.
The economic requirements of a collective bargaining agreement shall be effective on approval by the Montgomery County Council and Prince George’s County Council.

subsection.text: The Commission shall include in its annual proposed operating budget submitted to the county executives of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County adequate funding to carry out a collective bargaining agreement.

Unless the Montgomery County Council and Prince George’s County Council approve the Commission’s budget so as to approve the terms of the collective bargaining agreement, the Commission and the employee organization, within 5 days after the annual joint county council budget meeting under § 18–106 of this article, shall reopen the negotiated agreement and bargain with respect to the provisions of the agreement not approved by the county councils.

If a provision of a collective bargaining agreement is ruled invalid or is not funded by Montgomery County or Prince George’s County, the remainder of the agreement remains in effect unless reopened under subsection (b) of this section.
This subtitle and any agreement made under it may not impair the rights and responsibilities of the Commission to:

paragraph.text: determine the overall budget and mission of the Commission;
maintain and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of operations;
determine the services to be rendered and the operations to be performed;
determine the location of facilities and the overall organizational structure, methods, processes, means, job classifications, and personnel by which operations are to be conducted;
direct and supervise employees;
hire, select, and establish the standards governing promotion of employees and classify positions;
relieve employees from duties because of lack of work or funds or when the Commission determines continued work would be inefficient or nonproductive;
take actions to carry out the missions of government in emergency situations;
transfer and schedule employees;
determine the size, grades, and composition of the workforce;
set the standards of productivity and technology;
establish employee performance standards and evaluate and assign employees, except that evaluation and assignment procedures shall be a subject for bargaining;
establish and implement systems for awarding outstanding service increments, extraordinary performance awards, and other merit awards;
introduce new or improved technology, research, development, and services;
control and regulate the use of machinery, equipment, and other property and facilities of the Commission, subject to § 16–207(a)(6) of this subtitle;
maintain internal security standards;
create, alter, combine, contract out, or abolish any job classification, operation, department, unit, or other division or service;
suspend, discharge, or otherwise discipline employees for cause, subject to the grievance procedure set forth in a collective bargaining agreement; and

adopt and enforce policies and regulations necessary to carry out this section and all other managerial functions that are not inconsistent with federal or State law or the terms of a collective bargaining agreement.

subsection.text: The Commission may not sign a contract that will displace employees unless the Commission gives written notice to the certified representative at least 90 days before signing the contract or within a different period of time agreed to by the parties.
The Commission may not:

paragraph.text: interfere with, coerce, or restrain an employee in the exercise of the employee’s rights under this subtitle;
dominate, interfere with, or assist in the formation, administration, or existence of an employee organization or contribute financial assistance or other support to an employee organization;
encourage or discourage membership in an employee organization by discriminating against the employee through hiring, tenure, promotion or demotion, or other conditions of employment;
discharge or discriminate against an employee because the employee has signed or filed an affidavit, petition, or complaint or given any information or testimony under this subtitle; or

refuse to bargain in good faith with an employee organization that is certified as the exclusive representative of a bargaining unit over any subject of bargaining or refuse to participate in good faith in the mediation, fact–finding, or grievance procedure under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subsection (a)(2) of this section does not prohibit the Commission from allowing employees to negotiate or to confer with the Commission over labor matters during work hours without the loss of pay or time.
An employee organization may not:

paragraph.text: interfere with, coerce, or restrain an employee in the exercise of the employee’s rights under this subtitle;
cause or attempt to cause the Commission to discriminate against an employee in the exercise of the employee’s rights under this subtitle;
coerce, discipline, fine, or attempt to coerce a member of an employee organization as punishment or reprisal;
coerce, discipline, fine, or attempt to coerce a member of an employee organization for the purpose of impeding the member’s work performance;
refuse to negotiate in good faith with the Commission as required by this subtitle; or
fail or refuse to cooperate in impasse procedures and impasse decisions as required by this subtitle.

subsection.text: Only an eligible employee may file an unfair labor charge against an employee organization for a violation of subsection (a)(3) or (4) of this section.
Employees of the Commission shall retain the right to:

paragraph.text: form, join, or assist an employee organization;
bargain collectively through a representative that the employees have chosen;
engage in other lawful concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining; or
refrain from an activity described in this subsection.

subsection.text: An employee may only present a grievance arising under a collective bargaining agreement to the Commission through the employee organization certified as the exclusive representative for the bargaining unit.
In this section, “strike” means the action of an employee, in concert with others, to:

paragraph.text: refuse to report to work;
stop or slow down work; or

abstain wholly or partly from the full, faithful, and proper performance of duties when the object is to induce, influence, or coerce a change in the terms, conditions, rights, or privileges of employment.

subsection.text: A Commission employee, a group of Commission employees, or an employee organization may not engage in, induce, initiate, or ratify a strike by Commission employees.
If a strike occurs, a court of competent jurisdiction may enjoin the strike on request of the Commission.
An employee may not receive compensation from the Commission while the employee is engaged in a strike.

paragraph.text: If an employee engages in, induces, initiates, or ratifies a strike, the Commission may take appropriate disciplinary action against the employee, including suspension or discharge.

If disciplinary action is taken and appealed, the labor relations administrator shall hold a hearing on the disciplinary action at which the Commission, the employee, and any interested employee organization may present evidence and argument.

If after a hearing an employee organization certified as an exclusive representative is found by the labor relations administrator to have assisted, authorized, or initiated a strike involving the refusal of Commission employees to report for work, the labor relations administrator shall revoke the certification of the employee organization for 1 year after the end of the strike.

If after a hearing an employee organization certified as an exclusive representative is found by the labor relations administrator to have assisted, authorized, or initiated any other type of strike, the labor relations administrator may revoke the certification of the employee organization for up to 1 year after the end of the strike.

subsection.text: It is an unfair labor practice for the Commission or an employee organization certified as an exclusive representative of a bargaining unit to violate the rights of a Commission employee under this subtitle.
Within 30 business days after the alleged violation, the party charging an unfair labor practice shall submit the charge in writing to the party alleged to have committed the unfair labor practice.

Within 15 days after an unfair labor practice charge is submitted, the Commission and the employee organization shall request the labor relations administrator to hold a hearing and determine whether an unfair labor practice has occurred.
The labor relations administrator shall:

paragraph.text: issue a finding of facts and conclusion of law;
order the party found to have committed the unfair labor practice to cease and desist from the prohibited practice; and

order all relief necessary to remedy the violation of this subtitle and to otherwise make whole any injured employee or employee organization or the Commission, if injured, including reinstatement, restitution, back pay, or other remedy as necessary to restore the employee, the employee organization, or the Commission to the position or condition it would have been in but for the violation.

subsection.text: The labor relations administrator may not order punitive damages, consequential damages, damages for emotional distress, pain, and suffering, or attorney’s fees for purposes of satisfying subsection (d)(3) of this section.
If the labor relations administrator finds that the party charged has not committed an unfair labor practice, the labor relations administrator shall issue an order dismissing the charges.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the decision of the labor relations administrator is final.
A party may seek judicial review of the decision on the basis that the decision is arbitrary, capricious, or exceeds the authority of the labor relations administrator.

subsection.text: The Commission and the employee organization shall share equally the costs of any unfair labor practice proceeding.

If the party found to have committed the unfair labor practice fails or refuses to comply with the decision of the labor relations administrator wholly or partly, the charging party may file an action to enforce the order with the circuit court of the county in which any of the involved employees work.
This section applies to the expression of any personal view, argument, or opinion or the making of any personal statement that:

subparagraph.text: publicizes the fact of a representational election and encourages employees to exercise their right to vote in the election;
corrects the record with respect to any false or misleading statement made by any person; or
informs employees of the Commission’s policy relating to labor–management relations and representation;

paragraph.text: does not contain a threat of reprisal or force, or a promise of benefit; and
was not coerced.

subsection.text: The expression of any personal view, argument, opinion, or statement described in subsection (a) of this section does not constitute:

paragraph.text: an unfair labor practice under this subtitle; or
grounds for setting aside any election conducted under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Arbitration” means a procedure by which the parties involved in a grievance submit their differences to an impartial third party for a final and binding decision.
“Bargaining unit” means all employees except a confidential employee.

“Collective bargaining” means the performance by the exclusive representative of the bargaining unit and the Commission of their mutual obligations to negotiate in good faith with respect to wages, hours, and other terms and conditions of employment.
“Collective bargaining agreement” means a written contract between the Commission and an employee organization implementing collective bargaining.
“Confidential employee” means an employee who:

paragraph.text: acts in a confidential capacity and formulates and effectuates Commission policies that relate to collective bargaining with employees; or
has access to confidential information not generally available to employees regarding the formulation and effectuation of Commission policies that relate to collective bargaining.

subsection.text: “Employee” means a police officer who is ranked as a sergeant or below employed by the Commission.
“Employee organization” means an organization that has as one of its primary purposes representing employees in collective bargaining.
“Exclusive representative” means an employee organization that has been certified by the Labor Commissioner as representing the employees in the bargaining unit.

“Grievance” means a dispute concerning the application or interpretation of the terms of a collective bargaining agreement or the regulations of the Commission that relate to terms and conditions of employment.

“Impasse” means failure of the Commission and an exclusive representative to enter into a collective bargaining agreement at least 30 days before the day on which the Commission’s budget is due for submission to the Montgomery County Council and the Prince George’s County Council.
“Labor Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry or the Commissioner’s designee.
“Mediation” means assistance by an impartial third party to reconcile a dispute arising out of collective bargaining through interpretation, suggestion, and advice.
“Strike” means the action:

paragraph.text: of an employee, in concert with others, to:

subparagraph.text: refuse to report to work;
be willfully absent from the employee’s position;
stop or slow down work; or
abstain wholly or partially from the proper performance of duties; and

paragraph.text: taken for the purpose of inducing, influencing, or coercing a change in wages, hours, or other terms and conditions of employment.

subsection.text: The Commission shall recognize the right of an employee organization, certified under this subtitle as the exclusive representative of the bargaining unit, to represent the employees in the bargaining unit in collective bargaining and in the settlement of grievances.
An employee organization certified as the exclusive representative of a bargaining unit shall:

paragraph.text: serve as the sole bargaining agent for the bargaining unit in collective bargaining; and
represent all employees in the bargaining unit fairly, without discrimination, and without regard to whether an employee is a member of the employee organization.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commission and the exclusive representative jointly shall appoint an experienced neutral party, from a list of five nominees on whom they have agreed, to serve as labor relations administrator for a 2–year term.
If an exclusive representative has not been certified to represent employees of the bargaining unit, the Commission shall appoint the labor relations administrator for a term not exceeding 1 year.

subsection.text: A labor relations administrator:

paragraph.text: is eligible for reappointment; and
may be the same individual as the labor relations administrator appointed under § 16–203 of this title.

subsection.text: An employee organization that is certified or that seeks certification as an exclusive representative under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: file with the Commission and the Labor Commissioner a copy of the employee organization’s constitution and bylaws; and
report promptly any change in the constitution or bylaws.

subsection.text: The constitution or bylaws shall include:

paragraph.text: a pledge that the employee organization accepts members without regard to age, race, gender, religion, marital status, or national origin;
the right of members to participate in the affairs of the employee organization;
procedures for periodic elections of officers by secret ballot;
fair procedures governing disciplinary actions;
procedures for the accurate accounting of income and expenditures;
a requirement that an annual financial report be produced; and
the right of members to inspect the employee organization’s accounts.

subsection.text: An employee organization shall file an annual report with the Commission and the Labor Commissioner.
The annual report shall include a financial report that:

paragraph.text: is signed by the president and treasurer or corresponding principal officers of the employee organization; and
contains information in detail sufficient to accurately disclose the financial condition and operations of the employee organization.

subsection.text: An employee organization that has not filed an annual report or the constitution and bylaws of which do not conform to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section may not be or remain certified as an exclusive representative under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A petition for an election of an exclusive representative may be submitted to the Labor Commissioner by:

subparagraph.text: an employee organization that demonstrates that at least 30% of the eligible employees in the bargaining unit support representation by an exclusive representative for collective bargaining;

an employee, a group of employees, or an employee organization that demonstrates that at least 35% of the eligible employees in the bargaining unit certify that a majority of the eligible employees in the bargaining unit no longer support the current exclusive representative; or

subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commission, demonstrating that one or more employee organizations have presented to it a claim, supported by substantial proof, to be certified as the exclusive representative.
