paragraph.text: The Labor Commissioner may accept a petition from the Commission only if the Labor Commissioner finds, on investigation of the petition, that a valid question of representation exists.

subsection.text: Elections shall be conducted by:

paragraph.text: the Labor Commissioner; and
secret ballot.

subsection.text: Each ballot shall contain:

paragraph.text: the name of each employee organization that submits a valid petition;
the name of any other employee organization supported by a valid petition signed by more than 10% of the eligible employees in the bargaining unit; and
an option for no representation.
If none of the choices on the ballot receives a majority of the votes cast, the Labor Commissioner shall conduct a runoff election.
In the runoff election, the ballot shall contain the two choices receiving the highest number of votes cast in the initial election.
After the election, the Labor Commissioner shall certify the employee organization that received a majority of the votes cast as the exclusive representative.
An employee organization may not be certified as an exclusive representative except as provided in this subtitle.

subsection.text: Elections may not be conducted within 2 years after a valid election held under this section.

section.text: Any dispute about the eligibility of an employee in the bargaining unit shall be submitted to the labor relations administrator for final and binding arbitration.

subsection.text: The Commission and the exclusive representative of the bargaining unit shall engage in collective bargaining.
Subsection (a) of this section does not require the Commission or the exclusive representative to agree to any proposal or to make any concession.
Collective bargaining may include negotiations about the terms of employee retirement systems but not about the hiring practices of the Commission.

subparagraph.text: Collective bargaining may not begin later than September 1 before the beginning of a fiscal year for which a collective bargaining agreement has not been reached between the Commission and the exclusive representative.
Collective bargaining shall conclude on or before the following February 4 or any later date determined by mutual agreement of the parties.

paragraph.text: During the period between the dates set in paragraph (1)(i) and (ii) of this subsection, the parties shall negotiate in good faith.

If a party to the collective bargaining considers a bargaining proposal to violate the responsibilities of the Commission under § 16–311(a) of this subtitle or the rights of employees under § 16–314 of this subtitle or to otherwise violate this subtitle, the party may petition the labor relations administrator for a determination of whether the bargaining proposal constitutes a negotiability dispute that violates this subtitle.

The labor relations administrator shall resolve a negotiability dispute in accordance with the procedures for resolving an unfair labor practice charge, except that the labor relations administrator may shorten the time periods or order any appropriate expedited procedures.
The labor relations administrator may order a party to withdraw all or part of a bargaining proposal that violates this subtitle.

Unless petitioned to judicial review on the basis that the decision or order is arbitrary, is capricious, or exceeds the authority of a party, any decision made or order issued under this section is final.
A mediator may be used during collective bargaining:

subparagraph.text: on request of both parties; or
if an impasse exists, on request of either party.

paragraph.text: The mediator shall be selected by the parties from a list supplied by the American Arbitration Association or the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

If the parties to collective bargaining have not reached an agreement on or before December 1 or any later date determined by mutual agreement of the parties on a collective bargaining agreement that would succeed the existing collective bargaining agreement:

subparagraph.text: either party may declare a bargaining impasse; and
the parties jointly shall appoint an arbitrator.

paragraph.text: If the parties are unable to agree on an arbitrator, the labor relations administrator shall appoint the arbitrator on or before December 7 or any later date determined by mutual agreement of the parties.
Notwithstanding appointment of the arbitrator, this subtitle does not require arbitration to begin before February 1 or any later date determined by mutual agreement of the parties.

subsection.text: On or before February 1 or any later date determined by mutual agreement of the parties, the arbitrator shall direct the parties to submit:

paragraph.text: a joint memorandum listing all items to which the parties previously agreed; and
a separate memorandum of each party’s last final offer presented in negotiations on all items to which the parties previously did not agree.

On or before February 10 or any later date determined by mutual agreement of the parties, the arbitrator shall hold a closed hearing on the parties’ proposals at a time, date, and place selected by the arbitrator.
Each party shall submit evidence or make oral and written arguments in support of the party’s last final offer.
The arbitrator may not open the hearing to a person that is not a party to the arbitration.

On or before February 15 or any later date determined by mutual agreement of the parties, the arbitrator shall issue a report selecting the last final offer submitted by the parties that the arbitrator determines to be more reasonable when viewed as a whole.
In determining which last final offer is more reasonable, the arbitrator may consider only:

subparagraph.text: past collective bargaining agreements between the parties, including the past bargaining history that led to the collective bargaining agreement or the precollective bargaining history of employee wages, hours, benefits, and other working conditions;
a comparison of wages, hours, benefits, and other conditions of employment of police officers in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County;
the public interest and welfare;
the ability of the Commission to finance any economic adjustments required under the proposed collective bargaining agreement; and
the effects of any economic adjustments on the standard of public services normally provided by the Commission.

paragraph.text: In determining which last final offer is more reasonable, the arbitrator shall consider all items on which the parties agreed before the arbitration began to be integrated into each offer.
The arbitrator may not:

subparagraph.text: receive or consider the history of collective bargaining relating to the immediate dispute, including any offers of settlement not contained in the last final offer submitted to the arbitrator; or
compromise or alter the last final offer that the arbitrator selects.

paragraph.text: Subject to § 16–310(a) of this subtitle, the last final offer selected by the arbitrator, as integrated with the items on which the parties previously agreed, shall be the final agreement between the Commission and the exclusive representative without ratification by the parties.
The parties shall execute a collective bargaining agreement incorporating the final agreement, including arbitration awards and all issues agreed to under this section.

subsection.text: The Commission and the exclusive representative shall share equally the costs of the arbitrator’s services.
The Commission and the exclusive representative shall execute a collective bargaining agreement incorporating all matters agreed.
A collective bargaining agreement may include a provision for:

paragraph.text: dues and maintenance or service fees paid by payroll deduction; and
the arbitration of grievances arising under the collective bargaining agreement.

subsection.text: The collective bargaining agreement supersedes any conflicting rule, regulation, or administrative policy of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The economic provisions of a final collective bargaining agreement are subject to funding by the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

The Commission shall request funds in the Commission’s final budget from the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County for all economic provisions of a final collective bargaining agreement.

subsection.text: If the request for funds necessary to implement the collective bargaining agreement is reduced, modified, or rejected by the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, the Commission or the exclusive representative, within 5 days after final budget action by the county councils, shall reopen the negotiated collective bargaining agreement and bargain with respect to the provisions of the collective bargaining agreement not approved by the county councils.

If a provision of a collective bargaining agreement is ruled invalid or is not funded by Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, the remainder of the collective bargaining agreement remains in effect unless reopened under subsection (b) of this section.
This subtitle and any collective bargaining agreement made under it may not impair the rights and responsibilities of the Commission to:

paragraph.text: determine the overall budget and mission of the Commission;
maintain and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of operations;
determine the services to be rendered and the operations to be performed;
determine the location of facilities and the overall organizational structure, methods, processes, means, job classifications, and personnel by which operations are to be performed;
direct and supervise employees;
hire, select, and establish the standards governing promotion of employees and classify positions;
relieve employees from duties because of lack of work or funds or when the Commission determines continued work would be inefficient or nonproductive;
transfer and schedule employees;
determine the size, grades, and composition of the workforce;
set the standards of productivity and technology;
establish employee performance standards and evaluate and assign employees, except that evaluation and assignment procedures shall be a subject for collective bargaining;
establish and implement systems for awarding outstanding service increments, extraordinary performance awards, and other merit awards;
introduce new or improved technology, research development, and services;
control and regulate the use of machinery, equipment, and other property and facilities of the Commission, subject to negotiation related to matters affecting the health and safety of employees;
maintain internal security standards;
create, alter, combine, contract out, or abolish any job classification, operation, department, unit, or other division or service, subject to subsection (b) of this section;
suspend, discharge, or otherwise discipline employees for cause, subject to the grievance procedure set forth in a collective bargaining agreement; and

adopt and enforce regulations and policies necessary to carry out this section and all other managerial functions that are not inconsistent with federal or State law or the terms of a collective bargaining agreement.

subsection.text: The Commission may not sign a contract that will displace employees in the bargaining unit unless the Commission gives written notice to the exclusive representative of the bargaining unit at least 90 days before signing the contract or within a different period of time agreed to by the parties.

This section may not preclude or impair collective bargaining as to any subject matter included in any written collective bargaining agreement made between the Commission and the exclusive representative of the bargaining unit on or before December 31, 2001.
The Commission, its agents, or its representatives may not:

paragraph.text: interfere with, intimidate, restrain, coerce, or discriminate against an employee in the exercise of the employee’s rights under this subtitle;
dominate, interfere with, or assist in the formation, administration, or existence of an employee organization or contribute financial or other support to an employee organization;
encourage or discourage membership in an employee organization by discriminating against the employee through hiring, tenure, promotion or demotion, or any term or condition of employment;
discharge or otherwise discriminate against an employee because the employee has signed or filed an affidavit, petition, or complaint or given any information or testimony under this subtitle;
refuse to engage in collective bargaining in good faith with the exclusive representative of the bargaining unit as required by § 16–307(d)(2) of this subtitle; or
fail to comply with any provision of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subsection (a)(2) of this section does not prohibit the Commission from allowing employees to negotiate or confer with an employee organization during work hours without loss of pay or time.

section.text: An employee or an employee organization or its agents or representatives may not:

paragraph.text: interfere with, intimidate, restrain, coerce, or discriminate against an employee in the exercise of the employee’s rights under this subtitle;
cause or attempt to cause the Commission to discriminate against an employee in violation of § 16–312(a)(3) of this subtitle;

refuse to engage in collective bargaining in good faith with the Commission as required by § 16–307(d)(2) of this subtitle if the employee organization has been certified as the exclusive representative of employees in the bargaining unit in accordance with § 16–305 of this subtitle;
engage in a strike in violation of § 16–315(a) of this subtitle; or
fail to comply with any provision of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Employees may:

paragraph.text: form, join, or assist an employee organization;
bargain collectively through a representative that the employees have chosen;
engage in other lawful concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining; and
refrain from any of the activities described in this subsection.
An employee or group of employees in the bargaining unit may:

subparagraph.text: present to the Commission at any time a grievance arising under a collective bargaining agreement; and
have the grievance adjusted without the intervention of the exclusive representative of the bargaining unit.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall hear the grievance and participate in its adjustment.
An adjustment may not be inconsistent with the collective bargaining agreement.
The Commission shall give prompt notice of all adjustments to the exclusive representative.

subsection.text: Employees may not engage in a strike.
If a strike occurs, a court of competent jurisdiction may enjoin the strike on request of the Commission.
An employee may not receive compensation from the Commission while the employee is engaged in a strike.

paragraph.text: If an employee organization certified as an exclusive representative engages in a strike, the Labor Commissioner shall revoke its certification.

An employee organization that is decertified under paragraph (1) of this subsection or any other employee organization that engages in a strike is ineligible to be certified as an exclusive representative for 1 year after the end of the strike.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not preclude the Commission from entering into a collective bargaining agreement with an exclusive representative that requires an employee, as a condition of employment, to pay a maintenance or service fee as a contribution towards the cost of the negotiation and administration of the collective bargaining agreement.
A maintenance or service fee under subsection (a) of this section may not exceed the annual dues paid to the exclusive representative.
Before the Commission discharges an employee who fails to pay a maintenance or service fee, it shall give the employee:

paragraph.text: written notice of the delinquent payment; and
adequate time to correct the delinquency.

subsection.text: If the Commission and an employee are unable to resolve any issue relating to the payment of a maintenance or service fee, the issue shall be submitted to an umpire in accordance with § 16–317 of this subtitle.
Any charge that the Commission, an employee, or an employee organization has engaged in an unfair labor practice shall:

paragraph.text: be in writing;
state concisely and simply the facts that are asserted or, if the facts cannot be stated in detail, the issues that are involved; and
be served personally on the party alleged to have engaged in the unfair labor practice within 180 days after the alleged unfair labor practice occurred.

subsection.text: If the party charging an unfair labor practice and the party charged are unable to resolve the matter, the charge shall be submitted to an umpire.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall appoint the umpire from a list of five nominees agreed on by the exclusive representative and the Executive Director of the Commission.
The umpire shall serve for a 2–year term and is eligible for reappointment.

subsection.text: The umpire may not be otherwise employed by the Commission or the exclusive representative.
The power of the umpire is exclusive.
The technical rules of evidence do not apply.
The umpire:

paragraph.text: shall investigate and attempt to resolve, as provided in this subtitle, a charge of engaging in an unfair labor practice;

shall defer to any valid grievance procedure adopted by the Commission and the exclusive representative for the resolution of disputes subject to the grievance procedure, unless the deferral would result in a violation of the purposes of this subtitle;
shall defer to the Law Enforcement Officers’ Bill of Rights for the resolution of disputes subject to that law;
shall recognize fundamental distinctions between private and public employment; and
may not regard State or federal law that is applicable to private employment as controlling precedent.
Based on the preponderance of the evidence, the umpire shall submit written findings of fact and conclusions of law to the parties within 40 days after the day on which the umpire is appointed.
If the umpire determines that a party named in the charges has engaged or is engaging in an unfair labor practice, the umpire shall issue an order requiring the party to cease the practice.
An order may:

subparagraph.text: include any remedy, including reinstatement of an employee with or without back pay;
require periodic reports on the extent to which the party found to have engaged in an unfair labor practice has complied with the order; and
be designed to prevent future unfair labor practices.

paragraph.text: Within 30 days after the issuance of a final order, a party who is aggrieved by a final decision of an umpire may file a petition for judicial review of the decision with the Circuit Court for Montgomery County or the Circuit Court for Prince George’s County.

The circuit court may not consider evidence that was not offered in the proceeding before the umpire unless the court determines that the failure to offer the evidence should be excused because of extraordinary circumstances.
The circuit court may not overturn the umpire’s decision unless the court finds that the umpire’s decision is not supported by substantial evidence.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise provided by written agreement, the parties shall share equally the costs of the umpire’s services.

paragraph.text: A party charging an unfair labor practice may petition the Circuit Court for Montgomery County or the Circuit Court for Prince George’s County for enforcement of an order of an umpire.

Unless a petition for judicial review has been filed in accordance with subsection (i) of this section, a petition for enforcement of an order of an umpire may not be used to obtain judicial review of the final decision of the umpire.

section.text: If the expression does not contain a threat of reprisal or force, a promise of benefit, or a misrepresentation of fact, an expression of any view, argument, or opinion, whether oral or in written, printed, graphic, or visual form, does not constitute an unfair labor practice under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Adversely affect” means to:

subparagraph.text: eliminate more than two employee positions assigned to perform bargaining unit work if the positions are:

sub-subparagraph.text: authorized;
fully funded; and

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: vacant for less than 90 days; or
occupied at the time the Commission solicits a service contract; or

subparagraph.text: permanently and involuntarily reduce:

sub-subparagraph.text: below the number of hours for regular full–time employment for more than five employees currently assigned to a regular full–time work schedule to perform bargaining unit work when the Commission solicits a service contract;
the pay grade for more than five employees currently assigned to a regular full–time work schedule to perform bargaining unit work when the Commission solicits a service contract; or

the base pay or fringe benefits otherwise applicable to a job classification covering more than five employees currently assigned on a full–time basis to perform bargaining unit work when the Commission solicits a service contract.

paragraph.text: “Adversely affect” does not include an action the Commission takes in accordance with:

subparagraph.text: a bona fide disciplinary proceeding;
an applicable collective bargaining agreement in accordance with Subtitle 2 of this title; or
a reallocation or reassignment to another bargaining unit work or other duties that does not result in a change in job classification or grade.

subsection.text: “Bargaining unit work” means work duties assigned or allocated to a position occupied within the preceding 90 days by an employee who is represented by a certified representative.
“Certified representative” means an employee organization certified as an exclusive representative in accordance with Subtitle 2 of this title.
“Secretary–treasurer” means the secretary–treasurer of the Commission.
“Service contract” means a procurement contract for services that will be provided to the Commission.
This subtitle applies to a service contract that:

paragraph.text: the Commission solicits as a management plan intended to adversely affect employees of the Commission represented by a certified representative; and
a procurement officer of the Commission estimates will exceed a yearly cost of $75,000 as calculated under subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: The Commission shall adjust the estimate of the yearly cost described in subsection (a)(2) of this section to the nearest $100 every 2 years to reflect any aggregate increase in the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers, for the Washington–Baltimore metropolitan area, or any successor index, for the previous 2 years.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: solicitation of a service contract as part of a management plan or program intended to augment bargaining unit work and not for a present or eventual purpose of adversely affecting employees of the Commission represented by a certified representative;
solicitation of a service contract for which the primary purpose is to obtain goods or construction services;

solicitation of a service contract that the Commission’s purchasing officials reasonably believe and express in writing may negatively affect the potential for participation by a minority business enterprise according to a minority business enterprise utilization program authorized under Title 15, Subtitle 2 of this article;
solicitation of a service contract for a service provided by a consultant;
solicitation of a service contract for a professional service, unless the scope of service is provided by employees of a bargaining unit when the service contract is solicited;
solicitation of a service contract that the Commission reasonably believes is:

subparagraph.text: necessary to meet an emergent or imminent threat to public health, welfare, or safety;
required to comply with the requirements of a grant related to the funding of the service contract; or
related to the settlement of an insurance claim;

paragraph.text: solicitation of a service contract that is in the best interest of an employee based on a need for specialized safety experience or expertise;
solicitation of a service contract for a service provided by a public entity or provided to the Commission in accordance with a public–private partnership with a private entity;
solicitation of a service contract to be awarded on a noncompetitive basis in accordance with applicable laws regarding service contracts awarded on a noncompetitive basis;
a service contract entered into before October 31, 2007;

the renewal or rebidding of a service contract entered into before October 31, 2007, if the renewal or rebidding of the service contract does not result in a greater adverse effect on employees of a bargaining unit than existed before its renewal or rebidding;
solicitation of a service contract for a capital improvement project or asset management project;

solicitation of a class, type, category, or particular service contract that the Commission reasonably believes should be performed by an independent contractor to eliminate a conflict of interest otherwise apparent if the services are performed by an employee of a bargaining unit;

solicitation of a class, type, category, or particular service contract when the need for the service or activity is such that the time necessary for the analysis required under § 16–404 of this subtitle would:

subparagraph.text: result in damage to property of the Commission;
result in injury to an individual; or
substantially hinder the objective of constructing or maintaining safe and sanitary properties and facilities; or

paragraph.text: a service contract that the Montgomery County Council or the Prince George’s County Council authorizes or requires to be provided by an independent contractor.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to or limit the authority of the Commission to abolish a bargaining unit position or conduct a reduction in force.

section.text: Before the Commission solicits a service contract under this subtitle, the secretary–treasurer shall certify that the Commission has complied with §§ 16–404 and 16–405 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The secretary–treasurer may not certify that the Commission complied with the requirements of this subtitle unless the Commission:

paragraph.text: has taken steps to consider alternatives to the service contract, including reorganization, reevaluation of service, and reevaluation of performance;
has consulted with the certified representative of all employees of the Commission who will be adversely affected if the Commission enters into the service contract; and

has demonstrated, based on a cost comparison analysis and good faith estimates, that by entering into the service contract the Commission will save at least an amount equal to the lesser of $200,000 or 20% of the estimated net present value of the cost of the service contract.

subsection.text: The Commission shall estimate and compare at least the following in the cost comparison analysis:

paragraph.text: direct costs, including fringe benefits and the assumption that the contractor will pay employees who perform work under the service contract at the lesser of the labor rate established as the county living wage rate for Montgomery County or Prince George’s County;
indirect overhead costs properly allocable to the bargaining unit work or service contract according to generally accepted accounting principles; and
costs associated with unemployment compensation or outplacement assistance for displaced employees.

subsection.text: The Commission shall provide at least 60 days’ advance notice, and maintain at all times a formal plan of outplacement assistance, for each employee of the Commission who is represented by a certified representative and will be adversely affected by a service contract that is subject to this subtitle.
A plan described in subsection (a) of this section shall include:

paragraph.text: efforts to transfer or place each adversely affected employee of the Commission in a vacant position of the Commission that the employee is qualified to perform;
inclusion of a requirement in the service contract that the contractor shall:

subparagraph.text: notify the Commission of each vacant position for which displaced employees of the Commission may apply; and
consider and give preference to hiring displaced employees of the Commission; and

paragraph.text: written notification of the anticipated adverse effect on one or more job classifications to the certified representative at least 90 days before the anticipated adverse effect will occur.

section.text: The certified representative of an adversely affected employee of the Commission may submit a proposal for existing bargaining unit employees to continue performing the services described in a solicitation while achieving the targeted savings.

subsection.text: If the Commission fails to comply with this subtitle and an employee of the Commission is adversely affected, the certified representative of the employee may file an appeal on the record on behalf of the employee before the State Office of Administrative Hearings in accordance with the contested case provisions of the Administrative Procedure Act, Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: If the administrative law judge finds that the Commission was arbitrary and capricious in soliciting or entering into a service contract that is subject to this subtitle, and the employee of the Commission has been adversely affected, the administrative law judge may award the employee actual damages for back pay and front pay for a combined period of up to 2 years beginning on the date the employee was first adversely affected.
The employee is obligated to mitigate the actual damages.

An award of actual damages authorized under this subsection shall be the sole and exclusive remedy for a violation of this subtitle that is available to the employee, and liability may not accrue for punitive damages, consequential damages, or damages for emotional distress or pain and suffering.

subsection.text: Noncompliance with this subtitle may not invalidate a contract award or proposed contract award that the Commission has otherwise validly awarded or issued.

section.text: In this subtitle, “full–time park employee” means an individual employed by the county Parks and Recreation Department who:

paragraph.text: works at least 37.5 hours each week, excluding Commission holidays; and
has been employed by the Department for more than 1 year without interruption.

section.text: This subtitle applies only in Prince George’s County.
The county planning board shall designate a director to coordinate its county recreation program with the Commission’s park functions.
The county planning board shall employ full–time park employees and part–time employees as necessary to carry out the functions and programs of Title 25, Subtitle 8 of this article.

subsection.text: The county planning board shall employ full–time park employees under the Commission’s merit system, as provided in Subtitle 1 of this title.
Full–time park employees shall receive the same employment benefits that other employees receive under the Commission’s merit system, including:

paragraph.text: annual leave;
sick leave;
health benefits; and
retirement benefits.

subsection.text: The county planning board may employ part–time or temporary employees for a period of time and at a salary as the county planning board may determine.
The county planning board may accept the services of volunteers without compensation.
Employees employed by the recreation department on July 1, 1970, who are employed under the county merit system shall be employed by the Commission:

paragraph.text: to further the functions and programs of Title 25, Subtitle 8 of this article;
in a position classification that the county planning board may establish; and
at a pay grade not less than that held by the employee under the county merit system.

subsection.text: Employees transferred to the Commission under this subtitle shall be given credit for sick and annual leave accrued under the county merit system and for any other benefits, privileges, and rights accrued while employed by the county.

section.text: The county planning board may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commission may acquire property for the purposes stated in subsection (b) of this section to carry out the Commission’s general plan for the physical development of the metropolitan district.
The purposes for acquisition include:

paragraph.text: in the metropolitan district:

subparagraph.text: parks;
forests;
roads; and
other public ways, grounds, and spaces; and

paragraph.text: public recreation, including the construction of public recreation centers, community buildings, or other public buildings necessary to house a public recreation program.

subsection.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: may improve and develop property that it acquires under this section for the purposes stated in subsection (b) of this section; and
controls the maintenance and operation of the property.

subsection.text: A general regulation governing property acquired for a purpose under subsection (b)(1) of this section in either county may not take effect until the regulation receives the affirmative vote of at least three members of the Commission from that county.
This section is for the purpose of preserving and enhancing the scenic beauty of Rock Creek.

Notwithstanding any power of the Commission to acquire property, without the approval of the majority of the members of the Montgomery County Council, on or after July 1, 1969, the Commission may not construct a new road adjacent to Rock Creek within 1500 feet from the banks of the creek.
This section may not be construed to prohibit the construction of a bridge or road necessary to cross Rock Creek.

To finance wholly or partly the acquisition of property under § 17–101(b) of this subtitle, the Commission may receive and expend any contribution or appropriation by the United States, the District of Columbia, the State, any other political subdivision, or any person.

To finance wholly or partly land acquisition, design, development, redevelopment, or revitalization in Prince George’s County, the Commission may receive and expend any contribution or appropriation by the United States, the District of Columbia, the State, any other political subdivision, or any person.
Title to lands acquired under § 1(a) of the Capper–Cramton Act, Public Law 71–284, 46 Stat. 482, shall vest in the United States, as provided in that act.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, without the approval of the General Assembly:

paragraph.text: title to any other property acquired may not be placed in or granted to the United States or any person or political subdivision other than the metropolitan district itself or the State; and

the control, maintenance, operation, or policing of any other park, forest, road, or other public way, ground, or space in the metropolitan district may not be placed in or granted to the United States or to any other person or political subdivision other than the Commission itself.

subsection.text: In Prince George’s County, the title, control, maintenance, or operation of property acquired in the Prince George’s County portion of the metropolitan district may be transferred by county local law to:

paragraph.text: the redevelopment authority of Prince George’s County; or
the revenue authority of Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: The Commission may acquire land for the purposes stated in § 17–213 of this title and Title 18, Subtitle 2 of this article outside the metropolitan district but in the regional district.

The Commission may acquire land under subsection (a) of this section if the Commission finds that the acquisition is necessary to preserve any portion of the Commission’s regional park plan for the metropolitan district.

paragraph.text: To acquire land under this section, the Commission may expend any current funds that may be expended under this division for land acquisition in the metropolitan district for the purposes authorized by this section.
Funds used for land acquisition in the Montgomery County portion of the metropolitan district may include the proceeds of bonds the Commission issues under Title 18, Subtitle 2 of this article.

subsection.text: Whenever the Commission considers it necessary to acquire any property for a purpose stated in § 17–101(b) of this subtitle, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: purchase the property from the owner; or
if the Commission fails to agree with the owner, condemn the property by proceedings in the circuit court for the county in which the property is located.

subsection.text: At the same time, the Commission may acquire the interest of any tenant, lessee, or other person having an interest in the property.

section.text: The Commission shall condemn property using the procedures for condemnation of land by a public service company in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, at any time after 10 days after the return and recordation of the verdict or award in the proceedings, the Commission may enter and take possession of the condemned property, notwithstanding any appeal or further proceedings on the part of the defendant.

paragraph.text: Before entering the property, the Commission shall pay to the clerk of the circuit court the amount of the award and all costs assessed to date.
At the time of payment, the Commission shall agree to abide by and fulfill any judgment following appeal, or until the time to request an appeal expires.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Business” means a lawful activity conducted primarily:

subparagraph.text: for the purchase, sale, lease, or rental of property;
for the manufacture, processing, or marketing of products or other personal property;
for the sale of services to the public; or
by a not–for–profit organization.

paragraph.text: “Business” does not include a farm operation.

subsection.text: “Displaced”, with respect to a person, means moving from real property, or moving the person’s personal property from real property:

paragraph.text: wholly or partly as a result of the Commission’s acquisition of the real property; or
as the result of a written order of the Commission to vacate the real property for a public works program or project the Commission undertakes.

subsection.text: “Farm operation” means an activity that:

paragraph.text: is conducted primarily for the production of one or more agricultural products, including timber, for sale or home use; and
customarily produces those products in sufficient quantity to be able to contribute materially to the operator’s income.

subsection.text: “Relocation payment” means a payment the Commission makes to a displaced person in accordance with this part.
In this section, “average annual net earnings”:

paragraph.text: means one–half of any net earnings of the business or farm operation, before federal, State, and local income taxes, during:

subparagraph.text: the 2 taxable years immediately preceding the taxable year when the business or farm operation moves from the real property acquired for the project; or
a different period the Commission determines to be more equitable for establishing the earnings; and

paragraph.text: includes any compensation paid by the business or farm operation to the owner or the owner’s spouse or dependents during the period.

subsection.text: A person who is displaced by the acquisition of real property for a program or project the Commission undertakes may apply to the appropriate county planning board for a relocation payment under this section.
The Commission shall make the relocation payment to the displaced person after the county planning board approves the application.

paragraph.text: The relocation payment shall include:

subparagraph.text: actual reasonable expenses to move the person and the person’s family, business, farm operation, or other personal property;
actual direct losses of tangible personal property as a result of moving or discontinuing a business or farm operation; and
actual reasonable expenses in searching for a replacement business or farm.

paragraph.text: The losses payable under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection may not exceed the reasonable expenses that would have been required to relocate the property, as determined by the appropriate county planning board.

subsection.text: A displaced person eligible for a relocation payment under subsection (c) of this section who is displaced from a dwelling and who chooses to accept a relocation payment under this subsection instead of a relocation payment under subsection (c) of this section may receive:

paragraph.text: a moving expense allowance determined according to a schedule established by the Commission, not to exceed $300; and
a relocation allowance of $200.

Subject to subsection (g) of this section, a displaced person eligible for a relocation payment under subsection (c) of this section who is displaced from the person’s place of business or farm operation and who chooses to accept a relocation payment under this subsection instead of a relocation payment under subsection (c) of this section may receive a fixed payment in an amount equal to the average annual net earnings of the business or farm operation.
A relocation payment under this subsection shall be at least $2,500 and may not exceed $10,000.

subsection.text: A business is not eligible to receive a relocation payment under subsection (f) of this section unless the Commission is satisfied that the business:

paragraph.text: cannot be relocated without a substantial loss of its existing patronage; and
is not a part of a commercial enterprise that has at least one other location that:

subparagraph.text: the Commission is not acquiring; and
is engaged in the same or a similar business.

subsection.text: In addition to any other authorized payment, the Commission shall make an additional relocation payment not to exceed $15,000 to a person who is displaced from a dwelling that the person owns and has occupied for at least 180 days immediately preceding the start of negotiations to acquire the property.
The additional relocation payment shall include:

paragraph.text: any additional amount that, added to the acquisition cost of the dwelling acquired by the Commission, equals the reasonable cost of a comparable replacement dwelling that is a habitable dwelling:

subparagraph.text: adequate to accommodate the displaced person;
reasonably accessible to public services and places of employment; and
available on the private market;

paragraph.text: subject to subsection (c) of this section, any additional amount that the displaced person must pay to finance acquisition of a comparable replacement dwelling; and

reasonable expenses the displaced person incurs for title insurance, recording and transfer fees and taxes, and other taxes and closing costs incident to the purchase of the replacement dwelling, other than prepaid expenses.

The Commission shall include financing under subsection (b)(2) of this section in an additional relocation payment only if the dwelling was encumbered by a mortgage that was a valid lien on the dwelling for at least 180 days immediately preceding the start of negotiations to acquire the dwelling.
The amount payable under subsection (b)(2) of this section shall be computed for the period of time remaining under the mortgage on the acquired dwelling as the product of:

subparagraph.text: the net present value of the difference, if any, between:

sub-subparagraph.text: the interest and other debt service costs to be incurred to finance the replacement dwelling for that period; and
those costs that would have been incurred for that period to finance the acquired dwelling; and

subparagraph.text: the unpaid principal balance of the mortgage on the acquired dwelling at the time of acquisition divided by the principal amount of the purchase money mortgage on the replacement dwelling.

paragraph.text: The discount rate shall be the prevailing interest rate paid on savings deposits by commercial banks in the general area where the replacement dwelling is located.

subsection.text: The Commission shall make the additional relocation payment only to a displaced person who purchases and occupies a habitable replacement dwelling by the later of:

paragraph.text: 1 year after the person receives from the Commission final payment of all costs of the acquired dwelling; or
the date when the person moves from the acquired dwelling.

subsection.text: Whenever the acquisition of real property for a program or project the Commission undertakes will result in a person being displaced, the Commission shall refer each displaced person who needs relocation advisory services to the appropriate county agency that provides those services in accordance with § 12–206 of the Real Property Article.
The agency shall provide relocation advisory services to the displaced person the Commission refers to the agency under the agency’s relocation advisory services program.
The Commission may establish regulations and procedures necessary to ensure that:

paragraph.text: relocation payments and assistance are administered in a manner that is fair and reasonable and is as uniform as practicable;
a displaced person who makes proper application for a relocation payment for that person shall be paid promptly after a move or, in case of hardship, be paid in advance; and

a person aggrieved by a determination as to eligibility for a relocation payment, or the amount of a relocation payment, may have the person’s application reviewed by the appropriate county planning board.

subsection.text: In order to promote uniform and effective administration of relocation assistance and land acquisition, the Commission shall consult State and local agencies providing similar services on the establishment of regulations and procedures for the implementation of the programs.

section.text: Payment received under this part may not be considered as income for the purposes of Title 10 of the Tax – General Article.

subsection.text: The State or the Commission, as appropriate, shall hold any land acquired under this division to which it takes title:

paragraph.text: for the general benefit of the residents of the State; and
especially for the benefit of the residents in the metropolitan district.

subsection.text: Without the approval of the Commission by resolution:

paragraph.text: title to the land may not be conveyed by the State; or
public use may not be terminated.

subsection.text: This division does not limit the police power of the State, either county, or any municipal corporation where any park, road, or public space is located.
The concurrent police power of a municipal corporation extends only to areas located within its boundaries for purposes of this division.
All property acquired by the Commission for any purpose specified in this subtitle and Subtitle 1 of this title is exempt from State, county, and municipal taxes.
All land dedicated to the Commission in accordance with county subdivision regulations is property acquired by the Commission within the meaning of this section.

paragraph.text: The Commission may lease to any responsible person any land in the metropolitan district acquired for park purposes under this division.

subparagraph.text: The term of a lease may not exceed 20 years without the prior approval of the lease by legislative enactment of the county where the lease property is located.
The initial term of a lease may not exceed 40 years.
A lease may be renewed for additional terms not exceeding 10 years each.

paragraph.text: A lease agreement shall contain provisions for reversion without cost to the Commission of the property and its improvements regardless of whether the improvements were added to the property by the lessee during the term of the lease or any extension of the lease.

The Commission may grant privileges, permits, and concessions, and may enter into contracts relating to them, with any responsible person to engage in any business or enterprise on land in the metropolitan district acquired for park purposes under this division.

Any privilege, permit, or concession granted under this subsection shall be on terms and conditions the Commission considers advantageous to the development of the park system as a part of the plan for the physical development of the metropolitan district and the plan of the regional district within the metropolitan district.
The purpose for which property is leased, or for which a privilege, permit, or concession is granted, may not be inconsistent with the use of the property for park purposes.

Any lease or contract executed under this section shall contain a condition stating specifically the purposes for which the property is leased or for which the privilege, permit, or concession is granted.
An agreement the Commission enters into in accordance with this division shall contain provisions prohibiting the assignment of the agreement without the consent of the Commission.

subsection.text: In Montgomery County, a lease, contract, or agreement entered into under this section may not:

paragraph.text: authorize a person other than the Commission to close a park or park facility; or
grant a person other than the Commission the authority to close or require the closing of an existing park or park facility under the jurisdiction of the Commission to prevent competition.

subsection.text: This division does not limit the Commission’s authority to require an agreement to contain more restrictive provisions the Commission considers to be in the public interest.

section.text: The Commission may transfer any land that it holds under this title and determines not to be needed for park purposes or other purposes authorized under this title.

subsection.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: may sell or otherwise dispose of any playground or recreational facility no longer needed for public use; and
shall use the proceeds of the sale or disposition for the construction, acquisition, or improvement of any other playground or recreational facility in the metropolitan district.

Except for parkland acquired under an agreement with the National Capital Planning Commission, the Commission may exchange playground or recreational land held or acquired by the Commission in its own name or in the name of the State for any other land held or acquired by the United States, the State, or any other public body or agency, which the Commission determines to be more suitable for playground and recreational purposes.
An exchange under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: may be accompanied by a partial cash payment moving either to or from the Commission; and
shall be considered an acquisition of land for the public uses provided in this title.

subsection.text: The Commission may adopt regulations for the use of any property under its jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: post the regulations outside each park headquarters building, community center, recreation center, or similar building in a developed park area; and
after posting the regulations, publish them at least three times within 60 days in one or more newspapers of general circulation published in the metropolitan district.

paragraph.text: The posting and publication of the regulations shall be sufficient notice to all persons.
The sworn certificate of a commissioner as to the posting and publication of the regulations is prima facie evidence of posting and publication.
A violation of a regulation under § 17–207 of this subtitle is a Commission infraction unless the violation is declared by law to be a crime.

subparagraph.text: A Commission infraction is a civil offense.
The adjudication of a Commission infraction:

sub-subparagraph.text: is not a criminal conviction; and
does not impose any of the civil disabilities ordinarily imposed by a criminal conviction.

paragraph.text: A Commission park police officer may deliver a citation to any person charged with a Commission infraction.
The Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: retain a copy of the citation; and
include on the citation a certification attesting to the truth of the matter specified in the citation.

paragraph.text: The citation shall also contain:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the person charged;
the nature of the infraction;
the location and time that the infraction occurred;
the amount of the fine assessed for the infraction;
the manner, location, and time in which the fine may be paid to the Commission; and
notice of the person’s right to a trial for the infraction.

paragraph.text: The Commission may:

subparagraph.text: establish a schedule of fines for each conviction of a Commission infraction;
impose a fine not to exceed $50 for each conviction of a Commission infraction; and
impose a fine not to exceed $100 for each repeat violation.

paragraph.text: The recipient of a citation for a Commission infraction shall pay the fine to the Commission within 20 days after the receipt of the citation.

If a person who receives a citation for a Commission infraction fails to pay the fine by the payment due date specified in the citation and fails to file a notice of the person’s intent to stand trial for the offense, the Commission shall send a notice of the infraction to the person’s last known address.
A person who fails to pay the fine within 15 days after the date of the notice is liable for an additional fine not to exceed twice the original fine.

subparagraph.text: If the fine is not paid within 35 days after the date of notice, the Commission may request adjudication of the case through the District Court.
The District Court promptly shall schedule the case for trial and summon the defendant to appear.

paragraph.text: A person who receives a citation for a Commission infraction may elect to stand trial by filing with the Commission a notice of the person’s intent to stand trial.
The notice shall be given at least 5 days before the payment due date specified in the citation.

On receipt of the notice of intent to stand trial, the Commission shall forward to the District Court having venue a copy of the citation and a copy of the notice of intent to stand trial that was filed by the person who received the citation.
On receipt of the citation and the notice of intent to stand trial, the District Court shall schedule the case for trial and notify the defendant and the Commission of the trial date.
The District Court shall remit to the Commission all fines, penalties, or forfeitures the District Court collects for Commission infractions.

subsection.text: A person found by the District Court to have committed a Commission infraction shall pay a fine not to exceed:

paragraph.text: $50 for a first violation; or
$100 for a repeat violation.

subsection.text: In a proceeding for a Commission infraction before the District Court, the violation shall be prosecuted in the same manner and to the same extent as provided for municipal infractions under Article 23A, § 3(b) of the Code.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Animal” means any bird or mammal or any part, egg, offspring, or dead body part of any bird or mammal.
“Hunt” means to pursue, capture, kill, gig, trap, shoot, or attempt to pursue, capture, kill, gig, trap, or shoot, or in any manner reduce any animal to personal possession.

subsection.text: A person may not hunt an animal on property owned by, operated by, or leased by the Commission without prior written authorization from the Commission.

For the purpose of this section, each animal taken illegally by hunting, offered for purchase, sold, bartered, or exchanged in excess of the bag limit or possessed illegally constitutes a separate violation.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

subparagraph.text: for a first violation, a fine not exceeding $1,500, with costs imposed at the discretion of the court; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $4,000 or both, with costs imposed at the discretion of the court.

paragraph.text: For the purpose of this subsection, a subsequent violation is a violation that:

subparagraph.text: occurs within 2 years after any prior violation of this section; and
arises out of a separate set of circumstances.

paragraph.text: In addition to the penalties in paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection, the court may order the license under which the person operated in committing the violation to be suspended for 12 months from the date of the subsequent conviction.
The Commission may adopt regulations necessary to administer and enforce this section.
Violation of any regulation adopted by the Commission under this subsection is a misdemeanor and is punishable as provided in subsection (d) of this section.

The Chief Judge of the District Court may establish, by administrative regulation under § 1–605 of the Courts Article, a schedule of prepayable fines for a first offense misdemeanor violation of this section and regulations adopted under this section.
The amount of a prepayable fine may be not more than the maximum and not less than the minimum criminal penalty established in this section.
By paying a fine set under this section instead of appearing for trial in District Court, a person is voluntarily accepting a conviction for the violation charged.

subsection.text: If the District Court or circuit court imposes a fine for a violation of this section, the court shall collect the fine and remit it to the Commission.
If a park police officer apprehends a person for violating any law punishable as a misdemeanor under § 17–209 of this subtitle, the officer may prepare and sign a written citation.
A citation issued under subsection (a) of this section shall include:

paragraph.text: a notice to appear in court;
the name and address of the person charged;
appropriate license numbers, if any;
the violation charged;
the time and place the person shall appear in court; and
other pertinent information the Commission requires.
A person charged under subsection (a) of this section may give a written promise to appear in court by signing the citation prepared by the officer.
An officer shall arrest a person charged under subsection (a) of this section if:

subparagraph.text: the person does not furnish satisfactory identification;
the officer has reasonable grounds to believe the person will disregard a written promise to appear; or
the person refuses to sign a written promise to appear.

subsection.text: A person shall comply with the written promise to appear in court unless the person:

paragraph.text: posts sufficient collateral for the violation;
pays the fine in advance of trial; or
is represented by counsel in court.
If a person fails to comply with the notice to appear in a citation issued under this section, the court may:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, issue a warrant for the person’s arrest; or
after 5 days, notify the court clerk of the person’s noncompliance.

paragraph.text: On receipt of notice of noncompliance from the court, the clerk shall notify the person by mail at the address indicated on the citation that the court may issue a warrant for the person’s arrest unless, within 15 days after the notice is mailed, the person:

subparagraph.text: pays the fine on the charge as provided for in the original citation and an additional fine of $100 for failing to appear; or
posts bond or a penalty deposit and requests a new trial date.

paragraph.text: If a person fails to pay the fines or post the bond or penalty deposit under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the court may issue a warrant for the person’s arrest.
If the original violation is not punishable by imprisonment, the court may not issue a warrant for the person’s arrest under this subsection for at least 20 days after the original trial date.

section.text: The Commission may assign living quarters in a house or building in its jurisdiction to a person:

paragraph.text: connected with the Commission; and
having the duties of caretaker or supervisory attention over the house or building.

subsection.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, name and rename any street or highway and number and renumber the houses in the metropolitan district if each new number or change of number is reported to the owner or occupant of the building for the purpose of:

subparagraph.text: correcting mistakes;
removing confusion because of a duplication of street names; and
securing a uniformity of street names and numbering of houses;

paragraph.text: place or have placed new numbers on the buildings or premises and proper signs indicating the names of streets and highways; and
appropriate and expend as much of any surplus from fees for building permits issued in each county as is necessary to pay for the expenses in carrying out this section.
The Commission may adopt reasonable regulations for carrying out any changes in street or highway names or the numbering of houses.
A violation of a regulation adopted under this subsection is a misdemeanor punishable under the general penalty provisions of this division.

The Commission may not rename any street or renumber any house located in a municipal corporation in Prince George’s County unless the proposed change is approved by the legislative body of the municipal corporation.

subparagraph.text: Any party aggrieved by the refusal of a municipal corporation to approve a proposed change may appeal to the Prince George’s County Council.

After public hearing and on a finding of need for public health, safety, and welfare, the County Council by resolution may authorize the change notwithstanding the objections of the municipal corporation.
The resolution shall require the affirmative vote of two–thirds of all the members of the County Council.

paragraph.text: If in the Commission’s judgment it is necessary to provide for flood control in the metropolitan district, the Commission may condemn land and easements necessary in the construction of levees and other flood control works.
The condemnation proceedings shall be in accordance with the general powers provided in this division.

The Commission may assume all damages incident to any flood control works or improvements that it finds necessary to construct, except damages to land and easements of railroads or other public utilities.
The Commission may agree to:

subparagraph.text: furnish, without cost to the United States, all land and easements that may be necessary in the construction of any flood control works or improvements; and
take over, operate, and maintain the works when constructed.

subsection.text: The Commission may use for park purposes the land acquired for flood control and navigation projects as provided in Title 25, Subtitle 7 of this article.

section.text: The Commission may appoint park police officers as necessary to provide protection for the activities and property of the Commission.

subsection.text: The park police:

paragraph.text: possess all the powers and authority vested by existing law in the Montgomery County and Prince George’s County police;
are responsible to and under the supervision of the Commission; and
shall exercise supervisory jurisdiction over the park system.

subsection.text: The park police shall:

paragraph.text: prevent crime;
apprehend criminals;
enforce the criminal and motor vehicle laws of the State;
enforce park regulations; and
perform other related duties that the Commission imposes.

subsection.text: The park police have concurrent general police jurisdiction with the Montgomery County and Prince George’s County police:

paragraph.text: within the parks and other areas under the jurisdiction of the Commission;
within buildings under the jurisdiction of the Commission; and
on the portion of all roads and sidewalks immediately adjacent to property under the jurisdiction of the Commission.
The park police have jurisdiction off park property that may be provided by any reciprocal agreement entered into under § 2–105 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
A reciprocal agreement shall specify the circumstances under which a park police officer may make arrests off of park property.
Notwithstanding § 2–105 of the Criminal Procedure Article, a reciprocal agreement may allow arrests in emergency or nonemergency situations.

section.text: The Montgomery County and Prince George’s County police have the same general police jurisdiction and responsibility for the apprehension of criminals and detection of crime within the parks and other areas and buildings under the jurisdiction of the Commission as they have elsewhere in their respective counties.

paragraph.text: In Prince George’s County, the county planning board may appoint a deputy chief of the county division of the park police.
The deputy chief has the same jurisdiction, powers, and authority as park police officers appointed by the Commission.

subsection.text: The deputy chief shall serve at the pleasure of the county planning board.
The county planning board shall set the compensation of the deputy chief.

section.text: The Commission may not acquire new land or use land already held by the Commission for the purpose of constructing an administration building without the prior approval of the County Executive and County Council of Montgomery County and the County Executive and County Council of Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: The Commission has acquired title to the entire parcel of property known as Glenn Dale Hospital for use in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: The Commission:

subparagraph.text: shall maintain the approximately 150 acres that have not been developed as part of the existing hospital campus in the Commission’s park system; and

may sell, lease, or otherwise transfer the approximately 60 acres that have been developed as a hospital campus to a person who will use the property as a continuing care retirement community in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 4 of the Human Services Article.

paragraph.text: If the Commission is unable to find a qualified person to carry out the intent of paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection, the Commission shall retain possession of the approximately 60 acres until the General Assembly approves an alternate use.
The Commission has received property as a gift under the last will of Violet Blair Janin to establish a public park in memory of Jesup Blair.
The property received under paragraph (1) of this subsection is the portion of the farm, “The Moorings”, from the trees fronting on Georgia Avenue and Blair Road, including all improvements.
In accordance with the conditions set forth in the will, the Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: make ample provision for the maintenance of the property as a public park;
unless it is absolutely necessary to remove trees in connection with the laying out of the public park, preserve all of the trees on the property; and
replace any trees on the property that are destroyed or die.

subsection.text: The Commission may possess, manage, control, and maintain the property as a public park and memorial to Jesup Blair by:

paragraph.text: preserving trees on the property;
maintaining good order in the public park;
building and maintaining roads, buildings, and conveniences as necessary or advisable;
replacing trees that die or are destroyed; and
taking other actions necessary to maintain the public park in good condition and carry out the purposes of the gift.

subsection.text: The Commission shall make yearly expenditures from the general revenues of the Commission received under this division to pay the cost of the maintenance, development, and use of the public park as necessary to accomplish the purposes of this division.

section.text: The public general laws governing the preparation and filing of budgets by State units do not apply to the Commission.
The Commission shall prepare annual capital and operating budgets for each fiscal year beginning on July 1 and ending on June 30 of the subsequent year.
The budgets shall contain:

paragraph.text: separately for each county for which items are allocable and for which a tax is imposed, the proposed expenditures and estimates of anticipated revenue;
a complete planning work program for each county in the regional district, including a schedule for the production of all plans and amendments;
items allocable jointly to both counties, including provisions for:

subparagraph.text: the operation of the units of the Commission established by law; and
the regional planning program; and

paragraph.text: a schedule of recreation activities and programs for Prince George’s County in accordance with § 25–806 of this article.

section.text: The Commission shall submit the proposed budgets on or before January 15 of each year to the county executives of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: In Montgomery County, the County Executive shall submit the proposed budgets to the County Council, together with the County Executive’s recommendations, on or before March 1 of each year.
In Prince George’s County, the County Executive shall submit the proposed budgets to the County Council, together with the County Executive’s recommendations, on or before April 1 of each year.
After public notice, each county council shall hold a public hearing on the Commission’s proposed budgets at least 21 days after receiving the budgets from the county executive.
On or before June 1 of each year, each county council shall, by resolution:

paragraph.text: approve the portion of the budgets allocable to that county, with any alterations made under subsection (c) of this section; and

subject to the requirements and limitations of Subtitles 3 and 4 of this title and Title 21 of this article, impose taxes in the amounts the county council determines to be necessary to finance the portion of the budgets allocable to that county.

subsection.text: Each county council may add to, delete from, increase, or decrease any part of the budgets allocable solely to that county.

paragraph.text: Budget items allocable to both counties as submitted by the Commission shall be concurred in by both county councils.
The county councils may concur in additions to, deletions from, increases to, or decreases from budget items allocable to both counties.
Failure of the county councils to concur in any budget item allocable to both counties by June 15 shall constitute approval of the item as submitted by the Commission.

subsection.text: Within 3 calendar days after approval of the budgets, each county council shall submit the budgets to the respective county executive.
Within 10 days after delivery of the budgets by the county council, the county executive may disapprove or reduce any item contained in the budgets or the planning work program.

If the county executive disapproves or reduces any item in the budgets, the county executive shall return the budgets to the respective county council with the reasons for the county executive’s disapproval or reduction stated in writing.

Within 30 days after the respective county executive returns the budgets, each county council may, by affirmative vote of six of its members, reapprove or restore any item over the disapproval of the county executive.
After adoption of the budgets by the county councils, the budgets may be amended by resolution by the county councils on their initiative or at the request of the Commission.
Before adopting a budget amendment under this subsection, a county council shall:

paragraph.text: receive recommendations from the respective county executive; and
hold a public hearing on reasonable notice to the public.

subsection.text: An amendment to a budget item allocable to both counties is not effective unless it has received the concurrence of both county councils.

Unless approved by either or both county councils, as applicable, after receiving recommendations from either or both county executives, the Commission may not make or authorize an expenditure of funds exceeding 110% of the available approved budget amounts for:

paragraph.text: each park and recreation project and each administrative or operating department or function of the Commission, as set forth in each county’s legislation approving the budgets; and
each planning project contained in the planning work program for each county.

subsection.text: Except for enterprise funds, the Commission may not exceed the total approved budgets for each of its funds, without the prior approval of either or both county councils, as applicable.

section.text: The Commission shall prepare and submit a 6–year capital improvements program:

paragraph.text: before November 1 of each odd–numbered calendar year to the County Executive and County Council of Montgomery County; and
before January 15 of each calendar year to the county governing body of Prince George’s County.

section.text: The capital improvements program shall:

paragraph.text: include a statement of the objectives of the capital programs and the relationship of the programs to the county’s adopted long range development plans;
recommend capital projects and a construction schedule;
provide an estimate of cost and a statement of all funding sources; and
include all programmed parkland acquisition, all major park improvement and development, and major acquisition of equipment.

section.text: In Montgomery County, the County Executive shall submit recommendations with respect to the Commission’s proposed program, including any suggested amendments, revisions, or modifications, to the County Council as part of the comprehensive 6–year capital improvements program required by the county charter in each even–numbered calendar year.

subsection.text: On or before adoption of its annual budget and appropriations resolution, each county governing body shall adopt the 6–year capital improvements program:

paragraph.text: each even–numbered calendar year in Montgomery County; and
each year in Prince George’s County.
Each county governing body shall hold a public hearing before adopting the 6–year capital improvements program.
The public hearing may be conducted in conjunction with public hearings on the 6–year programs or capital budgets of the county and other units.
Each county governing body may amend, revise, or modify the 6–year capital improvements program.
An amendment, revision, or modification made under this paragraph may not become final until at least 30 days after it is submitted to the Commission for written comment.

section.text: In Montgomery County, the County Council may amend an approved 6–year capital improvements program at any time by an affirmative vote of six of its members.

subsection.text: The Commission’s capital budget for each fiscal year may include only projects that fully conform with the part of the most recently adopted 6–year capital improvements program applicable to that year.

paragraph.text: Unless the 6–year capital improvements program has been amended in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection, a capital project may not be undertaken, wholly or partly, that is not in conformity with the part of the program applicable to that year.
The 6–year capital improvements program may be amended by the county governing body:

subparagraph.text: on its own initiative or at the request of the Commission; and
after a public hearing on reasonable notice to the public.

section.text: In this subtitle, “bond” means a bond, note, or other evidence of indebtedness issued under this title.
A requirement for signature under this subtitle may be satisfied by manual or facsimile signature.

subsection.text: The Commission may issue and sell bonds in amounts necessary for the purposes under subsection (b) of this section and under regulations the Commission determines.
The Commission may issue the bonds to pay for the acquisition of property in the metropolitan district for the purposes of § 17–101(b) of this article.
The Commission may issue the bonds periodically in one or more series.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the amount of bonds outstanding at any time may not exceed an amount that is redeemable within 30 years from the date of issue by the tax authorized and pledged to pay the bonds, to the extent that the tax is proposed to be imposed in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County or both.
To determine the amount of bonds that may be outstanding under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commission may assume:

subparagraph.text: future imposition of the tax at the rate established by each county;
100% collection of the tax in each fiscal year; and
the assessed value of property at the time the bonds are issued will remain constant.

subsection.text: The bonds shall:

paragraph.text: be registered or coupon bonds in denominations determined by the Commission;
bear interest:

subparagraph.text: annually at a rate the Commission determines to be advantageous and otherwise in the public interest; and
payable semiannually or at a time determined by the Commission;

paragraph.text: mature within 50 years from the date of issue; and
be issued under the hand and seal of the Commission, by manual or facsimile signature.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, the Commission may sell the bonds by competitive or negotiated sale in a manner, for a price, and at rates the Commission determines to be in its best interests.

paragraph.text: In the issue of bonds, the Commission may provide for the redemption of some or all of the bonds before their stated maturity.
The redemption price of the bonds may be greater than the par value of the bonds.

subsection.text: The bonds shall be issued on the full faith and credit of the Commission and the county guaranteeing the bonds.

paragraph.text: If the Commission decides to spend the proceeds of a bond issue throughout the metropolitan district, Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall guarantee the payment of principal of and interest on the bonds.
The following guarantee shall be stated on each bond:
“The payment of interest when due and of the principal on maturity is guaranteed by Montgomery and Prince George’s counties, Maryland.”.
The county executives of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall sign the endorsement by manual or facsimile signature on each bond.

If there is any liability under the guarantee, each county’s liability shall be in the proportion the assessable basis for that part of the county in the metropolitan district bears to the assessable basis of the whole district.
