subparagraph.text: affirm or reverse the action; or
remand the action to the county planning board for further consideration.

subsection.text: If a petition for judicial review is filed under this section, the procedures under § 22–402(b) of this article apply to the county planning board and other parties as appropriate.

The county planning board or the governing body of the appropriate county may institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceedings to compel the construction and installation of improvements or conservation of resources at a time and according to specifications set by or in accordance with this division.
Any court of competent jurisdiction has jurisdiction to issue restraining orders, temporary or permanent injunctions, mandamus, or other appropriate forms of remedy or relief.

section.text: This part applies only in Montgomery County.

subsection.text: In addition to all other remedies provided by law, the district council may authorize the county planning board to impose civil monetary fines or penalties and, if the public health, safety, or welfare is threatened, issue stop work orders for a violation of:

paragraph.text: this division;
county subdivision regulations and zoning laws;
any law or regulation that the Commission or the county planning board is exclusively authorized to administer; or
any decision made by the Commission or the county planning board under its respective authority.
A fine not to exceed $500 may be imposed for each violation under this part.
The district council may establish a schedule of fines for each violation and may adopt procedures, consistent with this part, for imposing and collecting the fines.
Each day a violation occurs is a separate violation under this part.

The district council may provide that the county planning board may enforce the imposition of fines and penalties in a manner consistent with the process requiring notification and hearing under Title 11, Subtitle 2 of this article.
The imposition of fines and penalties under this part is not subject to an appeal to the Board of Appeals.

subsection.text: The district council may provide for the county planning board, through counsel, to prosecute violations for which civil monetary fines or penalties are imposed.

A violation of a local law implementing the State Forest Conservation Law shall be enforced in accordance with Title 5, Subtitle 16 of the Natural Resources Article and not in accordance with this part.

section.text: This title applies only in Montgomery County.

subsection.text: The Town of Kensington has concurrent jurisdiction to enforce the county zoning laws within its boundaries.

A two–thirds majority vote of both the district council and the county planning board is required to take any action relating to zoning within the Town of Kensington that is contrary to a resolution of the Mayor and Town Council.

A two–thirds majority vote of the county planning board is required to take any action relating to land use planning within the Town of Kensington that is contrary to a resolution of the Mayor and Town Council.
The City of Takoma Park has concurrent jurisdiction to enforce the county zoning laws within its boundaries.

A two–thirds majority vote of both the district council and the county planning board is required to take any action relating to zoning within the City of Takoma Park that is contrary to a resolution of the Mayor and City Council.

A two–thirds majority vote of the county planning board is required to take any action relating to land use planning within the City of Takoma Park that is contrary to a resolution of the Mayor and City Council.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agreement” means a development rights and responsibilities agreement to establish the conditions under which development of real property may proceed that is:

paragraph.text: of a specified duration;
made between:

subparagraph.text: the county planning board or its designee;
a reviewing entity; and
a person having a legal or equitable interest in the property; and

paragraph.text: approved by the district council or the County Executive.
“Development” means any activity that materially affects the existing condition or use of any land or structure.
“Development” does not include normal agricultural activity.

subsection.text: “Regulatory plan” means an application proposing development on privately owned land that must be submitted to the county planning board for review and final approval under this division or county law or regulation.
“Reviewing entity” means the County Executive or other local, State, or federal government or unit that agrees to execute an agreement.

section.text: This subtitle does not:

paragraph.text: require the district council to adopt a local law; or
authorize the district council, the Commission, or a designee of either unit to require a party to enter into an agreement.

subsection.text: In accordance with this section, the district council may adopt local laws that establish procedures and requirements for the execution of agreements.
A local law adopted under this section by the district council shall authorize the county planning board to:

paragraph.text: if approved by the district council or County Executive, execute agreements affecting real property in the portion of the regional district in Montgomery County with a person having a legal or equitable interest in the property; and
if requested by any party, include a reviewing entity as an additional party to the agreement.

subsection.text: A local law adopted under this section may specify the circumstances under which a person may request the negotiation and execution of an agreement, including:

paragraph.text: the size, use, zoning, or staging plan of the proposed development; or
other relevant factors, including:

subparagraph.text: the provision of public benefits or amenities; or
growth management policies adopted by the county.

paragraph.text: Before entering into an agreement, a person having a legal or equitable interest in real property, or the person’s representative, shall request that the county planning board consider negotiating and executing an agreement.
A request under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be made as part of a regulatory plan authorized by this division.

subsection.text: Except as provided under subsection (c) of this section, the county planning board may agree to negotiate and enter into an agreement.
The county planning board may not enter into an agreement unless the county planning board has:

paragraph.text: held a public hearing on the proposed agreement; and
determined that the proposed agreement is consistent with the Commission’s general plan.

subsection.text: A public hearing for a regulatory plan satisfies the requirement for a public hearing in subsection (c) of this section.
An agreement shall include:

paragraph.text: a legal description of the real property subject to the agreement;
the names of all persons having a legal or equitable interest in the property;
the duration of the agreement;
the permissible uses of the real property;
the permissible density or intensity of use of the real property;
the maximum height and size of structures;
the general location of all structures and supporting facilities and features;
a description of all anticipated permits required or already approved for the development of the real property;
a statement that the proposed development is consistent with:

subparagraph.text: the Commission’s general plan; and
all applicable development laws and regulations administered by the county planning board;

paragraph.text: a description of the requirements determined by a county planning board to be necessary to ensure the public health, safety, and welfare; and
to the extent applicable, provisions for the:

subparagraph.text: dedication of a portion of the real property for immediate or future public use;
protection of sensitive areas;
preservation and restoration of historic structures; and
construction or financing of public facilities.

subsection.text: An agreement may:

paragraph.text: establish the terms by which, and any period of time when, development or individual phases shall begin and be completed;
incorporate the terms and conditions that would be included in other enforceable agreements and instruments between the parties required as part of a regulatory plan; and
provide for other matters in accordance with this division.

subsection.text: An agreement may not prevent a county planning board, district council, County Executive, or other local, State, or federal government from requiring a person to comply with laws, rules, regulations, and policies enacted after the parties executed the agreement if the district council or the County Executive determines that compliance with the laws, rules, regulations, and policies is essential to ensure the public health, safety, or welfare.

Except as otherwise provided in the agreement under § 24–305(a)(3) of this subtitle or extended by amendment under subsection (b) of this section and § 24–308 of this subtitle, an agreement is void 5 years after execution by the parties.
If approved by the district council or County Executive, as appropriate, the term of an agreement may be extended.

section.text: During the term of an agreement:

paragraph.text: development may occur in accordance with the law and regulations governing the use, density, or intensity of the real property:

subparagraph.text: enacted by the district council and administered by the county planning board or county; and
if applicable, enacted by a reviewing entity and in effect when the project was reviewed and approved by the county planning board and reviewing entity; and

paragraph.text: except as provided in § 24–305(c) of this subtitle, changes to the law and regulations described in paragraph (1) of this section enacted after the parties execute an agreement do not apply to development under the agreement.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the parties to an agreement may amend the agreement by mutual consent.

paragraph.text: The parties to an agreement may not amend the agreement unless:

subparagraph.text: there has been a public hearing on the proposed amendment; and
the district council or County Executive, as appropriate, approves any substantial amendment.

paragraph.text: A county planning board may not amend an agreement unless the county planning board determines that the proposed amendment is consistent with the Commission’s general plan.

subsection.text: The parties to an agreement may terminate the agreement by mutual consent.

paragraph.text: Except as provided under paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the county planning board determines that suspension or termination of an agreement is essential to ensure the public health, safety, or welfare, the county planning board may suspend or terminate the agreement.
The county planning board may not suspend or terminate an agreement unless:

subparagraph.text: there has been a public hearing on the suspension or termination; and
the district council or County Executive, as appropriate, approves the suspension or termination.

paragraph.text: An agreement shall be recorded in the land records of Montgomery County.
If an agreement is not recorded as required under paragraph (1) of this subsection within 20 days after its execution by all parties, the agreement is void.

subsection.text: When an agreement is recorded under subsection (a) of this section, the parties to the agreement and their successors in interest are bound to the agreement.
Unless terminated under § 24–309 of this subtitle, an agreement may be enforced by the parties to the agreement or their successors in interest using all remedies available by law.
No right to an administrative appeal arises from the negotiation or enforcement of an agreement.

section.text: This title applies only in Prince George’s County.

Notwithstanding any other State law, in its rules and procedures the district council may allow a duly elected officer of a bona fide civic association or homeowners association to represent the association before the county planning board, district council, zoning hearing examiner, or board of appeals regardless of whether that individual is an attorney.

subsection.text: The People’s Zoning Counsel or any party of record may request the continuance of a hearing in accordance with this section.
The zoning hearing examiner shall grant a continuance if a required technical staff report has not been filed at least 30 days before the scheduled hearing.
If a continuance is granted under this section, the zoning hearing examiner may not hear the case for at least 30 days after the technical staff report is filed.
All witnesses appearing in a hearing before the district council are subject to cross–examination.

paragraph.text: The district council may establish rules for the administering of oaths to and the cross–examination of witnesses appearing to testify at district council hearings.
Before establishing rules under this subsection, the district council shall conduct a public hearing on the proposed rules.

section.text: A contested application for a map amendment or special exception may not be granted or denied without written findings of material facts and conclusions.
The record of every district council hearing on a map amendment or special exception shall include:

paragraph.text: the vote of each member;
whether the member abstained from voting; or
whether the member was absent.

section.text: If the People’s Zoning Counsel has a reasonable belief that a final action on an application for a subdivision, special exception, variance, or site plan is arbitrary and capricious, the People’s Zoning Counsel may petition for judicial review of the final action on behalf of a bona fide citizens association that is entitled to judicial review under this division.

subsection.text: In this section, “date of disapproval” means:

paragraph.text: the date of the decision of the district council; or
in case of judicial review, the date of the final judgment of the circuit court.

subsection.text: If the district council wholly or partly disapproves an application for a map amendment, it may not act on a subsequent application for any portion of the same land:

paragraph.text: within 18 months after the date of the first disapproval; and
within 24 months after the date of any subsequent disapproval.

subsection.text: In any subsequent application for any portion of the same land and for the same zoning classification or the same purpose for special exception, by the same applicant, the district council may not base its findings solely on any fact or circumstance that was presented at the hearing on the prior application.

section.text: The district council may not approve a special exception to construct or operate a rubble landfill:

paragraph.text: at a site without a three–fourths majority vote of the district council; or
if an application for a special exception to construct or operate a rubble landfill at the site was previously denied on or after October 1, 1981.

subsection.text: The Commission shall prepare a report in accordance with this section before a zoning hearing examiner or the district council may conduct a hearing on a request for a special exception to mine sand or gravel.
The report shall comprehensively evaluate the request by analyzing the impact of the proposed mining activities on the surrounding area, considering only:

paragraph.text: noise;
watershed and water quality;
airshed and air quality;
traffic and traffic safety; and
other environmental factors relating to the health, safety, and welfare of the residents in the affected area.

subsection.text: In addition to the initial filing fee, the applicant shall pay a fee not to exceed $8,000 for the services of the Commission to prepare the report.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the district council may review a final decision of the county planning board to approve or disapprove a detailed site plan.
A party of record may appeal to the district council a final decision by the county planning board to approve or disapprove a site plan.

subsection.text: The district council may only decide whether to review the final approval or disapproval of a detailed site plan under this section within 30 days after the date the final approval or disapproval was issued.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the district council decides to review an approval or a disapproval under this section, the district council shall hold a hearing within 70 days after the district council issues the decision to conduct a review.
The district council may decide to extend the time to hold a hearing under paragraph (1) of this subsection for up to 45 additional days on its own motion or on request of the applicant.

subsection.text: The district council shall issue a final decision within 60 days after the date of the hearing.

The district council may revoke a delegation of site plan approval authority to the county planning board only for the purpose of delegating approval authority over detailed site plans to the governing body of a municipal corporation in the regional district under § 25–301(c)(2)(ix) of this title.

section.text: If the United States Department of Agriculture sells any portion of the property known as the Beltsville Agricultural Research Center, the district council shall place and permanently maintain the land in a zoning classification of agricultural open space immediately after the transfer of the land to the buyer.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the district council may provide that the governing body of a municipal corporation may exercise the powers of the district council as specified in this subtitle.
When exercising authority delegated under subsection (c) or (d) of this section, the governing body of a municipal corporation:

paragraph.text: shall be subject to the substantive and procedural requirements and standards established by the district council; and
may not impose:

subparagraph.text: with respect to general delegation under subsection (c) of this section, a different requirement or standard than the requirements or standards that would apply if the district council had not delegated its authority to the municipal corporation; or

with respect to delegation in a revitalization overlay zone under subsection (d) of this section, a stricter requirement or standard than the requirements or standards that would apply if the district council had not delegated its authority to the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to land in a municipal corporation in the regional district.
The district council may delegate to the governing body of a municipal corporation the powers of the district council regarding:

subparagraph.text: design standards;
parking and loading standards;
sign design standards;
lot size variances and setback and similar requirements;
landscaping requirements;
certification, revocation, and revision of nonconforming uses;
minor changes to approved special exceptions;
vacation of municipal rights–of–way; and
except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, all detailed site plans.

paragraph.text: The authority to delegate with regard to detailed site plans does not apply to detailed site plans:

subparagraph.text: for a zone that requires detailed site plan approval by the district council;
that are required as a condition of approval of a zoning map amendment or a preliminary plan of subdivision;
for which the approval of a conceptual site plan or a preliminary plan of cluster subdivision is required; or
that are required for designated parcels as a specific condition of a sectional map amendment.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a revitalization overlay zone created by the district council.

For any portion of a revitalization overlay zone in a municipal corporation, the district council may delegate to the governing body of a municipal corporation the powers of the district council regarding:

subparagraph.text: design standards;
parking and loading standards;
sign design standards;
lot size variances and setback and similar requirements; and
landscaping requirements.

paragraph.text: The delegation of powers under paragraph (2) of this subsection may not impede a development that meets the requirements the district council sets for the revitalization overlay zone.
For any portion of a revitalization overlay zone not within a municipal corporation, the district council may authorize the county planning board to approve:

subparagraph.text: departures from parking and loading standards;
departures from design standards; and
any variance from the zoning laws.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, any party of record to an action of the governing body of a municipal corporation exercised under § 25–301(c) of this subtitle shall have the same right to judicial review by the circuit court as the party would have if the district council had taken the action.

Any party to an action of the governing body of a municipal corporation or the county planning board exercised under § 25–301(d) of this subtitle shall have the same right to judicial review by the circuit court as the party would have if the district council had taken the action.

With respect to an action taken under the general delegation authorized under § 25–301(c) of this subtitle, before exercising the right to judicial review under subsection (a)(1) of this section, a party of record shall appeal the action of the governing body of the municipal corporation to the district council for review on the record if the action concerns:

subparagraph.text: certification, revocation, or revision of nonconforming uses; or
detailed site plans.

paragraph.text: On appeal, the district council may:

subparagraph.text: approve the action of the municipal corporation by a majority vote of its members; or
approve the action of the municipal corporation with conditions or overrule the action by a vote of at least six members.
A person aggrieved by the action of the district council under this subsection may request judicial review of the action by the circuit court.
The municipal corporation whose action is affected by the action of the district council shall be considered an aggrieved person.

subsection.text: This section applies to land in a municipal corporation that is in the metropolitan district and is:

paragraph.text: zoned for residential or commercial use; or
adjacent to residential or commercial zones.

Notwithstanding any other law, and for the purpose of preserving, improving, or protecting the general character and design of lands and improvements in a municipal corporation, the legislative body of the municipal corporation, by local law, may impose stricter or additional conditions, restrictions, or limitations than are otherwise required by State, regional, or county zoning laws or agencies exercising zoning and planning jurisdiction over the municipal corporation.
The stricter or additional conditions, restrictions, or limitations may apply only to:

subparagraph.text: fences;
residential parking; and
residential storage.

subsection.text: The legislative body of a municipal corporation may not enact a local law under this section without holding a public hearing on all issues.

A municipal corporation that enacts a zoning law in accordance with this section shall deliver a certified copy of the local law to the district council within 5 days after the enactment and at least 30 days before the effective date of the local law.

paragraph.text: If the district council does not approve the local law before the effective date of the local law, the local law shall be considered disapproved and may not take effect.
The local law may not take effect unless approved by the district council.

section.text: The county, by local law, may provide for:

paragraph.text: the revitalization and redevelopment activities of the Commission in the county, including:

subparagraph.text: the organization or management of any revitalization or redevelopment activities of the Commission; and
consolidation of Commission activities with the redevelopment authority of the county; and

paragraph.text: the management and marketing of enterprise operations by the Commission in the county, including consolidation of Commission activities with the revenue authority of the county.

section.text: A local law enacted under this subtitle may not impair or abrogate:

paragraph.text: any right, including merit system and pension system rights, or benefit of any employee of the Commission; or
any pension obligation of the Commission for any Commission employee.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Agreement” means a development rights and responsibilities agreement negotiated and executed by the County Executive or the County Executive’s designee, with the approval of the district council, to establish conditions for advancing school capacity.
“Developer” means a person with a legal or equitable interest in real property located in Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: “Development” means any activity that materially affects the existing condition or use of any land or structure.
“Development” does not include normal agricultural activity.

section.text: A developer or developer’s representative may petition the County Executive to request that an agreement be executed.

subsection.text: Except as provided under subsection (b) of this section, the County Executive may:

paragraph.text: negotiate agreements with a developer for real property located in the county;
include a federal, State, or local government or unit as an additional party to the agreement; and
execute an agreement.

subsection.text: The County Executive may not enter into an agreement unless:

paragraph.text: the agreement is approved by the district council; and
the county planning board determines that the proposed agreement is consistent with the Commission’s general plan.

subsection.text: The district council may:

paragraph.text: establish procedures and requirements for the consideration and execution of agreements, including provisions for negotiation and approval in accordance with this subtitle; and
approve agreements negotiated by the County Executive.

subsection.text: The district council shall require a public hearing before approving an agreement.

section.text: An agreement executed by the County Executive takes effect without any further action by the district council.

subsection.text: An agreement shall include:

paragraph.text: a description of the real property subject to the agreement;
the parties involved;
the specific purposes of the agreement;
the duration of the agreement;
a physical description and location of the structures and supporting facilities and features on the real property;
a description of all anticipated permits required or already approved for the development of the real property;
provisions for the construction or financing of adequate public facilities for schools;
a statement that the proposed development is consistent with:

subparagraph.text: the Commission’s general plan; and
all applicable development laws and regulations; and

paragraph.text: a description of the requirements determined by the county planning board to be necessary to ensure the public health, safety, and welfare.

subsection.text: An agreement may:

paragraph.text: establish the terms by which and a period of time when development, or individual phases, shall begin and be completed; and
provide for other matters in accordance with this division.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in the agreement or extended by amendment under § 25–509 of this subtitle, an agreement is void 15 years after execution by the parties.
Any extension to an agreement is subject to approval by the district council.

section.text: The laws, rules, regulations, and policies in force at the time the parties execute an agreement shall govern the use, density, or intensity of development of the real property subject to the agreement unless the district council or State or federal government determines that compliance with laws, rules, regulations, and policies enacted after the parties executed the agreement is essential to ensure public health, safety, or welfare.
The parties to an agreement may amend the agreement by mutual consent if the district council:

paragraph.text: approves any substantive amendment; and
determines that the proposed amendment to the agreement is consistent with the Commission’s general plan.

subsection.text: The parties to an agreement may terminate the agreement by mutual consent.

If the County Executive determines that suspension or termination of an agreement is essential to ensure the public health, safety, or welfare, the County Executive may suspend or terminate the agreement.

paragraph.text: An agreement shall be recorded in the land records of Prince George’s County.
If an agreement is not recorded as required under paragraph (1) of this subsection within 30 days after its execution by all parties, the agreement is void.

subsection.text: When an agreement is recorded under subsection (a) of this section, the parties to the agreement and their successors in interest are bound to the agreement.
Unless terminated under § 25–510 of this subtitle, an agreement may be enforced by the parties to the agreement or their successors in interest using all remedies available at law or in equity.
No right to an administrative appeal arises from the negotiation or enforcement of an agreement.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agricultural property” means property that is used for:

paragraph.text: agriculture, viticulture, aquaculture, silviculture, horticulture, or livestock and equine activities;
temporary or seasonal outdoor activities that do not permanently alter the property’s physical appearance and that do not diminish the property’s rural character; or
activities that are intrinsically related to the ongoing agricultural enterprise on the property.

subsection.text: “District” means the Prince George’s County Soil Conservation District.
“Fund” means the Prince George’s County Agricultural Preservation Easement Fund.
“Preservation” means the limitation of the use of agricultural property to those uses consistent with, and not adversely affecting:

paragraph.text: the agricultural character of the property;
the scenic values enjoyed by the public; or
the governmental preservation policies furthered by the easement acquisition.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Prince George’s County Agricultural Preservation Easement Program.
There is a Prince George’s County Agricultural Preservation Easement Program.
The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: implement the policies of the county’s general plan and the Green Infrastructure Plan to preserve, protect, and enhance agricultural properties, particularly those in the Rural Tier;

preserve ecologically fragile and aesthetically valuable environments of the county, including streams, stream valleys, floodplains, wetlands, groundwater, steep slopes, woodlands, habitats, scenic vistas, and scenic corridors;
retain agricultural land and augment other local and State programs certified in accordance with the Code of Maryland Regulations for the preservation of agricultural land;
recognize the public value in protecting agriculture and agricultural viewsheds, vistas, rural culture and character, and longstanding agricultural enterprises;
limit nonagricultural uses;
conserve and protect biodiversity and wildlife and aquatic habitats;
promote interest in and the study of agriculture and agricultural preservation; and
promote tourism through the preservation of scenic resources.

section.text: The District shall administer the Program in accordance with regulations that the county planning board and the District adopt under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The County Council may enact local laws to provide for:

paragraph.text: agricultural preservation, outreach, and marketing;
maintenance of activities on agricultural properties of the Commission; and
the preservation of the agricultural industry.

subsection.text: A local law enacted under subsection (a) of this section may not be inconsistent with this division.
The county planning board and the District shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.
The regulations shall:

paragraph.text: establish an application process for the Program;
establish criteria for assigning priorities to applications for easements to purchase;
establish a process for negotiating the purchase of easements;
allow the District to procure any appraisals necessary for valuation of each easement; and
specify a method for appraising and valuing easements to encourage landowners to participate in the Program and maximize the acreage for easements to be purchased.

subsection.text: The regulations may provide for the adjudication and appeal of any disputed easement valuation by the county Property Tax Assessment Appeal Board in accordance with § 2–511 of the Agriculture Article.
There is a Prince George’s County Agricultural Preservation Easement Fund.
The county planning board shall administer the Fund.
The Fund consists of revenues from county metropolitan district taxes or county regional district taxes.
The purposes of the Fund are to:

paragraph.text: preserve, protect, and enhance agricultural properties; and
implement the purposes of the Program.
The Fund shall be used to purchase easements to implement the Program.
In deciding which easements to purchase using the Fund, the county planning board shall:

subparagraph.text: exercise prudence and due diligence; and
consider the recommendations of the District.

subsection.text: The county planning board may purchase an easement on agricultural property in the county that is outside the metropolitan district but is in the regional district.

To further the purposes of the Program, the county planning board may expend any current money that is authorized under this division to be used to purchase easements in the county in the metropolitan district.

When an agricultural preservation easement is purchased in accordance with this subtitle, the property owner shall convey a perpetual preservation easement to the county planning board at the time of settlement.
The easement shall be recorded in the county land records.

section.text: Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article does not apply to this subtitle.

The county shall cooperate or contract with the United States in any matter relating to any project for flood control or navigation in the valleys of the Anacostia River and its tributaries in the county.

subsection.text: Before the county enters into any contract or agreement with the United States and before any plan relating to a flood control or navigation project or the maintenance or operation of a flood control or navigation project is approved, the county shall submit for consideration each contract, agreement, or plan affecting a State road or land in a park or parkway under the jurisdiction of the Commission to:

paragraph.text: the State Highway Administration; and
the Commission.

subsection.text: The county may not approve a plan or enter into a contract or an agreement that is inconsistent with:

paragraph.text: the purposes of the Capper–Cramton Act, Public Law 71–284, 46 Stat. 482; or
any agreement between the Commission and the National Capital Planning Commission related to the park and parkway system authorized by that Act.

subsection.text: Except for costs borne by the United States or the State Highway Administration, the county shall pay all costs of a flood control or navigation project from the Stormwater Management Fund.
The county shall apply the Fund to the cost of:

paragraph.text: constructing and relocating all county roads and bridges related to the flood control or navigation project;
constructing necessary internal drainage facilities;
relocating utility structures; and
acquiring land and buildings necessary for the flood control or navigation projects.

subsection.text: The county may accept contributions from the United States, the District of Columbia, the State, Montgomery County, any municipal corporation or special taxing district, or any other person if the county determines that the contribution may assist in the construction of any project under this subtitle.

section.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: may use the lands acquired for flood control or navigation projects for park purposes if the use does not interfere with the construction, maintenance, and operation of the projects; and
shall control and operate recreational facilities within the projects.

subsection.text: The county planning board shall:

paragraph.text: provide an adequate and balanced program of recreation to serve the needs and interests of various age groups among the residents of the county; and
coordinate the program with the Commission’s park functions.

subsection.text: The county planning board may develop a program of recreation that may include physical, social, mental, and creative opportunities that the county planning board considers appropriate to offer in:

paragraph.text: major recreation centers, playfields, athletic fields, playgrounds, tennis courts, baseball diamonds, swimming pools, golf courses, community centers, and social centers on publicly or privately owned land or buildings made available for these purposes or over which the county planning board has sole or joint jurisdiction; or
land or buildings of a municipal corporation or political subdivision in the county, if the municipal corporation or political subdivision requests the services of the county planning board.

subsection.text: The county planning board may contract with recreation or sports groups or associations to incorporate the activities of the groups or associations into the program established by the county planning board under this subtitle.

section.text: The county planning board, in the development and conduct of its recreation program and in scheduling the use of publicly owned land or buildings for the conduct of the program, shall cooperate with recognized and generally accepted agencies, groups, and organizations that may request to use the land or buildings.
The county planning board may accept grants and gifts from any source to carry out this subtitle.
The county planning board may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to confirmation by the County Council, the County Executive:

paragraph.text: shall appoint a standing advisory committee on recreation, which shall be representative of the residents of the county; and
may appoint additional advisory committees on recreation as necessary.

subsection.text: The county planning board may make recommendations regarding the functions and membership of the advisory committees.
The county planning board shall prepare and submit to the County Council an annual budget, including a schedule of recreation activities and programs.
The County Council’s approval of the recreation schedule is concurrence in the recreation activities and programs proposed for any fiscal year.
The County Council may:

paragraph.text: modify the recreation schedule; and
direct the county planning board to initiate any recreation activity or program.

subsection.text: The county planning board shall initiate any activity or program directed by the County Council with reasonable promptness to the extent funds are available for that purpose.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Enterprise Fund” means the Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission Enterprise Fund.
“Marina” means the Bladensburg Marina and Boat Basin established by Chapter 618 of the Acts of 1959, and all improvements, facilities, and appurtenances of the Bladensburg Marina and Boat Basin.

subsection.text: The Commission shall administer, maintain, and operate the Marina.
The Commission:

paragraph.text: shall adopt regulations for the use and enjoyment of the Marina to assure that the improvements and facilities are open to all residents on equal terms;
shall set the fees for the use of the public and commercial navigation facilities; and
may contract with the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission for dredging activities relating to the maintenance and operation of the Marina.
There is a Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission Enterprise Fund.
The Enterprise Fund shall finance and account for the maintenance and operation of the Marina.
The Commission shall record revenues from the maintenance and operation of the Marina in the Enterprise Fund.
The Commission shall use the revenues of the Enterprise Fund:

subparagraph.text: to offset expenditures relating to the Marina; or
for other enterprise funds of the Commission’s park and recreational facilities located in the regional district in the county.

paragraph.text: Each year the County Council shall impose on all property assessed for county tax purposes in the county an ad valorem tax at a rate that the Commission certifies as necessary to produce the amount required to pay the annual cost of the Marina, less the proceeds of the Enterprise Fund.
The annual cost includes the cost of dredging operations relating to the maintenance and operation of the Marina.
Montgomery County is not liable for any cost, debt, expense, or obligation relating to the administration, operation, or maintenance of the Marina.
Funds for the administration, operation, or maintenance of the Marina may not be obtained from:

subparagraph.text: Montgomery County’s portion of the budget; or
Montgomery County’s portion of unbudgeted funds of the Commission.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means:

paragraph.text: in Montgomery County, the Montgomery County Historic Preservation Grant Fund; and
in Prince George’s County, the Prince George’s County Historic Property Grant Fund.
“Historic property” means a district, site, building, structure, or object significant in the history, upland or underwater archaeology, architecture, engineering, or culture of the State.
“Historic property” includes remains related to a district, site, building, structure, or object described in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: “Preservation” means the identification, evaluation, recordation, documentation, acquisition, protection, management, rehabilitation, restoration, stabilization, maintenance, or reconstruction of a historic property.
“Program” means:

paragraph.text: in Montgomery County, the Montgomery County Historic Preservation Grant Program; and
in Prince George’s County, the Prince George’s County Historic Property Grant Program.
There is a Montgomery County Historic Preservation Grant Program.
There is a Prince George’s County Historic Property Grant Program.

subsection.text: The purposes of each Program are to:

paragraph.text: preserve, protect, and enhance historic properties;
encourage others to preserve, protect, and enhance historic properties; and
promote interest in and the study of historic properties.

section.text: Each Program is of general benefit to the residents of the State and is charitable in nature.

subsection.text: The powers and duties of each Program are vested in and exercised by:

paragraph.text: in Montgomery County, the county planning board in consultation with the Montgomery County Historic Preservation Commission; and
subject to subsection (b) of this section, in Prince George’s County, the county planning board.
In Prince George’s County, the county, by local law, may provide for the historic preservation, outreach and marketing, and maintenance of historic properties activities of the Commission.
A local law enacted under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be consistent with the provisions of this division.
There is a Montgomery County Historic Preservation Grant Fund.
There is a Prince George’s County Historic Property Grant Fund.

subsection.text: Each county planning board administers its Fund.
Each county planning board shall deposit in its Fund those amounts authorized in accordance with Title 18, Subtitle 1 of this article to:

paragraph.text: implement and encourage restoration and preservation of historic properties; and
implement the purposes of its Program.
Each county planning board shall expend the amounts in its Fund to make grants to nonprofit organizations or foundations.
In Montgomery County:

subparagraph.text: grants may also be made for research, developing educational materials, and generally promoting historic preservation; and
in making grants, the county planning board, if practical to do so, shall obtain and implement the recommendations of the Montgomery County Historic Preservation Commission.

paragraph.text: In Prince George’s County:

subparagraph.text: grants may also be made to political subdivisions or individuals to acquire, preserve, restore, or rehabilitate historic properties; and
in making grants, the county planning board shall solicit and consider the recommendations of the Prince George’s County Historic Preservation Commission.

subsection.text: When a county planning board awards a grant, the grant recipient shall convey a perpetual preservation easement to the county planning board.

paragraph.text: Decisions by a county planning board concerning grants shall be made without regard to the financial status or annual income of the applicant.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, a county planning board may require matching funds in whatever proportion the county planning board considers appropriate.

section.text: Each county planning board shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.
Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article does not apply to this subtitle.

subsection.text: A charge alleging a violation of this division may be brought by warrant or indictment on the oath or information of a member or employee of the Commission or any other person.
Except as otherwise provided, a misdemeanor under this division may be adjudicated before the District Court or the circuit court of the county in which the violation is committed.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this division, a person who violates this division is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or a fine not exceeding $500 or both.
Each day that a violation of this division continues is a separate violation.

subsection.text: An owner or tenant of a building or private premises or an agent of the owner or tenant may not restrain or hinder the entry, examination, survey, or placing or maintenance of monuments or marks by a commissioner or an employee or agent of the Commission under § 15–118 of this article.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or a fine not exceeding $500 or both.
Each day a violation continues is a separate violation.
